It appears that these rules are to apply to defendants as well as to witnesses in court proceedings and to members of Parliament as well as to witnesses before parliamentary committees. In reaching these conclusions the judge has rejected contrary principles expounded in a number of British and Australian judgments.

I do not intend to make any detailed comment upon the judgment at this stage, but I draw the attention of the Senate to two parts of the judgment where I am advised that the judge seems not to have correctly stated what was submitted to him by counsel acting on my instructions. At page 11 of the judgment His Honour states that it was submitted that even to ask a witness whether or not he had made a particular statement to a parliamentary committee would be to impeach or question that statement. No such submission was made by counsel acting on my instructions. The written submissions accept that evidence of parliamentary proceedings may be used to prove material facts so long as there is no questioning or impeaching of the proceedings.

This could well involve the type of question referred to by His Honour, but is to be distinguished from the examination of a witness or the accused for the purpose of impeaching his evidence. At page 16 and in other parts of the judgment His Honour implies that the submissions relied upon the supposed rule that evidence of proceedings in Parliament may not be given in court without the approval of the House concerned. This also was not submitted by counsel acting on my instructions, and in fact the written submissions were at pains to draw a distinction between this so-called rule, which was really only a practice, and the principle contained in Article 9.

I also point out that in the first trial evidence given before Senate committees in camera and not published by the committees or the Senate was used to cross-examine witnesses and the accused. The judgment does not address itself specifically to the unauthorised use of in camera evidence, and presumably would allow any such use of in camera evidence. I present to the Senate a copy of the written submissions which were made on my instructions and a copy of Mr Justice Hunt's judgment. Copies of these documents are available for honourable senators. I will be considering the judgment, consulting Madam Speaker and honourable senators and deliberating upon what action should be taken in relation to the judgment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and papers.

Mr President, like you, I do not propose to comment in any detailed way at this stage on the statement and the issues raised by it except to say that it is clear that, quite apart from its immediate impact on the conduct of the Murphy case, the decision of Mr Justice Hunt in this matter raises questions of very great significance for both Houses of this Parliament. The larger issues concern the nature and extent of the protection afforded to parliamentarians and witnesses appearing before committees by Article 9 of the Bill of Rights, as a matter of law. It also raises quite starkly the question of what in principle should be the scope of that privilege.

Mr Justice Hunt, in his decision, gave what is on any view the narrowest possible interpretation that one could ever take on the scope of the Article 9 protection. I make the point only that these issues require very careful consideration by the Senate and, indeed, by our colleagues in the House of Representatives. It may be that an appropriate vehicle for giving these issues that consideration would be the Bill on the privileges of the Parliament that has been prepared as a result of the deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege, chaired by Mr Spender, which Bill is now before the House of Representatives. It may be that, having dragged our feet for about 86 years on the clarification and codification of privilege, we should now accelerate, particularly in the light of the Hunt decision, our consideration of these very important matters. A great number of issues of substance could be canvassed. I do not think that it is appropriate for any of us to do so at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —When would you expect the Government to come to a decision?

—The Government has taken the view that matters of privilege are not party matters but, traditionally, free vote matters. The way that it has been handled so far has been for the Manager of Government Business simply to make time available in a preliminary way-but hopefully there will be more extended time later on for the debate of the Spender Bill. The decision in this matter will concentrate everyone's minds rather more wonderfully than might otherwise have been the case. It is quite possible that there will be a general disposition stretching across party boundaries now to focus squarely on these issues; work out what in principle we really ought to be doing about describing precisely how the law operates in this area and whether we accept the conclusions of Mr Justice Hunt and in getting some appropriate legislation through. All I am saying is that this is a matter to which we all have to give close consideration over the next few days and the next couple of weeks. I would think it is appropriate that we not have an extended debate this morning but simply give the matter close consideration and bring it back to the Parliament at some early appropriate time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I support the remarks made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, who commented on your statement. I would also like to say how entirely appropriate I believe your initiative was, as President of the Senate, in instructing counsel to seek leave to make submissions to the judge who will preside at the second trial of Mr Justice Murphy. As you have said, following consultation with representatives of the three major parties in the Senate, counsel was instructed and he made very adequate submissions to the judge who has now given his judgment. He has virtually rejected at least the major submissions that were made on behalf of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that it would be inappropriate to pursue the matter any further in the courts at this stage in light of the imminent trial and any further legal proceedings appealing from what the judge has said. However, it is quite clear that the view which the judge has taken is very different from the one that we expected, even considering differences that occur amongst ourselves as to the ambit of our privileges. I think Mr Justice Hunt's decisions as to the ambit of those privileges will be a surprise to almost everybody in this chamber and in the other place. Obviously, it is a most controversial decision which has not followed many other decisions. It is a good example of how little one can be sure of what judges will decide.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the common law at work. That is why you need a Bill of Rights.
—If we had a Bill of Rights we would be even more under the power of judges when making decisions about what we could and could not do.
—Rubbish.

—It is a classic case. This is a judge who is taking a completely different line from that taken by many other judges. If one gives them wide powers one does not know where one will end up. However, that is by the way. Clearly the matter has to be given very urgent consideration by this Parliament. I think the time has come when we have to make these matters clear. In fairness to the judge, the Bill of Rights was stated in somewhat uncertain and old fashioned language and the judge had some difficulties. I do not think it is appropriate for this matter to be litigated any further. We, as parliamentarians, have to make up our minds promptly where we stand and make suitable declaration, hopefully by as wide agreement as we can possibly reach amongst ourselves, about the ambit of these privileges.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the legislation that has already been introduced in another place and the legislation that has been introduced in this place, I think by Senator Macklin, should be brought on for debate fairly soon. Incidentally, I do not think this should occur until after the trial has concluded. But I certainly agree that this is a matter that we must attend to promptly as soon as that inhibiting factor is out of the way. It has been inhibiting us on a number of matters, the most important of which is the consideration of a report of a Senate committee which needs to be considered promptly when that trial is concluded. It is a quite serious reflection on us that recommendations of the Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege, which are having a great effect on certain people, have not been considered by this chamber. That has not been done because any debate here on that matter may be relevant to and affect the trial of Mr Justice Murphy. There are two major matters to which we must attend as soon as that trial is out of the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the motion moved by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of the motion, add `, and the Senate considers that the Parliament should give urgent consideration to legislation to avoid the consequences of the unacceptable change in the law contained in the judgment of the Supreme Court of New South Wales'.

The crux of the matter here was pointed out by Senator Evans, namely, that, for all of the period since Federation, governments have had the power to do something about section 49 of the Constitution but have not done so. As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege, which operated from 1982 to 1984 and of which Senator Evans was also a member, I remind the Senate that we laboured mightily and produced a report. All of us on the Committee hoped that that report would lead to some urgent action. Interestingly enough, when the report was put down, Senator Evans was Attorney-General and he promised urgent consideration of that matter. Time has moved on and, urgent consideration no doubt having been given, it is now 1986 and we find another reason for not doing anything. It seems a great pity that the members of this chamber and of the other chamber take very little interest in this matter, which probably accounts for the fact that 87 years have gone by and nothing has been done.

Having read the judgment-I hope that honourable senators will read the judgment-I say that it makes extraordinary reading on any account. I wish to refer to only one aspect. Unfortunately this aspect is often presented in the media as our, that is the parliamentarians, protecting ourselves. Quite frankly, one of the major innovations in parliamentary practice occurred in the Senate, interestingly and coincidentally enough under Senator Murphy, in terms of the extension of the committee system. Fairly obviously, the Senate committee system is a much more extensive, more powerful and more innovative system than that of the House of Representatives. What we are looking at here is in fact damage to our committee system. We are considering the witnesses. We are not necessarily considering ourselves. After all, parliamentarians are pretty used to taking knocks in the media or elsewhere as part of the job. But our committee system relies on our witnesses not having to take those knocks anywhere else. It relies on their being able to give evidence to committees.

Although I am not a lawyer, having read the judgment I suggest that it could result in people who give evidence at in camera hearings of our committees having all that evidence rehearsed in open court. Quite frankly, what that would do to our powers, privileges and immunities as parliamentarians would be nil, but what it would to our ability to operate as parliamentarians would be a great deal and what it would do to witnesses would be devastating. If we just sit here and continue to twiddle our thumbs, that is what will happen. But I hope that members of all parties-this is not a party matter-will talk to the President of the Senate and support him in what he is doing in this regard, so that the privileges of this House in terms of our operations in committees can be protected.

I look back over a number of committees and point to the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. The Chairman of that Committee is no longer with us as he is a Minister of the Tasmanian Government. By ensuring that evidence given at in camera hearings would never be leaked, that Committee was able to look at confidential commercial information and establish a law in this country which is now operating very successfully and very well. That Committee's proceedings could not have taken place unless there were in camera hearings and unless the witnesses who appeared before the Committee could be absolutely assured that the information they gave would not go anywhere else.

I think it is extraordinary that we should be entertaining the idea that we have to wait until a court case is finished. I have no reason to interfere in that court case and I would suggest that any deliberation on the Parliamentary Powers, Privileges and Immunities Bill which I introduced in the Senate on 22 August has nothing whatsoever to do with that. If it is felt in any shape or form that the proclamation of the Bill by the Governor-General could impinge on that court case, I suggest that the Parliament could quite happily pass the Bill and the Governor-General could wait upon the conclusion of that court case before he signs it into law. But, quite frankly, I do not think it has anything to do with the deliberation of what this chamber thinks are its powers and privileges. I am fearful that, if we wait yet again for something else, we will be waiting for another 86 years. I emphasise that it is not a matter of protecting ourselves from the media. If we look at the report of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege we will see that that report states quite clearly that we were quite happy to give away quite a number of those seeming privileges. They are really no longer of relevance in today's world, whether or not our dignity is dented by what people say about us.

I think it is to the everlasting credit of the Senate that the Privileges Committee of the Senate has never gone down the track of worrying about our dignity but rather it has worried about the effective use of this chamber and its committees. That is all the Senate has ever been concerned about in terms of its privileges and I am very proud that that has been the case. I cannot say that that is the case for the other place because it is not; but it is the case for the Senate. I think we have very correctly seen that our privileges are not so much for ourselves but for the good government of this country and for the protection of witnesses who come before us to provide information to enable us to make the types of decisions about laws that this country requires. Unless all of us do something about it, it will not happen.

I raise again the fact that I introduced on 22 August last year a Bill which differs in its drafting fairly substantially from the Bill introduced by Mr Spender in the other place. In fact, there are only minor differences in consequence. I introduced the Bill because I wanted to give this chamber a Bill with which to operate and also to give an alternative wording. I say in defence of my Bill, and in doing so I will not impinge upon Standing Orders, that it was intended to give a much simpler wording to what the privileges are and to make it much easier for people outside this chamber to understand precisely what it was were trying to do. What I was trying to do in that Bill is what I have just put to the Senate. We are not about our own protection-I emphasise that for the third time-but we are about doing our job properly and using the privileges that have been provided to this chamber to do that job properly.

I give great support to you, Mr President, in the activities that you have been pursuing with Madam Speaker. I hope that you will be able to come back to this chamber very rapidly on that. You may even consider taking the unprecedented step of sponsoring a Bill with regard to the privileges and immunities of this chamber. I know that it is unprecedented but I suggest that, at the moment, we have no action being taken and we are not likely to get any because of the enormous legislative pressure which operates on any government. I am not being condemnatory of the current Government. There has been 86 years of government in this country and nothing has happened. All governments have to look at their legislative programs. In directing my remarks to you, Mr President, I wonder whether it may not be a time for unprecedented action on your part in sponsoring a Bill in this chamber and providing time, as you are able to do, for us to debate that Bill. I would hope that you might give serious consideration to the proposal I put to you because it seems to me that without your taking some action nothing is ever likely to happen. I do believe it is your responsibility, as our Presiding Officer, to undertake some action with regard to legislation on this matter so that by the time this Parliament rises we may have a Bill to fulfil the provisions of section 49 of the Constitution.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRADE PRACTICES (TRANSFER OF MARKET DOMINANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trade practices legislation that we have been debating in the Senate off and on for the whole of this current sitting period has now been split by the Government into two Bills-the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill which is before us at the moment and the Trade Practices Revision Bill. The Trade Practices Revision Bill includes all the amendments contained in the earlier Trade Practices Amendment Bill. A number of amendments were proposed by the Opposition, by the Australian Democrats and indeed by the Government. The Bill immediately before us, the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill, simply deals with one amendment to the Trade Practices Act which was previously contained in the general Trade Practices Amendment Bill, that is, the amendment proposed by the Government to section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to provide that that section, which deals with the acquisition of a dominant position in a market for goods, will not apply to the acquisition by a person of any shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate where before the acquisition the body corporate was in a position to dominate a market for goods and services and as a result of the acquisition a person is not and is not likely to be in a stronger position to dominate that market.

SPEECH.PARA: We had reached that amendment that the Government now proposes when it was contained in the previous Trade Practices Amendment Bill. We had debated the pros and cons of that amendment and had considered amendments to it. In fact, we had disposed of that question. So what we are really doing today is having a revived debate about that issue only, in a separate Bill, the Government obviously desiring that this question be dealt with and disposed of promptly in the Parliament and not be subject to the undoubted delays that are occurring and will occur as a result of the many amendments to what was the general Trade Practices Amendment Bill, or what the Government calls the Trade Practices Revision Bill. The Opposition has exactly the same view about the transfer of market dominance amendment as we expressed here in this chamber only several weeks ago. We support the amendment, and we shall be proposing an amendment to it to make sure that it does not apply to a takeover proposal that has already commenced in a legal sense-that is, where a part A offer has been registered or lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that amendment available?
—It is being circulated, but it is in exactly the same terms as the amendment we moved and debated here a few weeks ago.
—Do you mean the original grandfather clause?

—It is exactly the same as the grandfather clause that we moved before. I thought that I was making it clearer for people who may be listening and who do not know what a grandfather clause is. I thought I would explain in full exactly what it means. Senator Siddons perhaps understands better what is meant by a grandfather clause than do other people.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that this amendment is being made is that since 1977 when amendments were made to the Trade Practices Act, including this particular section dealing with mergers and the creation of monopolies, there have been doubts whether that section of the Trade Practices Act would apply simply to the bare transfer of monopoly power. In other words, where there is a monopoly contrary to the purposes and use of the Trade Practices Act-where a monopoly in fact has existed or exists, for whatever reason-the transfer of the ownership of that monopoly, whether by way of takeover or however, may be seen to be a breach of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act. That Act is concerned with the prevention of monopolies occurring. It is concerned with promoting competition, but it is not itself directly concerned with the Trade Practices Act. The policy of the Act is not concerned with who actually owns a particular corporation and whether or not that corporation has a monopoly power. So this interpretation of the existing section 50 which has already been made, although there is doubt and dispute about it, is certainly not within the policy of the Trade Practices Act.

There may be other policy reasons quite apart from trade practices policy, such as competition policy legislation, why some interest should be taken by government, by Parliament and by the public in the ownership and performance of monopolies. But that is certainly not part of the policy behind the Trade Practices Act. The matter is one which perhaps this Parliament should address on some other occasion, but the problem with the use of the Act or its possible use for this purpose is that not only is the policy and object of the Act not concerned with this aspect, but the Act itself is not drafted appropriately. The criteria are not appropriate to the sort of inquiry and investigation which may well be justified in relation to a monopoly or transfer of the ownership of the monopoly.

The problem is that the Trade Practices Act which prevents, if it does, the acquisition by takeover of an existing monopoly or the bare transfer of monopoly power, as it is called, would in general terms have that effect, but the Act provides for authorisations to be obtained by people who would be otherwise in breach of the Act. In order to establish an authorisation for conduct which is otherwise in breach of the Act, the person seeking that authorisation has to prove an actual public benefit-the authorisation of conduct which would be otherwise in breach of the Act. That authorisation procedure and that proving of a positive public benefit is apposite and appropriate for the other purposes and objects of the Trade Practices Act. It may be argued that conduct which would end up in a dominant position in the market which does not already exist may in fact be for the public benefit. That can be directly proved, but whether simply a new owner of a monopoly can be said to be able to provide any clear positive public benefit as against the previous owner is not by any means such an easy thing to do or even that can be adequately and sensibly done, certainly not within the four corners of competition policy legislation such as the Trade Practices Act. It is all about promoting competition, preventing the lessening of competition, the acquisition of monopolies and so on. This legislation is not directed to the actual control of a monopoly or the ownership of a monopoly.

Those are the reasons why we accept the Government's view that this section should be amended to make it clear that it does not apply to this bare transfer of monopoly power. I reiterate that section 50 is by no means clear that it does in fact do that. There is a lot of controversy whether it does or does not. Incidentally, in the particular takeover that is in the forefront of all our minds, namely the Bell Resources Ltd takeover offer for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Bell Resources has at no stage seen fit to seek authorisation. One can only presume that Bell Resources' legal advice is that the section does not apply. I think there are probably very good grounds for that legal advice. There may be some other advice I am not aware of, but it seems to me quite likely that Bell Resources is maintaining that section 50 does not apply to this situation anyway. I think there are very good reasons why that could be argued, but the best reasons of all are that the matter should be clarified. When we pass legislation here, where it is uncertain that provisions may or may not apply, it is best to clarify the position. This piece of legislation clarifies the position and the Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the proposed amendment that has been circulated by Senator Durack and also to support the general thrust of the Government's Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill 1986 in specifically getting rid of a problem which clearly relates to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover. In view of other amendments to the Trade Practices Act that the Government is endeavouring to get through this House, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, there is no doubt that there is a clear need to get rid of this particular section of it, as the Government has recommended, because of the consequences for any company that has a small subsidiary, for example, in a market such as the Australian Capital Territory, which is a nonsensically small market. I have already pointed out in dealing with other elements of the Trade Practices Act amendments before the Senate that to suggest that market dominance in a market as small as the Australian Capital Territory enables a company to be subjected to the requirements of this Act is arrant nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: If this section of the Act is not removed it would mean that any company that had a small subsidiary trading in the Australian Capital Territory, where it had in this minute market a position regarded as dominant, would be subject to the sorts of inquiries and so on that are required under this Act. The point I make has two consequences. In the first place it is a nonsense for the Government to require that market dominance in such a small market be regarded as market dominance. The Australian Capital Territory obviously should be regarded as part of the national market. But it also underlines the fact that if the Government is determined to proceed with its asinine change in that direction, it is absolutely essential that it get rid of this requirement.

With BHP, only one of its operations is basically monopolistic and has market dominance, and that is its steel operation. If it owned a group of lolly shops which dominated the market in the Australian Capital Territory as well, and that would not be a significant element of its activities, under the Government's proposals BHP, because of its dominance of lolly shops in the Australian Capital Territory, would be obliged to come under the requirements of examination and be subject to the question of market dominance, which, as I suggest, is a clear nonsense.

The fact that the steel activities of BHP are a monopoly dramatises the situation, but there are many activities of BHP which do not involve monopolistic activities. One could hardly accuse the coal industry, in which BHP has a major investment, of being an industry free of competition. It certainly is a most competitive area. The oil industry is very competitive indeed, and is subject, as we have seen, to massive fluctuations in market price. BHP's activities in iron ore are similarly excessively competitive in terms of the people in that market. In other words, in the great bulk of BHP's activities now there is in fact no element of monopoly. There is in respect of one area, and that is steel. The Government has a role in the steel industry which surely gives it the capacity to express a policy view about the manner in which BHP should undertake its activities in steel or, in fact, the manner in which BHP, dominated by a different board, should conduct its activities in steel and that, of course, is as a result of arrangements under the steel industry plan. In other words, there are plenty of other methods by which a government could properly require appropriate behaviour by that subsidiary of BHP which is in a monopolistic area. It is one of the reasons I strongly support the Government's removal from the Bill of these requirements relating to trade practices. In fact, when this came before the Parliament initially it was not even raised as an issue either by the Government or by the Opposition.

In this context I should say that my personal hope is that the BHP board will be successful. I find nothing attractive about partial takeovers which leave shareholders locked into a company whose directions and attitudes may well be changed. There is no doubt that partial takeovers such as this one leave majority shareholders at risk. I am hopeful that the major institutional shareholders will at least partly remain as shareholders in BHP. In fact, I would hope that they will keep all of their holdings in BHP. One would also hope that these institutions would ensure that there would be no change in course or direction by BHP, if Mr Holmes a Court succeeds, that would in any way result in any disadvantage to the majority shareholders and lead to the advantage of the Bell Group or Mr Holmes a Court.

There have been instances in the past of partial takeovers such as this resulting in a shuffling of assets, to the clear disadvantage of the shareholders in the existing company and to the advantage of the company which has made the partial takeover bid. We have to recognise that this bid is clearly not a bid for even half of everyone's holding at the moment. In fact, Mr Holmes a Court seeks only 20 per cent more. The essential point is that those people who receive a good price for a small part of their holding in BHP could well end up with a much reduced value for the great bulk of their shareholding. That is a judgment that people in the market must take. It is improper, I suggest, for governments to intrude and tell shareholders what is best for them. I think it improper that the rights of shareholders should be taken away from them by government intervention. That is why I welcome the Government's removal of this section under this amendment now.

It is essential to recognise that the interest of shareholders in BHP is best served by allowing them to make up their own minds. Non-intervention in the market place has traditionally been the philosophic view of the parties on this side of the House and I must say that I welcome the Government to that position. Its conversion has been effective and I am grateful that the attitudes it so strongly opposed in Opposition are now embraced so enthusiastically in government.

I conclude simply by stressing that BHP in itself is monopolistic in respect of only one element of its activities-that relates to steel-and that there are many areas where the Government can, if there are matters of public policy involved, intervene quite properly in that monopolistic area. But for any political party in Australia to suggest that there should be intervention which diminishes the rights of shareholders in relation to a company the bulk of whose activities are very competitive indeed and are in a very competitive environment on the basis that a part of its activities is monopolistic, is to create an impossible situation because there may be many companies indeed one of whose subsidiaries may be dominant in a small market under the Trade Practices Act, as the Government proposes to amend it, which would render it liable to this kind of governmental intervention. I congratulate the Government for recognising the error of its ways in this respect, but I only hope that it will recognise the error of its ways in respect of dominance in such small markets and reconsiders those other elements of the Trade Practices Act which it is resubmitting to this chamber and which will be to the disadvantage of the business community of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has split the trade practices legislation in two in what can only be described as a cynical exercise designed to interfere in the takeover battle between Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Bell. Despite the protestations from the Government and the protestations that we have just heard from the Opposition, the facts of the matter are that the Government is interfering in this takeover battle; it is interfering in the market-place in spite of its protestations. Mr Holmes a Court has now issued three takeover bids for the BHP company under the existing law. This is the third or the fourth-I have forgotten which-takeover bid under the existing law. The Government is now proposing to change the law to make it easier for Holmes a Court to get control of BHP. I find it totally incomprehensible why the Government, in the middle of the largest takeover battle this country has ever seen, is hell-bent on doing just that. It is refusing to hold up the legislation until the outcome is decided. It has refused to amend the legislation so that a public benefit inquiry can be held. It will be interesting to see whether the Government is prepared to let this piece of legislation go to a Senate committee so that we can get a balanced view on what is going on.

SPEECH.PARA: When the ends justify the means, one gets very strange bedfellows. Judging from the Opposition's comments, it would seem that it will be supporting this Government's legislation. In other words, we shall see an alliance on this BHP takeover bid that I never thought I would see in my country, involving Mr Halfpenny and a Labor-Liberal alliance, designed to make it easy for one, Mr Holmes a Court, to take over Australia's largest enterprise. Why is the Government doing this? I leave it to Government members of this Parliament to answer that question. There must be some reason why the Government is so hell-bent on making it easy for Holmes a Court to take over BHP.

Let me make the Australian Democrats' position abundantly clear. We are not taking sides in the BHP-Holmes a Court takeover battle, but what we are saying, loud and clear, is that the rules should not be changed in the middle of the game. I understood Senator Durack to say, in the speech that he has just given and in previous speeches on this issue, that the rules should not be changed in the middle of the game. But that is precisely what the Government is doing. It is changing section 50 so that there will be no public inquiry.

Let us look at the history of this legislation. First, the trade practices legislation came before the Senate, and it was debated in its entirety. The Democrats worked out a strategy that would engage the Opposition's support to block that legislation. What was the Government's reaction? It then split the legislation in two. One Bill was designed to help Holmes a Court, and the other Bill was the original trade practices legislation. What are we seeing today? Part of that Bill designed to help Holmes a Court-the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill 1986, as it is now called-is to be debated first in this chamber. The important Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 is to be debated second. Both of these pieces of legislation are taking precedence over a great backlog of legislation before the Senate. Why the indecent haste? Why are we debating the Bill on transfer of market dominance ahead of the Trade Practices Revision Bill at this point in time? The whole approach of the Government is incomprehensible.

In Committee, the Democrats will be moving three amendments. Firstly, we shall move that a public detriment clause should be considered. Secondly, we shall move that this Bill should go to a committee. Thirdly, if that fails, we shall move an amendment designed to maintain the status quo of the existing law for a period of 12 months-a grandfather clause with teeth, in other words. When we debated this section of the legislation previously, I moved an amendment which would have given the Trade Practices Commission power to investigate this takeover bid on the basis of the public benefit. That was rejected by the Government and the Opposition. I concede that it is difficult for the Commission to assess what is to the public benefit. It is a fairly nebulous concept, as has been remarked on two or three occasions. In fact, what generally happens when the Commission is assessing whether something is to the public benefit is that it looks first at whether there is anything to the detriment of the public. It looks at that factor first and then, assuming that there is nothing detrimental to the public, it generally concludes that the matter is therefore, at least prima facie, possibly to the public benefit. The Democrats have conceded that the public benefit clause was difficult for the Commission to evaluate and assess, so we have drafted an amendment which will be moved in Committee. It would allow the existing amendment of this legislation, the proposed sub-section (2C) to section 50, to apply, provided the Commission is satisfied that the takeover of a monopoly is not to the public's detriment.

I should have thought that the Opposition, in view of the remarks it has made, would be prepared to support such an amendment. We shall have to wait until the Committee stage to see whether that is so. If the Opposition is not prepared to support our amendment to give the Commission power to assess a takeover on the basis of its possible detriment to the public, we shall move that the whole Bill go to a Senate committee. There would seem to be very little doubt that the Opposition would support that course, because when the previous legislation was before the Senate the Opposition moved that the whole legislation should go to a committee. So there would seem to be no logical reason why the Opposition should not be prepared to support this legislation going to an existing standing committee of the Senate. The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would seem to be the appropriate committee to consider the matter.

If that course is not supported, the third thing that we would do would be to move an amendment to delay the operation of the proposed sub-section (2C) of section 50 in the case of a takeover bid being made under the existing laws. We would move that in the case of such a bid, sub-section (2C) should not apply to that bid for a period of 12 months. In this case, Holmes a Court is the example; and of course, Holmes a Court's bid is the first time that section 50 has applied at all in the history of the Trade Practices Commission. It is the first time that the Commission has seen fit to initiate legislation on a takeover of a monopoly. So our third amendment will simply say: If there has been a bid in the previous 12 months, before this piece of legislation is gazetted, the amendment to section 50 should not apply for a period of 12 months after this piece of legislation is proclaimed.

That approach seems quite reasonable to us. We do not see why the Liberal Party could not support such an approach simply because it has already indicated that it does not want to change the rules. It has removed its existing grandfather clause. However, as we pointed out previously, that clause does not have any teeth because all the raider has to do is withdraw his existing bid and issue a new bid. Holmes a Court has already had three or four goes at this. It should be no problem for him to withdraw his bid and have a fifth go. He would then get around the grandfather clause or amendment the Opposition has submitted. We have heard a lot about the fact that there should be no interference in the market-place. I hope that I have made it clear that what we are doing by passing this legislation is the exact reverse. We are interfering in the market-place.

There are some very real problems with the Holmes a Court bid. I want to take a moment of the Senate's time to outline some of those problems as we see them and why we think there should be some sort of an inquiry into what is going on. Many times in this place I have spoken about the tax losses to the Government associated with the negative gearing of takeovers, so I will not go into that matter again other than to say that last year Bell Resources paid an average of only 22c in the dollar company tax on its profits. It was able to get its company tax commitment so low only because of various tax avoidance measures. On the face of it there should have been a $66.6m tax bill for Holmes a Court. It was reduced to $36m. Next year, if the company gets hold of BHP, it could pay no tax at all, as it will have, on all the figures that are available to the public, a net cash deficiency of $82m.

The financing arrangements of this takeover bid are strange, to say the least. By and large they remain a mystery. Let me quote from the judgment of Mr Justice Marks in the case of BHP v. the National Companies and Securities Commission, the case between BHP and Bell over the legality of the last Holmes a Court takeover bid. Mr Justice Marks stated:

Although the hearing before me has been cut short, it was quite well advanced. It was cut short by a Bell capitulation following hard on the heels of a refusal by the Court to set aside a subpoena calling on documents disclosing details of the $2 billion loan facility itself preceded by a strong prima facie evidence pointing to their importance and other possible breaches of the requirements of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) (Vic) Code . . . The court is driven to the inescapable conclusion that the Bell interests have always been and are still bent on keeping the loan facility arrangements secret. That secrecy in the circumstances of the take-over scheme is impossible, in my view, to excuse. It is significant that Bell has never sought to explain or justify it. This conduct has been compounded recently by the highly misleading, if not deceptive, public statements of the chairman, one Holmes a Court, to the effect that the present offers have been withdrawn merely because of the length of the court hearing with overtones that this was connected with the length of the BHP case . . . In ordinary circumstances, it would be impossible to understand why a commercial arrangement for a credit facility should be other than disclosed, even though not thought to be directly relevant. The resistance in these proceedings to the disclosure is significant enough, but the secrecy is particularly ominous against the backdrop of statements of Holmes a Court to which I have referred.

The Government has said that there is no need for an inquiry, yet Mr Justice Marks, who had the benefit of hearing all the evidence in court, has said that there are ominous signs. He has criticised Mr Holmes a Court for not making available the details of the financing arrangements he has brought to bear for the takeover bid. I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans): Did the Ministers who interviewed Mr Holmes a Court ask for the details of the financing arrangements of the bid and, if so, is the Government prepared to make those details available to the public? I believe that no less could be expected in view of the great deal of public interest this whole takeover has brought about-indeed, rightful public interest. We saw on television last night-to my absolute amazement, and I have only the Carleton-Walsh Report to corroborate what I am saying-that the bank that is financing this $2 billion loan is itself subject to a takeover bid in the United Kingdom, and further, that the capital of the Standard Chartered Bank in the United Kingdom will be almost completely used up as a result of supplying this $2 billion of funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be naive! What makes you think it would come entirely from Standard Chartered?
—I am just quoting what was said last night. I am not naive at all.
—Haven't you ever heard of a syndication arrangement?

—The fact is that the Australian public has a right to know the details. If there is a syndicated arrangement through the Standard Chartered Bank the public has a right to know what other parties are involved in supplying this $2 billion. The fact is that $2 billion is more money than the Government could find to honour one of its promises to the Australian motorist, namely, that it would reduce the price of petrol in line with the international oil price. The Government said: `If we find $2 billion to honour that promise we will run the country bankrupt'. Yet we are sitting back and seeing $2 billion of foreign money flow into the country, and we are not even being told where the money is coming from.
—Where do you derive the assumption that this would be necessarily foreign money? You are just laying assumption on assumption on assumption.

—It is foreign money. It is money coming from an overseas bank. If that is not foreign money, I do not know what is. We, the Australian people, and certainly the Australian Parliament, have the right to know the ultimate source of those funds, whether any strings are attached to them and what are the repayment requirements. There is no doubt that the interest on those foreign funds will have to be met from Australian currency. The Australian people will be required to earn the foreign currency to meet the interest payment on the $2 billion overseas loan. I am very concerned about this takeover bid because, as far as I can see, it is the last move down a long sad course the Australian economy has taken. Both sides of the Parliament are sitting back saying that we must pursue free market policies and that we should not interfere with the workings of the economy in any way at all. Both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party are saying that.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that this policy of sitting back and allowing our assets to be bought up by who knows whom with no questions asked is running this country into bankruptcy. We are already deeply in hock. We are sacrificing Australia on the altar of laissez-faire economic theory. I was fascinated to hear yesterday that no less a person than Sir Robert Menzies, on the foundation of the Liberal Party, had said:
. . . individual enterprise must drive us forward. That does not mean that we are to return to old and selfish notions of laissez-faire.
This is precisely what is happening right now. There has been a 180 degree turn by the Liberal Party saying: `We will let the economy rip'.

Foreign debt has skyrocketed from $7 billion in 1980 to $52 billion in 1985. In five years there has been a staggering 700 per cent increase. About 30 per cent of our exports now go to pay our foreign debt. Only 7 per cent five years ago was needed to pay the interest bill on our foreign money. We cannot continue to let this happen. We are letting it happen with our largest enterprise, a company that is vital to Australian manufacturing. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd supplies the raw material for Australia's secondary industry. We will let one man gain control of that company and we still do not know how he will finance that. Will he increase the price of steel when he gets control? Will he use the resources of BHP to take over Bell Resources Ltd? Will he sell Utah Development Co. coal mining interests? We do know that he has a very serious cash shortfall on any projections. He has to do something to meet the interest bill on the $2 billion. He cannot meet it out of his existing cash flow from Bell Resources and it is doubtful whether he can meet it out of the cash flow of Bell Resources and BHP combined.

Mr Holmes a Court has to do something to reduce his interest bill, and he has to do it quickly. We want to know what he will do. We cannot find out because the Government says: `There is no need to have an inquiry. There is no need to worry about this. We seven Ministers have heard from Mr Holmes a Court and we know exactly what is going on. It is all okay'. I do not believe that this Parliament should be asked to accept those sorts of assurances on trust, particularly when they come from an individual and not from a board of directors and particularly when Mr Justice Marks has already raised questions which are very telling about details of the bid. I say only that if Holmes a Court gets control of BHP it will probably mean that the economic direction of this country has gone beyond the point of no return. If BHP is taken over, the existing Australian shareholders are bought out with a foreign loan and the control of that company which is vitally important to Australian secondary industry goes to one man about whose long term policy we have no idea, we are probably getting to a point where we cannot revive Australian secondary industry.

Australia has been very lucky that BHP, by and large-I do not want to defend that company-has tried to keep account of what is in the best interests of Australia. We have no assurances that that policy will continue. We know that the profits from Mr Holmes a Court's companies are very largely the result of share trading or from royalties from coal mining and other interests. In the record of Mr Holmes a Court and his Bell Resources companies there is no evidence to suggest that he has any experience whatsoever in managing and directing a large enterprise such as BHP. Mr Holmes a Court has indicated that he does not particularly want to be chairman of that company but the net effect of that takeover bid, if it is successful, will be that there will be a new board of directors, a new management of BHP. That is now unavoidable in the circumstances. Whether Mr Holmes a Court is chairman or whether somebody is chairman who is beholden to him remains to be seen, but there will be a fundamental change of direction in the way BHP is managed.

In Newcastle and Whyalla one finds that the employees of BHP are very concerned. We know that BHP has given a very large undertaking to the Government to refinance and modernise the whole steel industry by spending very large amounts of money. Can we be sure that if there is a change of management of BHP that modernisation program will proceed? We have the assurance of Mr Holmes a Court that this will proceed but he cannot speak on behalf of a board of directors, particularly one that has not yet been appointed. Until assurances by Mr Holmes a Court about the future of the steel industry in this country can be authoritatively questioned and examined we have no right to allow this takeover to proceed with the haste in which it is proceeding. At the Committee stage I will call for support for the three amendments that I have foreshadowed. I believe that those honourable senators who have the interests of this country at heart will support one of those three amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This matter was debated exhaustively and exhaustingly on 14 March. I do not propose to canvass all the arguments again, notwithstanding the passion which has been expended by Senator Siddons once again on this subject and, for that matter, notwithstanding his foreshadowing a further litter of amendments to the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill that, despite the normal conventions that apply in this place, he has not yet been able to circulate to those of us who will consider them in a matter of minutes. I referred to Senator Siddons's passion on the subject. I think that we are entitled to something of a horse laugh in response to his assertion earlier in his speech that he has not taken sides on this matter. All I can say is that if he has not taken sides on the merits of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Holmes a Court affair, he could have fooled me.

SPEECH.PARA: The points I make very quickly about the section 50 amendments are as follows. The change being proposed to the inquiry procedure in section 50 so far as it relates to bare transfers of monopoly power predates any suggestion of the present Holmes a Court acquisition exercise being set in train. That proposed change to the legislation was supported at the time by BHP in written representations to the Government, making and acknowledging the point that the present law was `anomalous'. That was the word used by BHP in its application to bare transfers of monopoly power. Prior to this BHP-Holmes a Court matter looming large in the popular consciousness, this change to the law had acquired complete unanimous across the board support for the merits of the matter involved. There is very good reason why the change acquired support. In the first place there was general doubt that the provision in section 50 was ever actually intended to apply to bare transfers of monopoly power. There remains only one judgment on the court records which produces the conclusion that that section is applicable to such non-competition reducing acquisitions.

The second reason why section 50 has been thought inappropriate to apply to bare transfers of monopoly power and why the amendment in this Bill has been thought to be necessary is that it involves the Trade Practices Commission getting itself involved in an inquiry about public interest issues which do not relate in any way, by definition, to questions of competition. A bare transfer of monopoly power, by definition, is a transfer, an acquisition situation, which does not result in any lessening of competition. The Trade Practices Commission exists for the purpose of supervising competition policy. It is a competition agency and yet in this situation it would be a monitoring and exercising authority with respect to something which, by definition, is competition neutral. That is another reason why section 50 has universally until now been thought inappropriate to the kind of acquisition we are now also concerned about.

The third reason why section 50 was thought inappropriate in its present form to apply to a bare transfer of monopoly power was that the particular test set out in section 50-that is, the test of establishing net public benefit flowing from the acquisition-is one which I think everyone agrees cannot sensibly be applied to a bare transfer of monopoly power situation. The most one could ever hope to establish in that situation is an absence of detriment. To leave the test in its present form in section 50 would be, for all practical purposes, to insulate monopolies from any kind of takeover challenge. That is the set of reasons why section 50 has been thought inappropriate. That is the set of reasons why this amendment was originally promulgated and that is why it deserves the continuing support of this Parliament.

It is not a matter of changing the rules in midstream, as has been asserted rather faintly these days by the Opposition and much more strenuously by Senator Siddons in his contribution this morning. What the exercise is all about, for those who would want to incorporate some grandfather clause of the kind we will be debating later, is mounting some kind of rear-guard action to apply, or go on applying, a set of rules to a particular transaction-namely, the Holmes a Court attempted acquisition of BHP-which rules everyone, including BHP, is on record as acknowledging are inappropriate. That is what it is about. It is not a matter of changing the rules in the Government's proposed amendment; it is a matter of resisting a quite cynical rear-guard action designed to apply inappropriate rules to a particular situation. That is far more a matter of ad hoc, unjustified in-principle legislation than anything that would be involved in applying, as was foreshadowed late last year, this amendment in the ordinary way, taking effect in the ordinary way upon proclamation and biting on everybody equally, not selectively.

It is not a matter of the Government taking the view that no inquiry of any form was necessary so far as this BHP-Holmes a Court affair was concerned. We have taken the view that any inquiry of the kind that might be thought to be provided for in the existing Trade Practices Act was wildly inappropriate for all the reasons I have just outlined. But it was not a matter of washing our hands of the situation and saying: `There is simply no potential public interest considerations here which require or demand examination of any kind'. Of course, we embarked upon what can properly be described as an inquiry, certainly the kind of inquiry which has been quite familiar at an executive government level in Great Britain, albeit in the context of a much more elaborate mechanism but, nonetheless, involving discretionary decisions by government after in-house government consideration.

We embarked upon the inquiry to which Senator Siddons referred of having a number of senior economic Cabinet Ministers sitting down with the parties concerned and exploring, in a great deal of depth and detail, the particular issues which have attracted so much public attention. In the course of that inquiry-I think Senator Siddons might be interested in listening to this since I am now responding to some of the questions he asked me in his speech-it was not a matter of ignoring, overlooking or passing over the kinds of policy issues that have been the subject of so much public attention. It was a matter of the seven Cabinet Ministers involved scrutinising very closely the financial arrangements that were proposed and the tax implications and so on of those financial arrangements and satisfying themselves that there were no public interest considerations evident on the material before them which justified some further Government intervention.

Senator Siddons asked me what, if anything, was done about inquiring into the financial arrangements contemplated by Mr Holmes a Court and whether we would make public the answers, if any, that we were given by Mr Holmes a Court. I answer him by saying that it was very much a part of the Government's inquiry to get quickly on to those basic and quite fundamental questions as to the financing arrangements and, for that matter, their taxation implications. I do not propose to make public now the various pieces of information and assurances that were given to us by Mr Holmes a Court in response to those inquiries. There are many matters of high commercial confidentiality involved and it is a matter for Mr Holmes a Court, not the Government, to decide what he wants to place on the public record and when he chooses to do so.

However, I now draw Senator Siddons's attention, if he can demonstrate enough interest in this debate to listen to what I am saying, to some very important statements that have been made by Mr Holmes a Court in his Part A document that was lodged this week with the National Companies and Securities Commission. It has been a characteristic of Senator Siddons's contribution to this whole debate that he has lagged about two furlongs behind any given play. While he has absorbed, with all the gamesmanship of the Victorian Supreme Court case, what Mr Justice Marks was saying and the state of public knowledge about these financing arrangements as they existed last week, he seems to have totally ignored some very important matters that have been put on the public record in the current Part A document. I do not know whether Senator Siddons has looked at the current Part A document but many of the matters to which he referred in his speech are there specifically addressed. They are not addressed to the same degree of detail as they were addressed in the Cabinet inquiry but they certainly track over the same territory and have some of the same effect.

For example, let me refer to clause 10 (3) (c) of the Part A statement as it bears upon the terms of the credit facility from the Standard Chartered Bank and let me read that clause because it is highly relevant to the sorts of concerns that Senator Siddons expressed. It states:

SCB's commitment under the Credit Facility is at present to provide loans in US dollars. However, the intent of both SCB and BRL is that the lending be syndicated and that the total amount needed under the Credit Facility (or so much of that amount as is reasonably practicable) be drawn down in Australian dollars from Australian banks. BRL seeks no currency risk exposure and would intend to manage any such exposure which ultimately arises under the Credit Facility as part of the BRL's normal currency risk management operations which include hedging and swap arrangements.
So the matters are addressed quite specifically. Okay, we do not have the details of the syndication--

TALK.START.PARA: —You certainly haven't.

—But there are excellent commercial reasons for that, which a businessman of Senator Siddons's experience should appreciate. There are particular concerns addressed in the Part A statement in a way that Senator Siddons utterly failed to acknowledge in his speech. In terms of the $2 billion that ultimately needs to be financed by Bell in terms of its ultimate obligation to pay for that acquisition, there is a reference in sub-clause 10 (4) of the Part A statement to BRL entering into `a standby underwriting arrangement to facilitate a pro rata rights issue by BRL to its shareholders to raise up to $700m'. On any view that is a very significant matter that has now been laid squarely on the table; a standby underwriting arrangement for an equity issue of that order of magnitude clearly completely changes the kinds of assumptions that were in so many of the public prints about all this as to the gearing ratios under which BRL would operate post-acquisition. Okay, we do not have the details of those standby underwriting arrangements; but there is a statement, which has to stand up if anyone's credibility is to remain intact after this, to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The point was further made by Senator Siddons that Bell, if it were successful with this and were then faced with the problem of generating the cash flow to service its debt and so on, might well embark upon an assets stripping operation of the kind that the Australian commercial world has never seen and that this will just be an exercise in chopping up BHP or divesting it of its assets in some way that would have profound and profoundly unhappy economic consequences for the nation of the kind that concerns Senator Siddons.
Let us look again at what is said in the Part A statement. Sub-clause 10 (4) states:
BRH and BRL have no plans that involve BHP either directly or indirectly in refinancing the credit facility and in particular have no plans that involve:
(1) the sale of any assets by BRL or its subsidiaries to BHP or BHP subsidiaries;
(2) the issue of any preference shares in BRL or its subsidiaries to BHP or BHP subsidiaries; or
(3) the acquisition of BRL or any its subsidiaries by BHP or BHP or BHP's subsidiaries.

These are very important matters that are referred to in this Part A statement. They are very much the kinds of matters that were fully explored in the inquiry on which the Government embarked. Of course, neither I nor the Government want to be taken as in any way taking sides in this matter, but what I am very concerned to ensure is that this debate be conducted in a way that has regard to the public policy issues involved, and that red herrings are not drawn across the trail and false trails are not laid in the course of this debate in the way they have been in such spectacular proliferation in the contribution by Senator Siddons.

The final point that Senator Siddons made in the course of his speech was that there is a dreadful cynicism involved on the part of the Government in splitting the original Trade Practices Bill into two parts and bringing it forward in the way that we have now done. I simply remind him that a splitting operation was in fact canvassed earlier by the Australian Democrats as the appropriate way of dealing with this matter. It will be recalled that we were told, with a great deal of harrumphing and drum beating, that the legislation, if we pursued this amendment, would be defeated on the third reading and that what the Democrats would do under those circumstances would be to bring back a trade practices amendment Bill of their own dealing with everything except the section 50 amendment. The Democrats would split out of such a Bill the section 50 stuff that is the subject of this Bill, which would enable the Senate to have a vote on the other matters, of course leaving it then up to the Government to bring forward a separate piece of legislation, as we now in fact have done, dealing with the section 50 matter. So let us have no more of this particular humbug about cynicism. It has been clear all along that there is clear majority support in this Parliament both for the section 50 amendments that we are now debating and for the other aspects of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill which I hope we will debate shortly. Because of the different characters of those two majorities, there was not support for a piece of legislation that combined those two streams of amendments. It is simply a matter of common sense, not a matter of cynical opportunism, an absence of moral fibre or any of the other sordid motivations that have been ascribed to us. It is simply a matter of common sense, a common sense that the Democrats themselves displayed at an earlier stage in this debate in choosing to handle the procedures in this way. The merits are unequivocally clear in this Bill. We have debated it at what is now approaching nauseous length in the past, and I hope that we can proceed to deal with it quickly, particularly if we now have from Senator Siddons the courtesy of seeing his amendments in the Committee stage.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 3, proposed new sub-section 50 (2C), at end of proposed sub-section, add:

``, unless, in the case of an acquisition of shares, a Part A statement within the meaning of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 or of a corresponding law of a State or Territory in respect of that acquisition of shares was lodged with the National Companies and Securities Commission in accordance with that Act or such a law before the day on which the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Act 1986 received the Royal Assent''.

This amendment adds a proposed new sub- section to the Bill to provide that the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill, which we have just supported, will not apply to any proposed acquisition where a Part A statement has been registered with the National Companies and Securities Commission at any time prior to this Bill receiving royal assent. I do not need to go over the argument again as we have already had argument in this place a few weeks ago. Clause 3 in the Bill is what is commonly called a grandfather clause. In other words, it preserves the legal situation as it stands for all those matters which have taken place prior to the Bill taking effect; for example, where an acquisition has already been commenced legally. It does not apply obviously to rumours or even to public statements that someone is going to make an offer. It applies only where a fully fledged legal takeover offer has been lodged and registered with the National Companies and Securities Commission. The law that we have just changed should not apply to any Part A statements which are in existence when it takes effect.

Clause 3 has been styled in popular language as not changing the rules of the game while the game is in progress. As I have said, clause 3 is commonly called a grandfather clause. It is not unusual in legislation by any means to preserve a situation which has already occurred. In other words, this clause does not have a retrospective effect. It ensures that this legislation applies only to takeover offers or, indeed, to acquisitions-they do not necessarily have to be takeover offers-which occur after the Bill becomes law.

I point out that this clause is not specific to the proposed takeover of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. In fact, when we last debated this legislation the Part A statement which had been lodged had been withdrawn but another statement has already been lodged and, therefore, it will apply to the proposed takeover. As the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in another place when this Bill was being debated in that place, to his knowledge there is a proposed takeover of another company. I find the Australian Democrats total obsession with the takeover of BHP very strange when another major takeover is in existence.

As I have said, this problem is not one of specific application to BHP; it is of general application to any takeovers which may exist. It is the sort of proposal that probably should be made in most legislation to ensure that this does not apply to events which have already occurred and are taking place. When people embark on a takeover they know what the state of the law is and they should be prepared to observe the law as it stands at that time. If events change, of course, and they have to make another acquisition at a later time, the state of the law at the time would apply. We are not trying to stop any takeovers occurring. We are certainly not putting any excessive time limits on it. We are simply saying that, until this law takes effect and we make a major change, all those legal situations which are occurring up to that point in time should be decided in accordance with the state of the law as it exists, or is thought to exist, until the amendment which we have just moved takes effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment we are debating is identical to the amendment that was put before the Senate when the Trade Practices Commission was debated in its entirety. At that time we opposed this amendment and we will have to oppose it again for the same reasons. For the record I will just recount what our reasons were. This amendment states that proposed new sub-section 50 (2C) will not affect any takeover that is in progress before the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill receives royal assent. If it achieved anything worth while we would wholeheartedly support it but the fact of the matter is that this amendment is only misleading the public and the Parliament. It is very easily got around. All any bidder has to do is withdraw his current bid, made before this Bill receives royal assent, and introduce a new bid after the Bill receives royal assent. Then he has completely got around the problems that Senator Durack has just outlined. We can see no reason why we should support an amendment that achieves nothing at all and misleads the public.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Durack and the Opposition are genuine in their stated aim of not wishing the rules to be changed in the middle of a takeover, they will support an amendment which we will be moving later which allows a 12-month period before a new bid can be made. That would achieve something, but this amendment achieves nothing. If the Bill is passed today, Holmes a Court can make a new bid tomorrow and so completely circumvent the reason for moving this amendment. We do not want to support something that will be misleading and achieves nothing. If the Opposition is genuine in its desire to make sure that a bid that is now before the Trade Practices Commission proceeds upon the basis of the existing law, it will support an amendment which allows that existing law to apply for a period of 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Durack on his heroic attempt this morning to defend the indefensible. Mercifully that defence was kept brief, as befitted its quality. The reality of the matter is that he knows and we all know that the grandfather clause proposal moved again by the Liberals simply does not stand up to any kind of scrutiny in principle at all. It does have a superficial attraction-the argument that the rules of the game should not be changed during the course, in particular, of some highly significant and highly contentious community controversy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally true that parties have to take their rights and obligations as they find them on the law as it stands and if the law later changes, so much the better for future generations, but that does not affect the rights and obligations as they stand before the law is so changed. While it is the case against that background that one might be inclined initially to say that in the context of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Bell Resources Ltd affair that BHP is entitled to rely on the state of the law as it now exists, ignoring for the moment that BHP has argued that the law was an ass in this respect when the matter was not perceived as affecting its interests--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is flexible, too.

—It is flexible; that is the case. While it is the case that one might think initially that BHP is entitled to rely on the state of the law as it presently exists, I believe it is also the case that Mr Holmes a Court in this current controversy is entitled to rely on certain considerations, and I think that these considerations are the ones that should move us to reject this amendment. The first matter of relevance is the clearly articulated intention of government, without controversy and without opposition being expressed at the time, to change the law-an intention articulated publicly in the latter part of last year. It is secondly the case that there have been overwhelming majority decisions in both Houses of Parliament in favour of a change to the law. There was originally a unanimous decision in the House of Representatives, followed by a majority vote of 51 to 6 when the matter was last debated in this place and then there was an all but unanimous decision, with a single dissentient, in the House of Representatives. So a clear will has already been expressed in favour of the amendment of the law in terms of its universal application without a grandfather clause of this kind being attached to it. One might normally think that that is a relevant consideration when one is ordering one's affairs and determining what it is appropriate to rely on.

SPEECH.PARA: The third consideration, much more legally pertinent than either of the first two, is that what is proposed by this particular grandfather clause does violence to the ordinary common and garden rule of the legislative process that the law changes when the proclamation of the amending Act occurs. There is no usual lingering effect of some pre-existing application of the law; the law itself changes from the date of proclamation. It is important to remember-this is really what is in issue and what has been completely overlooked in so many of the glib references to changing the rules-that there was no obligation already accrued as a matter of law to go through the inquiry process. No obligation has yet accrued. Similarly, there is no correlative right in the defender, someone resisting an acquisition, which in that sense has actually so far accrued. This is the case because the inquiry requirement in section 50 bites only on a completed acquisition. It is only when an acquisition has actually taken place without there having been an authorisation under the terms of section 50 that this particular prohibition in the Trade Practices Act actually has effect. There is no prohibition on a takeover offer being made without some inquiry having occurred, or there is no requirement that an inquiry be immediately set in train. There is no legal obligation on an acquirer, such as Holmes a Court, to go down that track; there is no legal right in a defender, such as BHP in the present matter, to insist on such an inquiry having occurred. The only time that obligations arguably accrue or rights arguably accrue on behalf of the defender is when there is a completed acquisition. On any view we do not at the moment, with the mere lodging of a Part a statement, have a completed acquisition.

What I am saying, very simply, is that in the present situation the acquirer, Holmes a Court, is entitled to rely on the law changing in the ordinary way on the date of proclamation making it the case in the future, if that change to section 50 occurs, that there will be no inquiry requirement as a condition of the successful acquisition where what is involved is a bare transfer of monopoly power. Holmes a Court and any other acquirer around the place at the moment who may have lodged a Part A statement are entitled, on the ordinary processes of the legislative system as we know it and usually apply it, to rely on that expectation that there will not be some separate and specific provision made in effect to continue in existence for one particular person of one very small group of people an obligation which for everyone else has been removed. The short point again, putting it another way, is that far from changing the rules midstream in a way that is for Holmes a Court's benefit--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not Holmes a Court; it is the Bell Group. It is a public company.

—Senator Crichton-Browne has a mind finely attuned to distinctions of this kind, as I am well aware from his own commercial background. It is entirely appropriate that that piece of pedantry be acknowledged and find its proper place in this debate. It is the case that what is involved here is not a change of rules in midstream designed to benefit or having the deliberate effect of benefiting the Bell Group or any other acquirer that happens to have a Part A lodged at the moment. What is involved in the grandfather clause amendment that is now before us is an attempt to change the rules in a different way-to prescribe a set of rules affecting those people with Part A currently outstanding in a way that affects nobody else and in a way that is utterly at odds with the way in which the legislative process normally operates. We had this argument at length on 14 March, and I do not think there is anything more I can usefully say or put on the record to oppose the amendment that has been moved. I suggest that the Committee respond accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, proposed new sub-section 50 (2c), at end of proposed sub-sections, add the following new words and paragraphs:
`provided that nothing in this sub-section shall apply to-
