(c) any acquisition of shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate within 12 months after the day on which the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Act 1986 received the Royal Assent-

(i) by any person pursuant to a take-over scheme or a take-over announcement within the meaning of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980 or a corresponding law of a State or Territory in respect of which any document or a copy of a document has been registered by, or lodged with, the National Companies and Securities Commission prior to that day, or

(ii) in the circumstances referred to in sub-paragraph (i) by any person who is an associate of, or associated with, any such person within the meaning of that Act or such corresponding law of a State or Territory; or

(d) any acquisition by a person of any shares in the capital, or any assets, of a body corporate where the Commission is satisfied that in all the circumstances the acquisition has resulted or may result in a detriment to the public and the Commission has within 21 days of the Commission becoming aware of the acquisition given to the person a notice stating that the Commission is so satisfied.'.
(2) After clause 3, add the following new clause:
`4. Section 90 of the Principal Act is amended by adding after sub-section (9) the following sub-section:

``(9a) Where an application for an authorization is made in respect of a proposed acquisition of shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate, and sub-section 50 (2c) is not applicable to that proposed acquisition by reason of paragraph (d) of that sub-section, the Commission shall make a determination granting an authorization under sub-section 88 (9) in respect of the proposed acquisition where it is satisfied that in all the circumstances the proposed acquisition would not result in or be likely to result in such a detriment to the public that the proposed acquisition should not be allowed to take place.''.'.

The effect of the first of these amendments, the one relating to public detriment, will be to give the Trade Practices Commission the power to waive section 50 (2C) if it believes that a takeover will result in a detriment to the public. In this case the takeover would be conducted under the existing section 50-in other words, an inquiry will be held if the Commissioner believes that there is a public detriment. By inserting a public detriment clause we are essentially making life easier for the Commissioner. We are imposing a positive obligation on the Commission to authorise the takeover if the public detriment does not exist. The Commissioner must authorise the takeover if there is no public detriment. We are also narrowing the range of matters which the Commission has to examine. Tax, debt and restructuring matters will now have a greater role. This is all to the good because these are matters which can be assessed and evaluated.

The Commission works on the notion of public detriment in a de facto way at present because it is so difficult to weigh up the public benefit. This amendment would merely formalise a situation which in a de facto way exists right now. The Government should not have any problem with these amendments, unless it believes that the present takeover is in the public detriment and it would like this Bill to be pushed through anyway. If the Government is assured that there is no public detriment, it will not affect the situation one little bit. This amendment puts the acid test on the Government. The Government has given an assurance that there is no public detriment in this takeover proceeding. If that is true, presumably the Trade Practices Commission will find that to be true and section 50 (2C) will then apply and there will be no inquiry. In all the circumstances I see no reason why the Government should have any objection whatever. If the assurances we have been given are real and there is no public detriment whatsoever, everybody will be happy.

The second amendment relates to changing the rules during the game. Senator Evans said that a fundamental principle of law is involved and that once a piece of legislation is proclaimed there should be no delaying factors and no exceptions. I am sure that situation is not inviolate. There is a real problem here in that under the existing law there have been three takeover bids for Australia's largest enterprise. If the Government is to avoid the criticism that has been levelled in this debate, and certainly will be levelled by the public for many years to come, that it has changed the rules to make life easier for Mr Holmes a Court and his company to take over Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd., it is not unreasonable that in this case there should be a delaying process so that the amendment the Government is so keen to see passed to section 50 does not interfere in a very important commercial matter in the community at this time.

A 12-month period for the existing law to apply would probably apply only in the Holmes a Court takeover bid. It is significant that section 50 has never been applied by the Trade Practices Commissioner before. This is the first time that a change of ownership of a monopoly has been of sufficient concern to the Trade Practices Commission to initiate legal action. That it has done, and we do not know what its concern is. It is not in a position to make that public, but certainly there is something of concern and this particular section has been brought in for the very first time in the history of the Trade Practices Commission. That alone, as I said in the second reading debate, should be sufficient reason for the Government to agree to an amendment that allows a 12-month stay of proceedings in this particular case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Siddons in these amendments because I believe that the question of a public detriment clause is of considerable practical importance and in the interests of the community should be taken seriously by the Government. I agree with Senator Siddons that an indication by the Government that it will not support this amendment would tend to indicate that we have all got something to worry about because if we did not have anything to worry about, the Government would gladly support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Committee stage on a previous occasion I made a number of points to the Minister for Resources and Energy concerning areas in my own constituency, namely the steel towns of New South Wales. I pointed out that as matters now stand there are so many open questions that there are good reasons for concern in those cities. There is need for there at least to be scope for an inquiry to decide whether there is any likelihood in the future of public detriment in Wollongong or Newcastle. That bears directly on the question of the viability of the steel industry in those cities, which are in a delicate stage in their career. I will go into that matter further in a few moments.

I asked the Minister then why he would not allow some sort of mechanism for an inquiry. I go no sensible answer from him. Senator Siddons has now brought up an amendment which would provide for that opportunity. I asked the Minister what thought the Government had given to the viability of the steel industry in Wollongong and Newcastle in the light of their circumstances now; whether the Government had investigated the areas of finance available to the Bell group and Mr Robert Holmes a Court, with the idea in mind that at some time there may be some kind of foreclosure or some circumstance arise which would affect that delicate balance of the steel industry; and whether the Government intended in that case to offer any guarantees to the steel towns that in the event of there being some problem after a takeover by Mr Holmes a Court it would support the steel industry. I have had no replies to any of that. I hope I will get a reply at some stage in this Committee debate.

I would like to take the matter a little further because after having discussed it and got that completely negative response from the Minister in the last debate, I went to the trouble last week of going to Wollongong and spending a day with Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd. In particular, I had a lengthy discussion with the General Manager of Australian Iron and Steel, Mr J. K. Ellis. Australian Iron and Steel, of course, is the steel division of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in Wollongong. I have some figures which I would like to draw to the Minister's attention because they have a very considerable implication for the future. According to Mr Ellis, during the remaining years of the steel plan-that is, to 1988-the Wollongong steel division alone will need extra capital of $220m in 1986, $340m in 1987 and $250m in 1988. That is $810m-nearly a billion dollars-which will have to be injected into that steel division over the next three years. Mr Ellis also authorised me to make public the fact that from 1989 onwards, after the expiry of the steel plan, between $100m and $150m a year will have to be injected into the steel industry in Wollongong alone to keep it competitive-no expansion-in the world scene.

We are talking here about an industry which requires enormous infusions of capital to keep it economic and to keep it going over the next few years. Over the next decade it is most unlikely to be the place to make a quick buck. It is a particularly vulnerable industry. It is a vulner- able industry which directly employs in Wollongong alone 17,000 people and which provides indirect employment for many others. Of the 17,000 people employed by BHP in Wollongong, 13,000 are employed in the steel division. There is considerable anxiety about this matter in Wollongong. I can assure the Minister that there is no doubt about that at all. He is a senator for Victoria. I do not suppose he cares much about the steel towns of New South Wales. I think it is up to me to raise that point.

A point that bears on this is that the Government has an agreement with BHP that steel prices will not rise by more than the consumer price index. Steel prices are already up to some two thirds of the CPI. There is not a great deal of room left in price expansion for that enormous capital infusion-as I said, nearly $1 billion over the next few years-to take place. In addition, Australian Iron and Steel in Wollongong has a considerable pollution problem and a very expensive one. In the city now it has been admitted and conceded by the company that it is producing carcinogens in very large quantities which affect the health of its workers. It has agreed with the State Pollution Control Commission that it will spend another $35m in the next few years on correcting this problem. The major source of the problem is the kish-the graphite-which is released into the air.

I raise those figures for the Minister's serious consideration. Mr Ellis has authorised me to make them public here. I do not think those figures, certainly for after 1989, have been made public before. They have a direct bearing on the public detriment area in this matter and I ask the Minister again in this debate: Can he give me detailed and specific undertakings and assurances in the light of these figures and in the light of the delicate state of this industry that its survival has been considered carefully by the Government? In no circumstances has the Government assured itself-there has been no inquiry and it has not even gone into the matter-that at some future time the financial backers of the Bell Group Ltd may need the money. They may want to foreclose or they may want the money because of some change in the nature of the finance. Is there a stage at which that finance has to be renewed? What sort of term is that finance on? What happens at that point? Is there a situation there where those 17,000 jobs in Wollongong and nearly as many in Newcastle could be placed in jeopardy? Mr Holmes a Court could come to the Government and say: `I am sorry, this is one of the commercial realities of life. I cannot go on. It is not possible. This is not an economic industry'. He would quote back to the Minister the figures which I am quoting to him today as a justification. That is not what we want to see happen. That is why we are taking such a strong line on this matter. It is because we believe that there is the act of risk to the public detriment here. That is not a criticism of the Bell Group or of Mr Robert Holmes a Court.

For all I know, his takeover could be the best thing for BHP since sliced bread. I do not know. The point is that I do not know and I do not think anybody else knows. It certainly ought to be in the interests of BHP, in the interests of the Bell Group and in the interests of the Australian people and especially the cities of Wollongong and Newcastle that some regard is taken of those points and that an inquiry is held. That can be done if Senator Siddons's amendment is passed. If Senator Siddons's amendment does not pass, I make it absolutely clear that the Government will stand hoist with its own petard. The Government will be as good as coming out and saying: `We have something to hide here, there is something wrong and we do not want it to get out'. I do not believe that is the case. I am not so cynical. I do not think that is so. All I think that has happened is that the Government has not taken this matter seriously enough. It has not understood what the implications are. It has not understood the extent of its own responsibility in a matter as large and as consequential as this.

That is probably the nub of the matter. All I can say to the Minister and to the Government, even if it means adjourning consideration of this Bill, is that surely the Government or the Cabinet should be prepared to give further consideration to this amendment, which has no harm to it whatsoever. Indeed, it provides a useful power. I think everybody would concede that. It is a very good backstop and is something that would give the Trade Practices Commission a valuable role in the community. As Senator Siddons has said-I say it again-if there is some sort of inquiry made into this particular takeover bid and that Commission finds there is no public detriment or risk of a public detriment, it can tell us all that and we can be reassured. The takeover can go ahead and there will be no problem. If that is not done we can all assume the worst. We can assume that the Government either wants to conceal something or that it is too lazy and too unconcerned for the welfare of 30,000 jobs with downstream effects in Wollongong to make the small mental effort of trying to understand the situation in those cities and to allow this amendment to pass-an amendment which would be of value and would do no harm. I reiterate that it could only be of value.

I implore the Opposition to support the amendment on that basis. Senators from New South Wales, I know, share my concern for what happens in Newcastle and Wollongong. We must all do that. We are all of us very unhappy and I think senators of all parties here have said that. What has happened to the steel towns already? They are having a rough time there. I have known of whole classes of apprentices who have completed their training with top marks and who have been dismissed the moment they have finished their apprenticeships. We do not want that sort of thing going on and we particularly do not want it getting worse.

Finally, I am prepared to quote a responsible view of the General Manager of Australian Iron and Steel, Mr J. K. Ellis, of Wollongong, who knows his own undertaking intimately. He has authorised me to quote him in this place and anywhere else I wanted to as saying that if the steel division of BHP suffers through any consequences of a takeover, and funding were to be cut back on those figures of his which I quoted earlier, that would provide the kiss of death for Wollongong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Mason asked me whether the Government is satisfied about the assurances that have been given in relation to the future of the steel industry by Mr Holmes a Court on behalf of the Bell Group. I simply make the point, as has been stated publicly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that the Government was given, in effect, identical assurances by both BHP and Mr Holmes a Court as to their commitment to the steel plan and some larger associated issues as to the future of the steel industry. There is no reason in the Government's mind, based on what we know of the financing arrangements and so on which were the subject of earlier debate today, to doubt that those assurances will be met or are capable of being met. I make the further point that the Steel Industry Authority is in many ways a more appropriate body to have views about the continued viability of the industry. The Steel Industry Authority has itself been asked to inquire into the sorts of matters that Senator Mason has raised and it has declined to do so because it too has not been sufficiently persuaded that there are the kind of public interest or community interest issues involved that Senator Mason is waxing so indignantly about.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to Senator Siddons's amendments, I make the point, first of all, in relation to the first part of his so-called improved grandfather clause that, even on the very brief reading that I have been able to make of this clause, having received it so recently, it is perfectly apparent that it will not succeed in doing what he wants it to do. The way in which sub-clause (c) is drafted produces the following effect. If someone makes a takeover offer before the day of assent of this legislation and that offer proceeds through to a successful acquisition within 12 months, this clause bites and the offer and the acquisition are subject to the inquiry procedure. If, however, an acquirer were to make an offer on the day after this particular Bill and amendment were assented to and then proceeded to acquire within, say, 12 months pursuant to that particular offer, then that acquisition process would not be caught by this particular clause here. So the sorts of points that Senator Siddons was making about the Liberals' grandfather clause are equally applicable to his in the sense that an acquirer with half a brain would, if confronted with this clause, simply withdraw an offer already on the table, wait until the Bill is assented to, and put down exactly the same offer thereafter. In those circumstances, the so-called grandfather clause would have no effect. So, technically, as I read it-unless I have overlooked something, which is perfectly possible given the timeframe that we have had-I do not think that the clause could possibly have the effect that Senator Siddons claims for it, in the context of BHP or anything else.

As to the no public detriment provision that Senator Siddons has sought also to write in here, which raises an important larger issue of principle, there are a number of drafting defects or apparent defects which also are evident in this. I do not stop to go on about those at any length, except to say that there is an incongruity between the provision in sub-clause (d), requiring the Trade Practices Commission to find detriment, and then create a situation in which it is subsequently determining whether there is detriment. It would seem to put an acquirer at a considerable disadvantage. Again, the time-frame of 21 days is arguably very narrow when the procedures are not spelt out for that preliminary threshold decision as to detriment to occur.

Again, there is a further quite substantial drafting problem in sub-clause (d), in the sense that it seems clear from the way that it is drafted that it is only after an acquisition has actually occurred that this particular mechanism is triggered. It is not when there is a takeover offer on the table, but only after a successful acquisition. That would seen to create all sorts of problems in practical enforcement, requiring subsequent divestiture and all the sorts of things that have given the courts and the Commission so much headache in the past.

That apart, it has to be acknowledged that, if one were to rewrite section 50 so as to have not a requirement of net public benefit but, rather, a negatively expressed requirement of no public detriment, that would certainly make section 50 a more manageable provision so far as inquiries were concerned. I have to acknowledge that, because I have been saying all the way through the debate that one of the fundamental flaws in section 50 has been that it is cast in terms of net public benefit rather than simply absence of detriment. So, certainly, if Senator Siddons could get his drafting successfully in place, this would represent some improvement on the hopelessly inappropriate character of the present clause. But that is not the end of the story. There are still all sorts of difficulties about applying the basic section 50 Trade Practices Commission inquiry regime to a bare transfer of monopoly power situation.

The three points which I will make again, as I have made them earlier today, are these: First, there is still a real doubt as to whether section 50 applies at all to a bare transfer situation. We have one court case saying so but a lot of legal argument to contrary effect, and there is certainly no guarantee, from Senator Siddons's point of view, that at the end of a long litigious process there would in fact be an inquiry required by the courts. Secondly, there is the really most fundamental objection to this, and that is about the role of the Trade Practices Commission as the appropriate agency for such an inquiry. We are still here talking about situations in which, by definition, there is no element of competition reduction involved. It is simply a bare transfer of monopoly power. We have a competition policy agency purporting to make decisions in the national interest on a matter which is competition neutral in character, and that simply is incongruous and is, we strongly believe, an inappropriate role for the Trade Practices Commission to be performing.

A further problem that I quickly mention is the difficulties of definition in the application of different tests to what might be a single situation. What I mean by this is best illustrated by an example. Take a situation in which one conglomerate seeks to take over another conglomerate where, by and large, there is no overlapping at all in terms of the market areas with which the respective conglomerates deal. But let us assume that in one small area of the total composite whole there is a reduction in competition, because there is one particular market where one part of one conglomerate deals with the same territory as a part of the other conglomerate which is being acquired. In those circumstances, we would have two potentially applicable tests-one being that of net public benefit, and the other one of no detriment-applying to a single takeover situation, with all sorts of enormous difficulties because it would still essentially be a bare transfer of monopoly power as to, let us assume, 98 per cent of the total transaction but as to one very small and, perhaps, technical part of it, we might have a competition reduction element, which would clearly by numerically or quantitatively insignificant but would raise all these difficult sorts of problems as a result of there being a two-tier test in the legislation. There are a number of points that can be made about this matter. For these reasons I have given I urge that the Committee reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support the Australian Democrats' amendments. In the intended view of the Democrats, the amendments go far further than our proposed amendment, which did not find favour with the Committee. They introduce all sorts of problems, most of which have been referred to by Senator Gareth Evans. I do not understand how the second limb, sub-clause (d), could work at all without knowing how the Trades Practices Commission is to be satisfied that there is a detriment, without any form of inquiry that it might otherwise undertake. It seems to be a pretty meaningless proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the other amendment, it is an entirely different concept from the grandfather clause. Although Senator Siddons has called it a grandfather clause, it is, in fact, intended to preserve the status quo-whether or not it has that effect is another matter-for a period of 12 months. Goodness knows what economic, legal or social significance such a proposal has. It might be designed to benefit BHP at present, although I do not think that 12 months grace would perhaps help it; I do not know. But apart from that purpose, I do not see what the possible justification is. Why 12 months? Why not three months? Why not two years, or never? It just does not seem to have any rationale. For those reasons, the Opposition will not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to Senator Gareth Evans's criticism that sub-clause (c) was meaningless. It clearly refers to any acquisition or shares in the capital or assets of a body corporate within 12 months after the day on which royal assent is received; and then paragraph (i) goes on to say that any takeover that was in existence prior to the date of the royal assent would qualify. So, the amendment covers it both ways. It covers the period 12 months after royal assent, and any takeover prior to that day. I fail to see that Senator Evans's very scathing and sarcastic criticisms are valid in any way.
—That might have been your intent but that is not the execution. It has to satisfy both conditions.

—It clearly refers to any takeover prior to royal assent, and to a period for 12 months after royal assent. I should have thought that that was perfectly clear and that it would have had the desired result of giving a breathing space to ensure that we are not changing the rules during an important takeover.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, left yesterday for official duties in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and France. He will return to Australia on 22 April. During his absence the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, will be Acting Treasurer.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that a Bureau of Industry Economics survey of 102 Australian companies has found that more than 50 per cent of manufacturers have not experienced any competitive advantage from the massive devaluation of the dollar? I ask: Do these findings bear out the Minister's expressed scepticism about the existence of a J curve effect in the Australian economy? Given the survey finding of a 26 per cent average price rise for imported material and components last year and the now apparent fact that devaluation will have nothing like the beneficial effect predicted by the Government, what action will the Government take to reduce the cost burden on Australian manufacturing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the Bureau of Industry Economics survey only from a newspaper report. I have not yet had a chance to consider it in detail. Rather than say that it bears out my expressed scepticism about the rate and extent of the J curve effect in Australia, I would prefer to say that it discounts some of the optimism that was expressed by other commentators, including economists and politicians, late last year. I think that can be said to be a result of the survey. However, I also noticed Press reports recently of a survey conducted by the Chamber of Manufactures in conjunction with some other group which suggested, on the basis of that survey, that one could be a little more optimistic about the competitiveness of Australian products within Australia and that a majority of companies were expecting a J curve effect to operate within the near future. That was the gist of that survey. The BIE survey has been conducted over a considerable period of time. I think it was first commissioned in about October last year. I do not feel competent to comment on it in any detail until I see the results.

ANSWER.PARA: The final question asked by Senator Chaney was: What action will the Government take to reduce the cost imposts on Australian manufacturing industry? Not having read the BIE survey and its conclusions, it might be easy for me to say that we have not formulated any response to that issue yet. However, let me say that I am not in a position on behalf of the Government to say that that is the fundamental issue which we would seek to address immediately. I am not in a position to say what steps might be taken by the Government if they were considered necessary.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXATION: FARM AND SMALL BUSINESS INCOME

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Finance confirm reports that the Auditor- General's annual report has disclosed that the Australian Taxation Office has concluded that only 63 to 75 per cent of farm income was disclosed and that as little as 60 per cent of the income of small businesses was disclosed? Will the Minister comment on this situation and will he outline what action the Government proposes to take on the matter?

—The facts are as Senator Elstob stated them regarding the figures in the Auditor-General's report. It is important to note that those figures were compiled by the Taxation Office prior to the introduction of the prescribed payments system in 1983. That system is designed to deal primarily with industries in which significant evasion is occurring. The Government's proposal to introduce the Australia Card will also have a very significant impact on the incidence of tax evasion. In addition, the Government has in recent years allocated staff increases to the enforcement branch of the Taxation Office, which is an essential step in the campaign against evasion and avoidance and is in line with the Government's longer term aim of boosting audit coverage to 2 per cent of non-salary and wage earners by 1992.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I preface my question by pointing out that building society lending has fallen by 55 per cent since June last year and that during January the building societies were responsible for only 19 per cent of total home lending, compared to 26 per cent in July 1985 and 30 per cent during the 1984-85 financial year. Does the Minister agree that last week's decision to protect existing savings bank borrowers will worsen the position of building society borrowers in that the societies inevitably will be forced to raise their interest rates to compete with the Government-subsidised banks? Does the Government have any intention to help the 32 per cent of Australians with outstanding building society mortgages?
—The Treasurer met with the building society representatives last night.
—He left for overseas.

—Following that meeting, as Senator Chaney says with a perceptive interjection, he left for overseas. But prior to leaving for overseas he issued a statement about this matter, particularly as to the view the Government would have expressed to the representatives of the building societies. I do not have a copy of the Treasurer's statement here. I note that it is set out in some detail in the Australian Financial Review. That is the position which the Government adopts. I am asked as a matter of opinion whether last week's decision will weaken the position of the building societies in a competitive environment in respect of interest rates. I guess that my off-hand, and not necessarily informed, answer to that question is probably yes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FAMILY COURT OF AUSTRALIA DECISIONS: ACCESS TO CHILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Attorney-General seen articles in the Advertiser of 31 March 1986 addressing Family Court of Australia decisions regarding access to parents who have sexually abused their children? Is the Minister aware of this problem and can he say how many such cases have come before the Family Court? Can he comment on the problem of women being charged with contempt when they refuse to comply with an access order so as to protect their children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and am assured that it has also been referred to the Attorney-General for his reaction. I understand that the Chief Judge of the Family Court, Justice Elizabeth Evatt, has asked the South Australian Minister for Health to provide information to the Court about the cases giving rise to the allegations referred to in the article. It is not possible on the state of current information to say how many cases have come before the Court to date where access has been given to parents who have sexually abused their children. In ordering access, the Family Court is required to have regard to the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration. No doubt that would be a crucial consideration were the facts in issue to come to light.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the contempt question, where a parent believes that children are at risk during access visits, the appropriate course of action, if any question of being subject to contempt law is in issue, is to take legal steps at the earliest opportunity to have the existing access order varied or suspended by the Family Court. I might mention finally that contempt of Family Court orders was the subject of a discussion paper issued by the Australian Law Reform Commission in December last year. The Commission commented that applications for parties to be dealt with for contempt of access orders were shunted by judges to avoid making a final determination and that when such applications were determined there was a tendency for the sentences imposed to be markedly lenient. Obviously, these are all considerations that will need to be borne in mind by the Government and those responsible for the administration of family law in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction a question concerning interest rates. If the Leader of the Government in the Senate wishes to take the question, in view of the incredibly honest answer that he just gave Senator Messner, I would be happy for him to accommodate me. Can and, if so, will the Government give an undertaking that home loan interest rates will not rise above 20 per cent-the level in New Zealand-during the Government's term of office? Can the Minister explain why it is fair for families with existing building society loans to be subjected to higher interest rates when those with bank loans have been exempt? Can the Minister explain why banks which had no money for housing on Wednesday, when the Government's decision was made, were advertising only 24 hours later that housing loans were available in abundance? Will the Minister give an absolute and categorical undertaking that the Government will never lift the ceiling rate on existing housing loans?

—I am able to give Senator Chipp a categorical assurance that, for existing bank loans, interest rates will not go beyond the present 13.5 per cent. For new loans, of course, the rate will be set by the market. The Government is confident that competition will help to keep those rates down. Senator Chipp asked why the Government's decision focused on banks rather than building societies. The answer is very straightforward and important. The banks had been losing deposits, building societies had not. In June 1986, building society deposits were holding while bank deposits fell by $680m. Figures out today show that bank deposits fell a further $200m. As to why the action that we have taken directly affects bank loans and not building societies, Senator Chipp will be aware that building societies are under State control-unlike banks. It is possible for State governments to decide to take action in relation to building societies similar to that we have taken for banks. Finally, banks will lend for housing from funds that they raise, if necessary at commercial rates, until such time as their deposits build up. This is also assisted by the subsidy paid to them by the Government, which will maintain their existing deposits.

—Has the attention of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women been drawn to the statement by the Queensland Minister for Welfare Services, Mrs Chapman, at a recent National Party Women's Congress in Southport that government responsibility for single mothers should stop after the first child? Could the Minister outline how the Government views this proposal and the assumptions about women on which the proposal is based?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rarely have I heard such an insensitive and inappropriate comment on a major social issue as that from Mrs Chapman of the Queensland Government about single mothers. It is greatly to be regretted that any representative of any government throughout Australia should make such a callous, punitive and totally impractical recommendation. As far as our Government is concerned, I remind Mrs Chapman and any honourable senators who may need reminding that the payment of benefit to single mothers is a responsibility which our Government undertakes. The impact of the sort of suggestion that Mrs Chapman made would be to condemn many single parent families to poverty. Of course, most single parent families live in very poor circumstances anyway. The number living in dire poverty would be dramatically increased by Mrs Chapman's suggestion.

ANSWER.PARA: There are 263,000 single parent families in Australia in receipt of a pension or benefit. These families contain 430,000 children-that is, more than one per parent. It is these children who would suffer under Mrs Chapman's proposal. The majority of sole parent families are headed by women whose marriages have broken down not, as implied by Mrs Chapman, by unmarried mothers. I point out too that sole parents include widows, divorcees and also a small number of men. Whatever moral judgments Mrs Chapman may bring to bear on the income support claims of unmarried mothers, she should realise that the children of these families would suffer most and children do not choose their parents. The majority of single parent families are headed by women, most of whom get little or no support from the father of their children. If Mrs Chapman wants to make some helpful contribution on the poverty of single parent families, she could campaign to help get fathers who are responsible for these children's welfare to contribute to it.

It is particularly inappropriate that Mrs Chapman, representing the Queensland Government, should make a derogatory comment of this kind since, as my colleague Senator Walsh has pointed out to the Senate before, Queensland has one of the highest rates of illegitimacy in the country. In 1984, 17.1 per cent of total births in Queensland were out of marriage, compared with the national average of 14.85 per cent. Teenage pregnancy in Queensland has twice the incidence of any other State. I suggest that the Queensland Government, and Mrs Chapman in particular, ought to devote their efforts to dealing with those social problems instead of simply coming up with a recipe that would mean more disaster for poor women and their children.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce by referring him to his comment last week in relation to the invitation by the United States for Australian involvement in the strategic defence initiative when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: While the Government was not supportive of Star Wars inevitably some research will be done in association with the program and we are not seeking to exclude people from that.
I ask the Minister whether he is aware of last night's statement in the other place by the Minister for Defence when he said:

The Australian Government does not endorse the SDI concept, and as a result we will not be entering into negotiations of any sort to establish an umbrella agreement of this kind for SDI research. This will preclude Australian participation in research funded under the SDI program.

In the light of that statement will the Minister confirm that no action will be taken to block Australian industry involvement in this research? Can he explain the extent to which he believes that this is likely to occur?

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a definitive view on that matter at this stage because the Government has not formulated finally its response to the Weinberger letter about participation in the SDI program. However, I want to correct the impression which Senator Short gave when he quoted something that I am purported to have said-in essence, that inevitably some research will be done in the SDI program. I did not say that. I said that inevitably some research will be done which may be seen as being relevant to the SDI program. I shall give some examples.
—You said `in association with the program'.

—In association with the program-that does not matter. I simply make the point that there is a somewhat neurotic clamour to say that because people disapprove of the SDI program, whether on grounds of international policy and the arms race and so on or on scientific grounds, any research which may be in any sense relevant to the Star Wars program should not be done. That is an absurd view. As a matter of fact, it was put to me this morning at a Press conference in Sydney that the over the horizon radar research being done in Australia-the Jindalee program-had been designated by the United States as Star Wars research. I do not give a damn-if I might use that expression in this chamber-what designation the United States Government wants to place on research items, but it would be very silly, that designation having been made, for the Australian Government to say that there would be no further research into the Jindalee. It would be absurd. There are a number of examples of that kind. Mr Beazley's answer given in the House of Representatives last night has a considerable amount of sense about it in the light of the Government's announced policy in respect of SDI. However, insofar as the fine tuning of that policy is concerned, the Government has not examined all the issues which will finally lead to a Government statement on those particular aspects.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of recent statements made on behalf of President Reagan which rejected the call for a nuclear testing moratorium because it was `not in the security interests of the United States, our friends and allies'? Was the Australian Government consulted on our security interests and our feelings on the proposed moratorium? If not, does the Australian Government agree with this assessment of Australia's security interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware that, following Mr Gorbachev's surprise public proposal on 30 March for a summit meeting in Europe to deal exclusively with the test ban issue, the White House issued a statement which said, among other things, that a nuclear testing moratorium was, as Senator Bolkus has quoted, `not in the security interests of the United States, our friends and allies'. A legally binding and effectively verifiable comprehensive test ban treaty to bring to an end all nuclear testing in all environments for all time is the Government's top priority in the disarmament field. The United States Government views this step as a long term objective that would be acceptable in the context of broad, deep and verifiable arms reductions, substantial improved verification capabilities, greater balance and conventional forces and at a time when a nuclear deterrent is no longer as essential an element as it is currently for international security and stability.

ANSWER.PARA: Clearly, as Mr Hayden pointed out in response to a question without notice from, I think, Mr Langmore in the other place on 18 March, there are, as a result, major differences between us and the Americans with regard to the timing of a comprehensive test ban treaty. A moratorium is another matter. We welcome any interruption of the nuclear testing programs and we have welcomed the Soviet moratorium. However, Australia does not regard moratoria as a substitute for the concrete steps that we are convinced need to be taken above all in the verification area to make possible the conclusion of a comprehensive test ban treaty. The Government regards effective means of verifying compliance as fundamental to the arms control process. We are confident that a comprehensive test ban treaty can be made effectively verifiable but we accept that prevailing doubts are real and must be addressed directly. The Government could not, as a matter of principle, urge any state to enter into an arms control arrangement that may not be effectively verifiable.

The United States is fully acquainted with our views on a comprehensive test ban treaty and on a moratorium on nuclear testing. Similarly, we are fully acquainted with the United States views. The Government engages in a continuous dialogue with the United States on these and related issues at both the ministerial and official levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and also concerns the invitation to Australia to join in research under the strategic defence initiative. Will the Minister give a guarantee that the Government will not seek to prevent universities and other tertiary institutions from becoming involved in aspects of the SDI program?

—I do not think there is anything much to add to the very clear statement made yesterday by the Minister for Defence and amplified just now by Senator Button or to the answer that has appeared in Hansard which I gave in response to a question from Dr Klugman. As far as we are aware, no universities are engaging directly in SDI research and as universities operate within government policy we do not expect that they will.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANS AUSTRALIA AIRLINES: CHANGE OF NAME

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation about the proposed change in the name of Trans Australia Airlines-TAA-and its corporate image so that it would be known simply as Australian Airlines-AA. I note that it is only a short time since TAA last had a major change in its logo; it is one of which I approve. Was the Government consulted by the Australian National Airlines Commission before this decision was made? If so, did the Government give its approval and why? Does the Minister not agree that there are very good arguments for retaining the long-standing, well recognised and even well-loved trading name, TAA, and that there are dangers in the confusion which can result from too frequent changes in corporate images and this one in particular? Will the Minister assure us all that this is not just an attempt to provide a public-relations firm led recovery? While recognising that the Commission is an independent statutory authority, will the Minister ask the Commission to reconsider what I believe to be its ill-advised decision?

—I have no brief on this matter supplied to me by the Minister for Aviation although I am aware of Press reports which suggest that the name TAA will be changed to Australian Airlines. I remind Senator Coates and the Senate that TAA is an independent corporation and is capable of making decisions on these matters as an independent authority. I think TAA would probably make some representations to the Minister in due course. I am not aware of whether it has done that but I would imagine that, as it has authority to make all commercial decisions, it has authority to act independently on all matters affecting the way in which the airline operates. However, as Senator Coates referred to a number of matters in respect of the operation of the Government airline-that authority is then delegated to Trans Australia Airlines-I will seek the opinion of the Minister and ask him to convey it to Senator Coates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he agrees with Mr Kim E. Beazley, a senior Minister in the Whitlam Government and father of the present Minister for Defence, who said in a letter to Saturday's West Australian in relation to the strategic defence initiative:

QUESTION.PARA: The United States has every right to develop the means of intercepting rockets intended to destroy millions of their people. If they find it, I hope they make this purely defensive weapon available to us.

Does he not agree that this is a more responsible view of the strategic defence initiative than the attitude being taken by the Hawke Government, which is fundamentally pro-Soviet because it will not aid the Western democracies to catch up with the developments in the fields of laser and particle beam weapons that the Soviets have made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could give a short answer and say that I do not agree with the view of Mr Beazley Senior on this matter. However, it is unfair to give such a short answer because the piece of the letter which was quoted is probably taken out of context.
—No.

—Maybe it is not but I have not seen the whole letter and I am not proposing to provide a firm and definitive no on the basis of half a sentence which has been taken out of the letter. On several occasions the Government has expressed its view about the international ramifications of the SDI program. We do not agree with it on international grounds because we think that it is not contributing to an appropriate environment for nuclear disarmament which is what this Government has sought and Ministers in this Government have said that on a number of occasions. It is not a uniquely Australian view. It is a position which has been taken by a number of other governments and it is certainly one to which we will adhere.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the honourable senator's characterisation of the Government's position on this matter being pro-Soviet, I think he would be capable of making that characterisation about almost anything we did. That is a comment on him rather than on us.
Senator MacGibbon proceeding to address a supplementary question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's question is not a supplementary question. He is now endeavouring to raise new material and I rule him out of order.

—I refer the Minister for Education to a supposed cost saving proposal advocated by the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, which would force unemployment beneficiaries to undertake a course of study. What is the Minister's reaction to this proposal? Can the Minister estimate the cost of this proposal and can he outline the Government's achievements in income support for young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief, my response to this particular alleged cost saving proposal is the same as it is to all of the cost saving proposals that come forward from the Opposition in its present state, denuded of ideas and competence: It is completely shonky. I would have thought that a former Treasurer, even the discredited former Treasurer as he is often referred to by my colleague Senator Walsh, would be able to do costings a little better than that. In fact the Opposition's plan to force the unemployed into institutions to study would add to public expenditure costs and certainly not reduce them. It would add to them in a way that would be most inefficient and would be of no benefit to anybody involved. In fact, the costs would be quite prohibitive.

ANSWER.PARA: My colleague the Minister for Finance has estimated the recurrent costs alone of Mr Howard's proposal to be in excess of $600m. These estimates assume that the scheme would be aimed primarily at the young unemployed who it is assumed would undertake training in technical and further education colleges; of course, costs would be far higher if some of the unemployed were put into colleges or universities to study. The estimates do not take account of the provision of necessary capital and equipment facilities which would of course add to the costs of this so-called savings exercise and make it totally exorbitant.

But, apart from the costs involved, such a scheme would be unworkable from a practical point of view because some 40 per cent of the unemployed are out of work for periods of less than eight weeks, so large numbers of people would withdraw from the scheme upon finding employment, thus obtaining very little with any benefit from such a short period of training. Clearly, this would be very expensive and very inefficient. It is important and interesting to contrast this extravagant and ill-thought-out scheme with the very solid record of providing education, training and job opportunities which our Government has now chalked up. At this stage in our Government more than 60,000 more young people are in post-compulsory-education training than was the case when this Government took office. We have made huge inroads into the youth unemployment problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—Well, the 60,000 young people to whom I was referring would otherwise have been on the dole. The Government would much prefer those 60,000 young people to be studying in upper secondary schools, in TAFE colleges, in universities or in colleges of advanced education than hanging around on the dole. That is the kind of solution to youth unemployment that our Government is pursuing, and with outstanding success.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry will be aware of recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures that show the cost of labour as a significant contribution to the current squeeze on our rural industries. In the light of this fact, why has the Government rejected farmers' demands that rural employees be allowed to enter into employment contracts and income sharing agreements outside the wages system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a widespread belief around the Opposition and probably in some parts of rural Australia that, if the accord and the wage fixing policy which is the principal component of it were abandoned, there would be lower wage outcomes than there have been under the accord. That is a belief, an act of faith, that is unsupported by the empirical evidence. The fact is that that policy was tried by the previous Government, by the discredited former Treasurer, in May 1981. We had a wages explosion of 14 per cent in 1981 and 13 per cent in 1982. Because of the success of the accord and the effect of Medicare, which was a major component of it, we have in fact generally seen wages rising at a lower rate than prices. As a result of productivity growth labour unit costs have been reduced to the lowest point since the late 1960s. That is the outcome of the accord-the lowest per unit labour cost since the late 1960s compared with the free market tried by the previous Government which produced wages explosions of 14 per cent and 13 per cent. Some farmers may argue that wages paid on farms would be lower under a decentralised system. That may or may not be true but it is important to note that, even if that were so, the indirect costs of labour to the agricultural sector are greater than the direct costs of labour. To say the least, it is highly unlikely that wage outcomes, or wage costs as they affect farmers, would be lower under the system proposed than under the system which exists.

ANSWER.PARA: I add that, when the level of wages is compared with the level of net farm income as estimated by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, it is important to note the deficiencies of that net farm income as a measure of household disposable income. It is deficient for these reasons: Firstly, it is based on a survey with voluntary compliance and the accuracy of the information provided cannot be guaranteed; that is an area of doubt. Secondly, there is no inclusion whatsoever of income earned off-farm in that BAE figure of net farm income. There is a deduction from cash flow, an imputed depreciation allowance, which in wheat farms in the most recent year averaged $27,000, that is notionally deducted from income irrespective of whether any money has been spent. Conversely-this is not an exhaustive list-there is no allowance in that BAE figure of net farm income for imputed income accruing from the fact that farmers normally have a house which is paid for by the business, whereas a number of wage earning families pay anything up to $8,000 a year on housing loans; there is no imputed income for a car or its running costs which are normally debited to the farm account. For food grown on the farm and consumed by the farm household the figure supplied in the BAE survey of $150 is the figure used. While there is considerable room for doubt as to how quantitatively important those items are that I have mentioned, that is, on imputed income or the absence of any significant imputed income in that BAE calculation, there can be no doubt that on average it would amount to several thousand dollars per household per year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: STRATEGIC DEFENCE INITIATIVE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is the Government aware that the Canadian Prime Minister wrote to United States Defense Secretary Weinberger on 11 September 1985 stating that the policies and priorities of the Canadian Government do not warrant that Government's support of the strategic defence initiative program? In view of the repeated statements by responsible Ministers of the Australian Government that Australia does not endorse the SDI program, can the Minister say whether Australia has responded to the United States request for our involvement in similar terms to those used by Canada? If Australia has not responded, why have we not responded and when will we respond? Is the Minister also aware that the United States is seeking the application of strict technology transfer controls to all nations which participate in the SDI program? In the event of Australian participation, will these controls be put in place in Australia? Will Australia have to become a member of the Co-ordinating Committee on Exports of Technology to Communist Countries and be subject to its edicts? In view of the heavy restrictions on technology and information transfer sought by the United States, can the Minister explain in what manner the benefits of high technology transfer to Australia will reach the civil industrial sector? How many years lead time does he anticipate--
—Order! I have asked honourable senators to restrict their questions as much as possible and I ask Senator Vallentine to comply with that continuing request.

—Finally, I ask the Minister: What powers are available to the Government to prevent academic or non-academic researchers based in Australia from taking Pentagon money for SDI research in the event that the Government rejects the United States offer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said on several occasions here today, the Government does not endorse the SDI program and, as a result, will not be entering into any negotiations to establish an umbrella agreement of any kind for SDI research, such as has been entered into by the United Kingdom Government and I think very few other governments-perhaps one. I am not aware whether the Canadian Prime Minister wrote to the United States Defense Secretary on 11 September. I understand that the position of the Canadian Government on this matter is that it is not co-operating with the United States Government as a government but individual companies in Canada may or may not be involved in joint ventures with--
—That is a very important point. They are not blocking the companies.

—I thank Senator MacGibbon. I am always reinforced when he interjects and tells me that I have made an important point. I feel much better about it all. I feel that the intellectual content of my answers must be substantial when Senator MacGibbon approves of them. I understand that to be the position of the Canadian Government. I was next asked whether Australia has responded to the United States request. We have not responded, as a government, to the Weinberger letter. We do not see any particular hurry about this matter; nor, I believe, does the United States. In that sense there has been no formal response. But the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have indicated the attitude which I expressed earlier in answering this question-that the Government was not supportive of the SDI program-and that matter has been indicated to the United States Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I was also asked whether the United States would seek strict technology transfer controls and so on. I am not able to say. If it did, I think it would be counter-productive in its terms and it certainly would not be beneficial in terms of Australia or any other country participating in the program. I was asked to explain in what manner the benefits of high technology transfer to Australia would reach the industrial sector in Australia. I do not have to explain that in view of the matters which I have referred to earlier in this answer. I was then asked what powers were available to the Government to prevent academic or non-academic researchers based in Australia from taking Pentagon money. I am unable to say what powers are available. It is not a question that the Government has addressed at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The first part of my question has not been answered. I asked: Will the Government respond to the invitation? Will it respond this week when Weinberger is in Australia, will it respond next week when Hawke is in Washington, or is it not going to respond at all? If not, why not?
—The Government will respond when the Government decides it is appropriate and not when Senator Vallentine decides it is appropriate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and refers to Australia's participation in the Star Wars program. Firstly, is the Prime Minister aware of reports that, in negotiations governing British participation in Star Wars research, the United States of America has specified that the results of that research can be applied only to Star Wars and not to other potential users, that all patents arising will be the property of the United States and that British researchers will be bound by United States secrecy and security laws? Secondly, is there any reason to believe that any involvement of private companies in Australia in such research would not take place under the same arrangements? Thirdly, would this not result in a de facto brain drain from Australia--
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Questions in this Question Time are very long. I ask you to discipline honourable senators in that regard.

—Order! I have asked honourable senators continually to restrict the length of their answers and Ministers to restrict the length of their answers so that everyone is given a fair go at Question Time. I ask Senator Sanders to comply with that request. If he does not do so I will ask him to put his question on the Notice Paper.

—Thank you, Mr President. In view of the fact that one Australian firm, Newtech Development Corporation, is already engaging in strategic defence initiative research, what will the Government do to protect its stated defence policy opposing Star Wars as well as Australian security and sovereignty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked firstly whether the Prime Minister was aware of reports about negotiations between the British Government and the United States of America in relation to participation in the SDI program and a number of conditions which are said to have been attached to those negotiations-that all patents will be the property of the United States and so on. First of all, I am not aware of the details of that and I doubt whether the Prime Minister is either. If the British Government agreed to all the conditions referred to by Senator Sanders in his question it would turn out, in my view, to be a much worse government that I ever thought it was, and that is saying something. I do not know whether the British Government has or has not agreed to all those conditions. I would think it unlikely in view of the attention that it has given in past years to questions of technological sovereignty as distinct from technological subservience. I was also asked whether there was any reason to believe that the involvement of Australian private companies would take place under the same arrangements. There is every reason to believe that it would not take place under the same arrangements because they are not desirable arrangements for either a government or a nation in terms of inverse transfer of technology, if I might call it that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sanders also asked me about the work of Newtech. He, of course, made the sloppy allegation that Newtech is engaged in what he called Star Wars research. He can characterise it in that way if he likes. Newtech was engaged in research on advanced chip technology long before the so-called Star Wars program was invented. If money is going to that company or to a joint venturer with that company in the United States which comes out of the Pentagon's defence budget, so be it. The fact of the matter is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't it bother you?

—I do not know what the honourable senator is suggesting. If he is suggesting that a company such as Newtech, having embarked on a research program in respect of chip technology, is suddenly abandoning that program because it is said to have some marginal relevance to SDI, frankly, that is not a view which I accept. If the honourable senator wants to put his Australian Democrat witch hunters into Australian universities and research institutions he should do it, but I will not be a part of it.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the presidential gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Ireland led by the Speaker of the Parliament, Mr Fitzpatrick. I welcome all members of the delegation to Canberra and I trust that they enjoy a pleasant visit to Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I believe that the Minister would be aware of comments in the media attributed to Messrs Peacock and Fischer, Opposition spokesmen on foreign affairs and veterans' affairs respectively, that Australia should sever all diplomatic ties with Libya if Colonel Gaddafi followed through with threats to bulldoze Australian war graves in Libya. Is the Minister aware of any real threat to Australian war graves expressed by Colonel Gaddafi? Is the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in London monitoring the position? What is the latest advice to the Minister from the Director of the Office of Australian War Graves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a beat-up story that has been published in one of the newspapers suggesting that possibly there is desecration of Commonwealth war graves in Libya. There is little substance to the story and a lot of exaggeration. Largely, one can say that a number of people have responded to this news item without there being any foundation to the original story. However, following the media reports which appeared in the Australian newspaper on 4 April, the Office of Australian War Graves sought advice from the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in London. I am advised that the Commission has no information suggesting that the security of the Commonwealth war graves is currently threatened. There are some 7,000 war graves of Commonwealth veterans, a little fewer than 1,000 of which are of Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: The Mike Carlton announcement appears to have been based upon a speculative item in the British Daily Telegraph of 2 April that suggested that Libya was requesting rent. In no way have we established, beyond what was on the Mike Carlton show, that the use of bulldozers would be involved in this particular war graves area. My advice is that there is no substance to the statement made in the media, and the Commonwealth War Graves Commission has undertaken to keep us advised should there be any change in the situation. The outrageous statements that there was some serious challenge to the sanctity of the war graves in Libya that were made by Mr Peacock and Mr Fischer, who sought to compound the issue even further, deserve outright condemnation by the Parliament. The latest advice I have, received yesterday, is that my Department, having discussed the matter with the Department of Foreign Affairs and a representative of the Libyan People's Bureau in Australia, confirms that there has been no desecration, that the cemetaries are well maintained, that they are inspected regularly by the Italian Embassy and that they are maintained particularly by the locally engaged staff and supervised by staff from the United Kingdom. I repudiate any suggestion that the Commonwealth war graves section or the Australian war graves section is under any threat from Colonel Gaddafi or the Libyan Government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BROKEN HILL PROPRIETARY CO. LTD: PROPOSED TAKEOVER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the conclusions of the Victorian Supreme Court case concerning the Bell Resources Ltd takeover of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, is the Minister now able to say what undertakings Mr Holmes a Court made on the subject of the future operations of BHP to the Cabinet committee which was claimed by Senator Gareth Evans this morning to be an acceptable alternative to a public inquiry? In view of the comments made by Mr Justice Marks, is the Minister satisfied that the Cabinet committee was not misled or deceived? What information was given to the Cabinet committee on the method of financing the takeover and, finally, what methods are available to the Government to enforce compliance with any undertakings given?

—If I might deal with the last part first, I have said in this chamber on other occasions, and I think it has been said publicly, that the only test of whether undertakings given have been carried out in the manner one might expect from the nature of the undertakings is, of course, the ultimate credibility of those who give them-public figures as they are, and important figures in the Australian business community. The Government is not in the position of administering sanctions, as it were, for failure to comply with undertakings. That would involve us as a government, or any government, in considerable difficulty.
—What about the BLF?

—If the honourable senator wants to ask me a question about the Builders Labourers Federation he may do so, but not in the context of dealing with this matter. As to the undertakings given by both BHP and Mr Holmes a Court to the Government at the time the last bid was in issue, I indicated subsequently, as did other Ministers, that the Government would consider publishing those undertakings at a particular time when the case in the Supreme Court of Victoria was resolved. This has happened. I am just not sure that there is not to be a new round of litigation which may affect the Government's decision on that matter. No final decision has been made on the release of those documents, although I know the matter was the subject of discussion only yesterday. A substantial number of the undertakings given by Mr Holmes a Court appear in the Part A statement in respect of the bid but I am not in a position to elaborate further than that other than to say that the question of the release of undertakings by both parties will be further considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, and I ask it against the background of the recent comments on Four Corners by the four former royal commissioners on drug abuse to the effect that the response by governments to their reports has been too little, too late. However, my question specifically relates to an assertion that has been frequently made, and made very recently, that there exists in the possession of authorities the photograph of a well known judge taken in the company of identified members of the Griffith mafia and other criminals, and that the photograph has been in evidence before either a recent royal commission or the National Crime Authority, or both. I ask: Firstly, has the Government knowledge of the existence of such a photograph and, if not, why has it not sought such knowledge? Secondly, what is the extent of the Government's knowledge and what action has been taken to prove the truth or falsity of the allegations? —I have no knowledge of the matters to which Senator Sir John Carrick is referring and accordingly I am not in a position to judge whether it is just another bit of scandalous scuttlebutt that is being trailed like another stinking fish across this chamber, in the way that happened on two or three dozen occasions over the first three years of the life of this Government, or rather whether there is something more to it. I will check with the Attorney-General and see what response he cares to make.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services and refers to the Frankston Baptist Centre Retirement Village in Victoria. Is it a fact that that organisation is in debt to the extent of around $20m? Further, what rights to care and occupancy do the residents of the village have if the village is to be sold to pay these debts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do know of the difficulties of the Frankston Baptist Centre Retirement Village, as do Senator Zakharov and, I think, every other politician from Victoria. It seems that the centre is currently experiencing considerable financial difficulties. In fact, my information is that the organisation owes no less than $17m to three major creditors and over $2m to trade creditors and various deceased estates. I feel very sorry for the people who are occupants and people who have put money in to become occupants of that village, particularly in light of the fact that the Reverend Bob Payne who ran that organisation spent a considerable amount of his time attacking this Government, representatives of the party that now make up this Government; he also spent a considerable amount of his time praising the previous Government and Liberal Party politicians were beating a path to his door, until the truth of his activities came out. Now I understand he is complaining that they will not have anything to do with him and do not want to see him any more. But that, I suppose, is pretty typical.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Community Services is closely monitoring the situation as it affects Commonwealth moneys paid in respect of nursing home benefits, and in respect of recurrent and capital expenditure for hostels. This includes monitoring the situation which may occur if the organisation's properties in Victoria and in Queensland, the Coorong Nursing Home, are sold. I understand that an offer to purchase the Frankston Baptist Centre Retirement Village is being considered at the moment, but I am also aware of the fact that in recent times other offers of this type have fallen through.

It is ironical, I suppose, that the Victorian Government had to lend $300,000 to this organisation to help bail it out, in light of the fact that this organisation spent so much time also attacking the Victorian Government. Also recently a further loan of $100,000 has been made. We are closely looking at the situation. We have taken legal advice with a view to clarifying the Commonwealth's position should the centre and the nursing home be sold. Through the Australian Government Solicitor in Victoria we have requested that a security agreement be negotiated to protect the capital grant it receives from us. In respect of the possible sale of the Coorong Nursing Home in Queensland, it is expected that the home would continue to operate as a participating home and therefore no inconvenience would occur to the home's residents. The Department is providing advice to the organisation concerning the ongoing costs of the hostel.

Information we have indicates that the hostel should not be forced to close. Advice we have also received seems to indicate that the standards of care are being maintained. Action is being taken by the Victorian Government to regulate the retirement village industry, including the protection of rights of residents in resident-funded complexes. The sad lesson out of this exercise is that people like the Reverend Bob Payne and others believe that somehow, because they are ministers of religion and apparently have pure motives, they are economic wizards. It does not mean that the people who put money in their hands are protected by some forces other than economic laws in this country. I hope though that the combined actions of the Government, the Department of Community Services, the Victorian Government and our legal authorities will enable people and the public purse to be protected in this case.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 April, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax which threatens thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax which threatens thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries.

The caterwauling we have heard from the Ministers opposite is a good indication of their lack of concern on the matters which have been raised with the Government by industry, by trade unions and by many other commentators and the Opposition. Those Ministers' lack of concern for the jobs that will be lost in the car industry no doubt will not be lost on their constituencies. The Government has what I would describe as a Jekyll and Hyde approach to industry policy. On the one hand through the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) it promised stability and predictability. On the other hand, it has put new and unexpected taxes which raise prices and reduce demand.
