On the one hand it urges industry to be more competitive and to be export-oriented, and on the other hand the Government adds to costs by new taxes on business and it brings in the accord-induced cost increases.

There has just been an announcement of job losses in Western Australia through Western Mining, and although this matter of urgency is primarily directed to our concern in the car industry, I stress that there are other industries which are also affected by the Government's taxation policy. Western Mining has announced nickel production cuts, but in face of the highly competitive position that company has with continuing low world nickel prices, it has had burdens laid upon it by the Government, as well as cost increases, including those laid on it by the accord, and the fringe benefit taxes on employee housing which will hit the company. It is a wide problem. It is not something which merely affects the car industry; it significantly affects the car industry. The car industry is probably the best example of the split personality that the Government has displayed in its approach to industry policy generally.

It is worth going back to see what Minister Button promised the Australian people with respect to the car plan, a plan which, of course, has had the substantial support of the Opposition. He came into the Senate on 29 May 1984 and gave us the details of that car plan. He put out a statement which included among the central aims of the car policy the holding down of the price of cars, the reduction of job losses in the short term and the provision of job stability in the industry. Instead of that we have a situation where the Government is causing the prices of cars to rise substantially, and it is doing so in a context which is an extremely delicate one because there are other factors at work in the car industry which are giving rise to difficulty and the Government is exacerbating those difficulties by its proposed changes to the taxation law. It has also, of course, changed the sales tax law. It has followed policies which have seen a massive devaluation of the dollar. We have seen record interest rates and we have seen the prices of cars rise in Australia by as much as 60 per cent on some imported models and by over 10 per cent for popular brands of locally produced cars.

On top of that, because of the fringe benefits tax, the cost to companies of providing vehicles for their employees will rise by as much as $1,200 a year, which is an increase of about 29 per cent. Our concern in the Opposition is the same concern which has been expressed by the trade union movement, by the Government of South Australia and by the industry itself. In the circumstances in which the industry finds itself, that sort of change will bring about a further reduction in sales, it will be very damaging and will cause the loss of thousands of jobs in Australia. That is a breach of two of the central aims of the Government's car plan, a plan which we have supported because we believe that the industry should have stability and predictability and that there ought to be as far as possible a bipartisan approach to important areas of industry policy. The Minister came in here and said that part of the plan was to hold down the price of cars and to provide job stability. The wilful actions of this Government are, of course, moving in the opposite direction.

Estimates of the impact of the tax vary but the estimates are consistent in that they all show that job losses will occur. The Government has had submissions from the Labor Government of South Australia which came to Canberra and which has been reported as saying that 4,500 jobs will be lost in that State this year; that is 4,500 jobs in one State alone. There is a comparatively modest Australia-wide estimate released by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries which suggests that 10,000 jobs will go around Australia. The trade union movement-a trade union movement which is usually so influential with this Government-has publicly put the figure at 25,000 jobs lost because of the Government's taxation measures. Whichever figure one selects, whether one says it is 4,500 jobs in the State of South Australia, 10,000 jobs around Australia, or 25,000 jobs around Australia as suggested by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, the direction is clear: Many thousands of jobs will be lost because of the new taxes being imposed by this Government.

One of the important elements of what was put forward by the Government in the car plan was this promise of certainty and predictability. I would like to quote a few more words of Senator Button's from May 1984. He said:

The broad outline of the Government's proposals for this industry is not negotiable, although in an industry of this kind there is always room for minor adjustments and improvements during a major program of change.

The Opposition considered the car plan carefully and has consistently since May 1984 given support to the broad outline of the car plan and support to the idea that there should be stability and predictability so that the industry can plan the investment and the changes required if we are to maintain this major sector of Australian manufacturing industry which employs tens of thousands of Australians. That proposition of Senator Button's had our support and has our support. We believe that predictability and certainty are important to get both the effort and the investment that is required, but now we can see the Government bringing about unnecessary changes which strike at the whole basis of the plan by reducing demand. Perhaps the most serious is the fact that the demand is especially likely to be reduced for high local content cars which are central to our national industry and to our national interest.

What is being done by the Government in the fringe benefits tax to be introduced on 1 July is being done at a critically important time for the industry because of the many factors coming together which I have mentioned. There is the devaluation, which is affecting not just those who import cars but those who import part of the components which go to making up cars, increased sales tax, record high interest rates, the introduction of unleaded petrol and then there is the final blow, the fringe benefits tax. I will not labour the situation with respect to the devaluation of the dollar but with the Laser, a car produced by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd with just over 50 per cent local content, we find an increase in price of about 18 per cent last year, which is well above the inflation rate. The Falcon rose in price by 11 per cent, which is again above the inflation rate. We find with respect to sales tax additional increases in the cost of cars being imposed by deliberate government action. We find with respect to the Government's high interest rate policy, again a disincentive to Australians to purchase cars, and we find an additional cost of upwards of $350 per vehicle because of the introduction of the unleaded petrol equipment.

We have all of these things which will reduce demand and now we have the additional problem of the fringe benefits tax. The exact impact of the fringe benefits tax remains unknown but I know that the Government has had detailed discussions with the industry and it has been provided with detailed information. In answers in this place Senator Button has indicated that at the time the tax was imposed the Government had very limited information on what impact it would have. The Government is saying on its estimates that the new tax will take about $350m in extra taxes out of the community, so that is the additional burden which will be borne by businesses, although the industry estimates that the additional taxes could be as high as $570m. Clearly that must damage the motor vehicle manufacturing plan and it must do something to inhibit demand.

We now have access to estimates put forward by the industry which suggest that the tax changes alone will cost the industry 35,000 vehicle sales in 1986 and 25,000 in subsequent years. The 25,000 figure which has been put forward by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries is a very conservative figure because if one looks at the study which has been prepared on its behalf one finds that tens of thousands more losses of sales are predicted than the industry is currently claiming. That is a very conservative figure. It believes that there will be a total reduction in vehicle sales of 90,000 in 1986 because of the other factors which I have mentioned but that there will be a 35,000 loss of vehicle sales this year because of the new sales tax. It believes that by volume there will be a 20 per cent loss of volume of sales in high content locally produced motor vehicles-the Falcon and the Commodore-and it is quite clear that there is basic agreement between the National Institute of Economic and Industrial Research Pty Ltd, which did the study for the Chamber, the Department of State Development in South Australia and the Vehicle Builders Union. The Government is faced with a virtual unanimity of view that there will be important employment consequences because of these tax increases.

This is a major disruption to the plan and it is the view of the Opposition that it threatens the motor vehicle plan. In the view of the Opposition that is very bad news for Australia because the stability and predictability which was promised by the Minister was an important pre-condition for getting the sort of changes to the industry which it was unanimously agreed it required. There is plenty of evidence from the comments of the Minister that he is concerned about the impact of this tax. The Opposition believes that the Minister's car plan is in fact being threatened by the greed of the Government for additional revenue and in particular for the need of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to introduce new taxes on business which would make up for the lack of substantial tax reform in the tax package last year. There was, I think, an inference that the industry was likely to get relief from this, but that now appears very unlikely. If the Minister is able to rise today to give us a contrary assurance, the Opposition, like the industry, will be much relieved.

The likely effect on industry of the issues I have raised is that there will be 90,000 units fewer produced than the record level of nearly 700,000 sold last year. The Minister is likely to make much of the fact that the industry has been through buoyant years. That is true. There have been high sales in the last two years. But the reality is that the period of difficulty in the car plan lies ahead. For the Government to be imposing changes which reduce by up to 35,000 vehicles in one year the sales which would otherwise have been made is a severe blow to the practicability of the car plan.

Until now, of course, the argument has been theoretical. The Opposition has raised in this place the predictions which have been made by trade unions, by a State government and by industry that there would be losses of sales and, hence, losses of jobs. But we have now reached the point at which we have stopped dealing with theory and we are starting to deal with reality. Already in this year we have seen a very significant drop in sales in the first three months. The Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries puts the drop in sales at 22 per cent for the first three months of 1986, compared with that of the corresponding period in 1985, with fleet sales, as a result of the tax, being down by 20 per cent in the first three months of 1986.

Of course, the tax has not yet been imposed, but the reality is that companies making purchases now will bear the burden of the new tax, and there is plenty of anecdotal evidence and statements by people in industry who purchase cars for business use that, because of the tax, purchases will be postponed and will be less frequent. Perhaps I may give a few more figures. The registration of new vehicles in January 1986 was down by 13.8 per cent compared with the figures for December 1985, and down by 14 per cent compared with the figure for January 1985. We find larger drops in February, when 26.7 per cent fewer sales or registrations were made compared with the February 1985 figure.

We have passed the point of theorising about this industry. We have reached the point at which the drop off in sales has become apparent, and we have a situation in which it is up to the Government to do something about the elements of the car plan which it has now put at risk and the damage which is being done to the Australian industry. What the Government needs to do during this period of serious difficulty for the industry, this period of emerging difficulty for the industry, is to hold down the price of cars, as Senator Button promised to do in May 1984, and to provide job stability in this essential industry. That is what the Government is not doing, and that is what the Opposition calls upon the Government to do.

I should like to refer to some of Senator Button's comments with respect to the matters that I have raised on this motion of urgency and which bear out the hopes which he held out that the Government would behave sensibly with respect to this industry. Senator Button was quoted in the Business Review Weekly in March this year, in an article which was headed with these words:
The Hawke Government is set to make significant changes to the fringe benefits tax on cars after strong representations from the industry.
The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, told the Business Review Weekly:
I think you will find we've arrived at a satisfactory solution.

I hope that the Minister will make it clear in his speech in this debate whether he regards no action as a satisfactory solution, because I am sure that this is not what the industry thought that he meant when he made that statement.

If we look, too, at the Minister's response when the issue has been raised with him in the Senate, we find that in November of last year he conceded that the Government, when it made its decision about the proposed fringe benefits tax, reached certain conclusions. He said:
Those conclusions were based on sets of quite conflicting information.

I can understand that. There may have been a degree of carelessness involved with respect to the Government's actions, or there may simply have been an impossibility of predicting with any certainty what the total circumstances of the economy and the industry would be in 1986 and what the impact of the tax might be. Senator Button admitted that the conclusions that the Government had made were based on conflicting information, and he went on to say that when the survey from the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries was published he would be discussing the results with the industry. He went on to say:
. . . if any appropriate steps seem to be necessary as a result of that discussion I will take those steps in the context of the Government's deliberations.

In February of this year Senator Button said in the Senate that whether or not the fringe benefits tax would be modified would depend on the assessment made of the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries paper and discussions which were then taking place about that paper.

To this point, in his utterances in this chamber and in his public utterances, Senator Button has clearly held out the view that it was quite possible that this tax would be damaging to the industry and that the Government would act appropriately if it became apparent that that was the case. I put it to the Senate and to the Minister, who is at the table, that it is now quite clear that damage is being done; it is now quite clear that the car plan, which is important to Australia, is being substantially interfered with by the Government's new tax proposals. I ask the Government to heed the Opposition's call, to remove the fringe benefits tax and to give this important industry a chance. We are not dealing with theory any longer. The predictions are being borne out. Sales are down quite dramatically; but worse is to come. The onus is on Senator Button to tell us that he will produce what he promised. The onus is on him to ensure that the Government acts in a rational way with respect to this important industry.

Last year the Minister admitted that the Cabinet made its decision to tax company cars without any really reliable assessment of the impact of the tax. I suggest that that reliable assessment is now available. Now that several studies show what a devastating effect the tax will have, there is no justification for the Government to proceed with the tax. We have just seen the Government, after many months, concede the damage that its policies were doing to the housing industry. We have seen the Government turn some of its policies on its head to try to do something about an industry which has gone into a severe downturn. We now have a situation in which a second industry faces difficulties that are just as great. The Opposition calls upon the Government to do something. What we call upon the Government to do is to remove its fringe benefits tax, which is damaging to this industry and other industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to Senator Chaney, I had the distinct feeling that he was trying to embarrass me. I find it most extraordinary, in a chamber such as this, that he should embark upon such a course. I suppose that the question ultimately which has to be resolved is whether or not he has succeeded. I begin by referring to Senator Chaney's final call for abolition of the fringe benefits tax regime generally; not, as I understood it, relating to the motor vehicle industry alone, but generally.
—It will not help Western Mining. It will be selective.

—Senator Chaney interjects `It will not help Western Mining'-of course. But I think that the fringe benefits tax issue really must be considered in the context of the Government's White Paper on taxation and the fact that the Government was losing some $700m a year in benefits paid to employees by way of the provision of motor vehicles, free lunches, school fees, housing, and a whole range of issues-being paid not in cash but in kind, a process which was expanding very rapidly, at 25 per cent a year in terms of lost revenue to the Government. Of course, whilst that sort of thing is good for those who get the benefits of free lunches, motor vehicles, free housing or subsidised housing-benefits of that kind-it is detrimental to every Australian taxpayer who does not get those benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has been said in the Senate about the fringe benefits tax. Let me remind honourable senators of what honourable senators opposite were saying about fringe benefits taxes in December 1985. Senator Messner-the Opposition spokesman on finance, if you please-was saying that the effect of the abolition of the deduction for business lunches would be a loss of employment in the entertainment industry, the restaurant industry and so on-the hospitality industry-of 11,000. He was ably supported in those predictions by Senator Knowles from Western Australia, who estimated the jobs loss as 10,500. It was predicted by the Opposition that, because the fringe benefit which went to business people for deductible business lunches was to be abolished, those sorts of job loss were going to occur. The estimate by Senator Knowles was 10,500. Senator Boswell gave a similar estimate to that of Senator Messner. Senator Boswell said:

. . . I believe it will be around February or March-there will be a massive fall in the industry. Jobs in the industry will be lost . . . is the largest employer of youth in Australia. It . . . provides many jobs for youths . . .

Other honourable senators, including Senator Michael Baume, went on to make similar sorts of predictions. Senator Baume said that the fringe benefits tax would destroy the viability of the hospitality industry. Let us consider what, in fact, has happened to the entertainment or hospitality industry as a result. Job vacancies in the restaurant and hospitality industry notified to the Commonwealth Employment Service-contrary to the projections of gloom made by honourable senators opposite-have increased by 4.1 per cent since the announcement of the tax. In respect of restaurants, hotels and clubs, the job vacancies notified have increased by 25.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you predicting an increase in the motor car industry? Don't talk to us about the restaurant industry.

—I am not making any predictions about that at the moment. Essentially, what I am saying, which Senator Lewis does not like, is how stupid his lot is in terms of their capacity to predict these things. That is what I am saying. Let us be blunt about it. In respect of vacancies in the skilled food and beverage trades, in December 1984 the average number of advertisements in newspapers was 173; in February 1986 it was 307. So much for the Opposition's principled assault on the abolition of free lunches for businessmen and what that was going to do to employees in the restaurant and hospitality industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it surprising that Senator Chaney should tackle me for the impositions which he says have been put on the car industry. For example, one thing which he said was important was the introduction of unleaded petrol. Senator Chaney ought to know his history better than that. His Government introduced unleaded petrol, not this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are misquoting me.

—No. Senator Chaney said that. He said that the impositions on the car industry included unleaded petrol. Senator Chaney was attacking this Government. He said that unleaded petrol, sales tax rearrangements and now the fringe benefits tax were impositions. Unleaded petrol was the former Government's thing, not ours.

SPEECH.PARA: We were also attacked for changing the sales tax regime for the motor vehicle industry. The sales tax regime was changed simply because the Auditor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia said last year: `There has been a rip-off going on here for many years in respect of sales tax paid by the motor vehicle industry and that rip-off has to end'. That rip-off went on all the time the Opposition was in government. It has now been changed. I am sorry that that imposition has been imposed on the vehicle industry; but the fact is that if one is in government one ought not tolerate rip-offs of the taxation system, by whomever they are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could change the policy.

—Of course, one could do anything. We will come to that in a minute. There are now dire predictions, part of which I share, about reductions in volume in the vehicle industry-the volume of registrations and so on. If the worst of these predictions occurs in the 1986 calendar year, the motor vehicle industry in this country will be back to the point it was at in terms of volume under the Fraser Government. That would be a dreadful thing for this country, and a dreadful thing for the motor vehicle industry if it were in such bad shape as it was under the Fraser Government. That would be very bad for the industry.
—Will that be good enough?

—Of course not. It will not be good enough, but that is where it will be. So, let us recognise that many factors go to the health of an industry such as the motor vehicle industry and not just a fringe benefits tax. There is an argument-in which I personally see some merit-that, if an industry has to depend for its viability on what is essentially tax avoidance by sections of the community, one ought to look at that. I do not entirely accept that argument, but I can see some merit in it.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the solution, as Senator Chaney has just proffered by way of interjection, is not to look at the industry's problems in terms of whether we have a fringe benefits tax or not-the Government is committed to a fringe benefits tax as a principle, and I think honourable senators opposite would be, too, if they ever got into government because they could not stand the drain on the taxation system which occurs through this sort of thing-but to look at the taxation arrangements for an industry such as this in another way. I am not saying that we can necessarily do that. Governments confront these difficulties. The Fraser Government confronted revenue difficulties in 1979 by imposing a 2 per cent tax on all items imported into this country at concessional rates. That has been immensely damaging to Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take it off.

—I would love to take it off. That is a point. All I am saying is that governments do these things which are in conflict, perhaps, with the most desirable industry policy principles. Governments do these things and there is that conflict. Senator MacGibbon interjects, saying `take the tax off'. But the tax brings in a revenue of $179m. If one takes off that tax one has to put something on somewhere else, unless one is able massively to reduce government expenditure. There is not a hint from this Opposition that it is in any way about massively doing anything but increasing government expenditure on the basis of the promises made by its Leader, the discredited former Treasurer.
—But you do agree that it is a problem?

—Sure. I should refer in passing to a number of other matters referred to in Senator Chaney's comments. Senator Chaney made a number of suggestions that I had by implication said that the fringe benefits tax regime in respect of motor vehicles would be changed. In part I think what he says about that is correct. It was certainly my wish that it would be modified. I make no secret of that. I have said it publicly. But, after all, governments make these decisions collectively. I do not retreat from the suggestion implicit in some of my statements that it was my hope that there would be some modification this year of the fringe benefits tax. I remind honourable senators that I always said, and persistently said, that there had to be a fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles; the rate at which it was struck was the important thing.
—Is it the rate or also who paid it? Do you consider that?
—I do not think I need to consider that in the context of this debate.
—I thought that, seeing this was honesty day, you could consider that, too.

—If the honourable senator cannot stand it, he had better leave the chamber. I have always publicly said-and I say again-that there was some concern about the rate in what was inevitably a predictable market downturn in 1986 following the record years of 1984 and 1985. I should add that the record year of 1985 for car production and car registrations was undoubtedly influenced by some of the facts which Senator Chaney has mentioned, such as the inevitable introduction of unleaded petrol. I think the industry and everybody else recognise that there was a pull forward effect on motor car registrations and sales because of that likely introduction in 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear that a lot of the comments here or anywhere else about the effects of the fringe benefits tax are made in the context of a government which, in respect of the taxation regime, has been prepared to make hard decisions. We believe that they had to be made and that they are very important decisions in the overall context of Australian taxation because there are many benefits in the taxation changes made by this Government, benefits which will be manifest in the second half of this year and throughout 1987 and will be manifest in terms of imputations in the taxation system in respect of changes to marginal rates, reductions in marginal rates and a wide variety of other smaller issues which go to the question of improving the investment environment for Australians and Australian institutions in industrial equities. There is no doubt that those things will follow in time from the tax changes which have been made.

The second point is that many of the criticisms which have been levelled by Senator Chaney in his remarks have to be levelled in the light of the realities of high growth rates, a rapid increase in employment, industrial stability arising from the accord and the policies of this Government, and vastly improved competitiveness in many industries from the devaluation of the Australian dollar, which we do not claim as a government policy but is something which the government must recognise as important and significant in terms of its benefits to sections of industry. In that sort of environment, I believe that the criticisms that have been made have to be somewhat muted and taken less heed of than otherwise might be the case. Senator Chaney, in his matter of urgency, referred to estimates of production and employment made by various organisations. All I say about those estimates is that they concern me as the responsible Minister but, on the other hand, even the most serious estimates do not reduce the volume of this industry to what it was prior to the improvements to which I have referred.

I do not believe that the fringe benefits tax threatens the viability of the motor vehicle plan. It makes it harder for the Government or any government to achieve the objectives of the plan, but any imposition from outside the industry does so, whether in terms of interest rates-which I concede-the effects of devaluation, currency movements or a wide range of issues. Senator Chaney referred to the fringe benefits tax threatening thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries. I have adverted to the references that he made to jobs in the motor vehicle industry. I remind him that the year before the car plan was introduced nearly 10,000 workers lost their jobs in the motor vehicle industry. They did so because no previous government had taken upon itself the task of tackling this very difficult industry in a rational way and of reducing protection for an industry which was vastly overprotected. No previous government had taken those tasks upon itself. As the industry lumbered from one failure to another the employment loss, of course, was very substantial. Senator Chaney's matter of urgency refers to the employment loss in industries other than the motor vehicle industry. He made no reference to them in his comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned Western Mining and Kambalda.

—There has been recent discussion about job loss at Kambalda. But Senator Chaney has not referred to the hospitality and entertainment industry because job opportunities have increased rather than been lost since the fringe benefits tax came into effect. I do not think that the Government would claim that that was a direct result of the fringe benefits tax but it would certainly claim that it was a direct result of the overall economic stability of this country, strong consumer demand and a whole range of issues which are symptomatic of an economy which is basically in a state of stability and growth.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the motives behind the Opposition's matter of urgency. It has succeeded marginally in embarrassing me. If the Opposition wants to chalk up a success on that basis I am certainly pleased to concede it, but I make it quite clear again that the Government will not abandon fringe benefits taxes because of the sorts of arguments which have been advanced in this debate to date and, indeed, which have been advanced in the wider community debate on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support Senator Chaney's urgency motion concerning the need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax, which threatens thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries. Before coming to the remarks which I want mainly to make I will pick up a couple of Senator Chaney's comments and thrusts. We have severely embarrassed Senator Button on this issue but that was not really the point. We were not seeking to embarrass the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce but to provide comments and proposals to help perhaps Australia's major manufacturing industry. If this Government, which has responsibility for framing industry policy and the environment in which such industries are to operate, cannot set an environment which is conducive to the development of those industries, it deserves to be very severely and roundly condemned. This is what we are doing and will continue to do beyond today.

SPEECH.PARA: In some of Senator Button's other remarks he set up a straw man about comments by my leader, Senator Chaney. The Opposition does not suggest that all the adverse factors now affecting the automotive industry and manufacturing industry generally can be changed. Obviously, it would be meaningless and quite unrealistic to suggest that. Rather, in the present context of manufacturing industry, it is meaningless, bad and bad policy to impose more burdens on the industry. That is just what this fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry is doing.

I want to do two things: First, to look at the detail behind the Government's original decision to impose this fringe benefits tax and its reasoning not to modify that proposal; and, secondly, to outline part of the dismal record of the Hawke Government in failing to take the necessary actions to tackle the problems of manufacturing industry and the motor vehicle industry in particular, problems which it professes to recognise but its performance shows that it does not. Defence of the Government's fringe benefit tax on the motor vehicle industry that we have heard today from Senator Button is, to say the good thing first, brave; to say the more realistic thing, it is lamentable in its lameness. Indeed it was sad to listen to. I do not believe now that the Opposition's matter of urgency goes far enough. I now feel, having listened to the Minister's response, that we should be calling for his resignation as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you had done that already.

—I have. I might have to do it again too. In saying this I feel very sorry for the Minister's position because, as I hope he knows, we on this side of the House have a very high regard and respect for him personally. He is the third most senior Minister in the Hawke Labor Government and he is the Minister with overriding ministerial responsibility for providing industry in Australia with the necessary environment in which to become-as he says he wishes and I accept that-more competitive, more enterprising, more export oriented and more flexible. No amount of personal regard for him can permit me to overlook the catastrophic defeats that he is suffering in failing to persuade his Cabinet colleagues, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in particular, that this Government-his Government-is pursuing policies which, far from making Australian industry more competitive, flexible, enterprising and profitable, are simply worsening the problems which industry faces in this country. It is this failure to carry the day with the Minister's Cabinet colleagues which has been responsible for Senator Button's embarrassing non-defence today of the Government's decision not to abandon, or even to modify, its proposal to tax employers on vehicles provided to employees. This decision is indefensible. The overwhelming weight of carefully researched evidence from the motor vehicle industry, from impartial studies that have been commissioned, from relevant industry unions, from one or more State governments, and from a wide range of other interested parties, is that this tax will result in a major reduction in sales of locally produced motor vehicles. The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries puts the reduction at 35,000 six-cylinder vehicles in 1986 and a continuing loss of 25,000 vehicles in subsequent years.

SPEECH.PARA: When one takes into account the other adverse factors now hitting the motor vehicle industry, most of which I remind the Senate are factors which are government induced such as the devalued Australian dollar, the high level of interest rates, the increases in sales taxes on motor vehicles, and the introduction of unleaded petrol, the total impact of locally produced motor vehicle sales this year will be an estimated reduction in sales of 90,000 vehicles; that is, one out of every five locally produced vehicles. Job losses in vehicle manufacturing will be 3,000. There will be an overall job loss of at least 10,000 and the great majority of these jobs will be lost in small businesses, vehicle distributors, vehicle repair shops, parts manufacturers, distributors and so on. But in addition to this extensive impact on the industry broadly defined, the impact on the business sector which uses motor vehicles in the normal course of business will be simply enormous.

Let me make it clear what I am talking about. It is not generally recognised just how widely this new tax will extend. To date most attention has focused on purchases of fleet vehicles by the larger companies. The effect on vehicle purchases by these companies will be very substantial as recent surveys have shown. For example, a survey by the highly professional and highly reputable accounting firm, K. M. G. Hungerfords, has disclosed that 52 per cent of companies surveyed will reduce the total value of their company fleet, 51 per cent will hold on to company cars longer and therefore buy fewer and 42 per cent will move to smaller, cheaper vehicles, most of which are imported rather than produced locally. There lies the nub of one of the Opposition's key arguments today and that is that the Government's fringe benefits tax proposals in relation to the motor vehicle industry are completely at odds with Senator Button's car industry plan, the whole purpose of which is to increase over time the local content of Australian vehicles and to make the industry viable. The two policies-on the one hand Treasurer Keating's tax proposals and on the other hand Minister Button's car industry plans-are completely at odds, completely contradictory one with the other.

However, in addition to the impact on vehicles purchased by larger companies what is not generally recognised is that the new tax will also apply to most vehicles operated by small owner-operated and controlled businesses. For example, a company supplying and servicing office equipment, machines and computers, which must have vehicles in order to operate, will be savagely hit by the new tax unless it complies with enormously time-consuming and costly paper work procedures of substantiation. The cost of the new tax on business expenses will be extraordinarily high. Remember, it is a tax which the employer or the small businessman must pay irrespective of whether he is making a profit or going bankrupt.

The Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries has estimated, on the basis of commissioned studies, that vehicle ownership costs for business will increase by 29 per cent. For many businesses, and particularly small businesses in the service industries, this increased cost will be crippling. The reason for the Government putting forward this new tax proposal, along with all its other new tax proposals, is to attempt to raise additional revenue to fuel its ravenous expenditure appetite. This inability of the Hawke Government to exercise discipline and restraint over its spending programs, coupled with its continual capitulation to the trade union movement in its policy development, is the reason why in Australia today we have the highest level of taxation in our history, the highest level of real interest rates in at least 60 years, the lowest value of the Australian dollar at least since the Second World War, a public debt in excess of $7,000 for every man, woman and child in this nation, a foreign debt of $4,500 for every man, woman and child in this nation-a foreign debt which is growing by well over $10,000m each year and that is equal to another $650 for every man, woman and child in Australia-and an inflation rate twice the average of other Western nations and four times higher than that of nations such as Germany and Japan. These are the facts facing Australia today; these are the facts that this Government tries desperately to conceal; these are the problems we should be tackling. How should we be tackling them? We should be tackling them by exercising responsibility in government spending, government taxation, government borrowing and the Government's approach to wage fixation, superannuation schemes and other cost impositions on business.

What do we have instead? We have the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles; we have the most savage anti-business, rag-bag tax package of proposals that has ever been brought into this Parliament. In several of these respects the Government would do well to heed the excellent contribution to the industrial relations and wages policy debate made by one of Australia's most respected former trade union leaders, Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon, in a paper prepared for the Economic Planning Advisory Council in February, a paper the Prime Minister deliberately tried to have stifled. In that paper, Mr Fitzgibbon spoke, among other things, about the need to make the industrial relations and wage fixation systems more flexible in order to develop a more co-operative spirit between management and labour. That is a philosophy very much in line-I almost said very much in accord-with the policy of the Liberal and National parties and very much against what the Australian Labor Party, the Government, has been arguing. That paper has been produced by one of the most respected trade union leaders in Australia. The paper should be widely read and in that spirit I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. I consulted with Senator Button who has concurred.
Leave granted.
The paper read as follows-
Paper by C. H. Fitzgibbon
February 1986
What are industrial relations? How have they been seen and how should they be seen? What are the social and economic dynamics working on them and producing change? How should the challenges be met?
THE EVOLVING NATURE OF INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

1. Industrial relations, meaning relations between labour and capital, developed out of the excesses of capital following the industrial revolution. The desire of labour to organise was associated with the fact that disorganised they were terribly exploited and forced by economic necessity to work under conditions calculated to make maximum profit for capital or management, having no relation to any care for the welfare of the workforce involved and where any morality was the province of a very limited number of political reformers none of whom represented the capital involved. The lack of morality or traditional care was not necessarily true of other non-European states which will become important later when we consider the current position of industrial relations in Australia and the international changes impinging on current Australian problems.

2. If we look at industrial relations over the years we see it altering in line with the general alteration in social attitudes and in recent years significantly affected by the variation in power base arising from the social alterations.

3. Put simply, industrial relations are merely human relationships and as such their application will vary very considerably having relation to the personalities of the humans in immediate contact, the social norms of the day and the traditions of the participants. As those relationships have developed in modern western society other factors have impinged upon them which have materially affected the comparatively pure self-interest roles of the original combatants. On one hand to apply some justice and reasonable share to their position and on the other hand to maximise financial return. However, like the organisation of capital, the organisation of labour was quickly seen as a method of constructing a power base and a political weapon of some force in a democracy.

4. The effect of that development has been to impose another discipline within the industrial relations system. That is the development of singular interest political activities. Those activities may be used to promote the welfare of members of the organisation, or the welfare of a political party; or discord. At times there cannot be any doubt the influence has been used to promote international objectives. Since action brings reaction where one political viewpoint attempted to take control of industrial organisations other political viewpoints also moved in.

5. The existence in the labour movement of a wide range of views varying from extremist to conservative cannot be ignored in the development of industrial relations. Under such circumstances, it has been and will be in the future very difficult to obtain on the labour side of industrial relations a single cohesive force only thinking of the welfare of the nation or of only the particular welfare of the workers in the organisation.

6. Exactly the same comments apply to management and to organisations of employers developed as a counterweight to organised labour. In industrial relations there are wide-ranging views amongst the management or capital side. It should not be thought that all management is conservative, but by its nature and the constraints placed on it to satisfy shareholders there is probably more conservative management than management able to adjust quickly and easily to altered social circumstances and power structures. It is as difficult for management to accept the need for change as it is for employee organisations to accept a need for change. However, the degree of conservatism is something that has been changing with the changes in social concepts and with the changes in the power structure of the community.
UNDERSTANDING CHANGE AND VARIATION IN SOCIAL PATTERNS

7. Changes are very difficult for ordinary people in the workforce to understand and accept and unfortunately often extremely difficult for many people in management or supplying capital to understand and accept. For both parties change appears to be nearly always forced on the majority rather than accepted willingly or foreseen and voluntary action taken to ensure its smooth introduction of a smooth transition from a past method to a future method.

8. Notwithstanding that position, as a matter of pure principle for both labour and management industrial relations should always be about the maintenance and, through time, the improvement of real standards of living, conditioned by the social values and economic realities of the day. The latter realities have led to significant changes in the conduct of industrial relations over the past few years. While there has always been an understanding in the Australian union movement of the need for political determination of social wage components, today there is a growing recognition by a significant percentage of the trade union movement of the need to take an interest not just in wages and other direct conditions of employment, but in a range of policies which affect real living standards. The welfare of workers and their families is as much influenced by government taxes and expenditure policies which affect the social wage as it is by direct conditions of employment. While the union movement represents some 2.6 million members, there is awareness that it should concern itself also with the welfare of worker's families-some six million Australians in total.

9. During the past few years there has also been a growing recognition, albeit too slowly, that the current economic realities are not the norms which prevailed in the period of Australia's post-war development-low unemployment and generally low inflation-and that industrial relations need to adapt to this fundamentally different situation.

10. In an interview with the Australian Financial Review, Bill Kelty offers us all a thoughtful personal insight into the experience and lessons of leap-frogging wage negotiations in the 1970s. He referred to a `sense of futility that you chase a wage gain and it's immediately followed by prices'. He tells us that `the unions went through a period of decentralisation, that is, they went through a period of relative self interest. The system broke down during that period. The experience was a sobering one'.

11. Perceptions as to how industrial relations need to adjust differ between those who favour the Prices and Incomes Accord, those who oppose it and those who favour deregulation and decentralisation of the wage determination process. Without, at this point, diminishing the importance of the choice between these different approaches, it is even more important that the need for change to the industrial relations norms of earlier periods has been recognised by some in important positions of influence.

l2. That understanding has been followed by a recognition that a grab by trade unions now for a bigger slice of the economic cake could destroy opportunities for growth because this would result in self-defeating inflation and lost competitiveness in our traded goods and services industries. It is accepted by realists that unless movements in labour costs are in line with economic capacity and growth in productivity the result will be to the detriment of organised labour and Australians generally. An awareness has developed that governments cannot prevent increased unemployment and/or higher inflation in the face of unrestrained cost increases, whether from labour or profiteering.

13. While we have come a long way in developing the concept of community interest in industrial relations, there are contemporary challenges which we must face up to. These require a broader extension and acceptance of the concept of community interest than we have achieved to date. First and foremost, though, meeting these challenges will require greater understanding of the issues involved before appropriate responses can be developed.

14. In looking at these contemporary issues we should focus on the special role which the ACTU must play in carrying responsibility for industrial relations. Being based on a voluntary affiliation, the ACTU has no direct control over the activities of its members but collective rights under its rules and significant underlying strength arising from that. However, in that the trade union movement is committed to collective responsibility, the ACTU also has an obligation to promote the best interests of its members as a whole (consistent with community welfare generally) rather than the special interests of any constituent members. This is especially true when the interests of any one member are involved.

15. In this regard it is relevant that the occupational composition of the workforce is changing and this is reflected within the ACTU. While blue-collar unions traditionally constituted the bulk of the ACTU's affiliates, increasing numbers of white-collar unions have joined the ACTU in recent years. The obvious implication of this is that the ACTU has now to take into account a greater diversity of interests among its members than previously. What seems good for the blue-collar worker may not seem to be for the white-collar worker and vice-versa. What would seem to best serve the interests of private sector employees would not always seem to be beneficial for public sector employees. What may be good for workers in traditional occupations may not be good for their sons and daughters who are seeking employment in new occupations emerging with changes in technology and consumer-spending patterns. The evolving diversity of interests serves to emphasise that the solutions to contemporary problems are unlikely to be found in directly improving the position of individual groups but rather in considering the interests of the whole.

16. The development of that philosophy is the basis for the growing recognition that, in order to overcome the social and economic waste caused by unemployment, restraint in costs is required. However, concern about unemployment has also led to a temptation in some quarters to resist changes which, overall, are desirable but which may damage employment prospects in particular industries. It has also fostered proposals to maintain or increase employment and activity in particular sectors even where this can not be shown to promote employment objectives generally or to increase the size of the national base. The concern of the labour movement about the loss of employment in any industry is only natural. However, the real questions are:
(a) are knee-jerk responses the appropriate ones? and
(b) how should we choose the industrial relations and developments initiatives best suited to the interests of the generality of the community?

17. This paper has adverted to the different social patterns of today as compared with the social patterns that shaped industrial relations in this and other countries in the early part of the century. The significant change in the relative powers of the two major partners to industrial relations is well documented, if not completely understood. It has produced excesses as the previous division of power produced excesses on the part of capital or management. One of the reasons for the difference in social patterns is the different expectation of the people who form the workforce of a country of the Australian nature. The different levels of those expectations over past years and how those levels of expectations are growing, even though in fact the position of the Australian economy is in some ways worse than it was in previous years is important to any understanding of the problem.

18. Those levels of expectation cannot be expected to diminish, having regard to the education now available to people, their ability to gauge what others have, and the greater degree of freedom constructed within the community by a different social welfare system.

19. The interaction of these forces, while not necessarily conclusive, is powerful in shaping the activities of organisations representing that electorate. The growth of the complex social security system-inadequate as it may be in parts, does produce a difference in freedom of choice over that which existed in previous years. One aspect of it alone must give problems to any critical observer attempting to analyse current labour statistics. That is, should a figure of two per cent of the workforce still be considered as representing comparatively full employment or should that figure now be closer to five or even six per cent to take account of the increased number who opt out of the system.
ECONOMIC REALITIES AND CONFLICT

20. Also, whether we like it or not, one of the major matters affecting social change and employment is the enormous difference in world trading patterns occurring over a number of years associated with the rise of Eastern or Far Eastern economies and, in our particular area, Pacific Basin economies and the development of the European Common Market.

21. Once it was said that Australia rode on the sheep's back, and there was a great deal of truth in that cliche. We had an established market for our agrarian products, particularly in the British connection. Later it was said that we rode on the miner's back. The truth of the matter is now that the market for our agrarian products has been substantially affected by, firstly, the emergence of the common market with its agricultural products and policies; and secondly, the fact that Eastern countries after the Vietnam war do have more ability to feed themselves than in the past, while in other parts of the world countries have more need but less ability to buy products.

22. In addition, where once it could be said that nations producing raw materials that were in demand were in a comparatively ``box seat'' position, as there have been developments in Chile, Brazil, India and other nations, including Papua New Guinea, which have ensured a greater availability of raw materials on a world-wide basis together with the development of new materials, the commodity market which includes much of the export of and the new wealth in Australia has come under much greater pressure and that looks like continuing at least for the foreseeable future. Worth a thought is also the effect on world inflation that a reduction in the cost of commodities, in particular oil, has had. In the overall perhaps the effect is beneficial.

23. It is also beyond doubt that the transfer of technology, eliminating in many cases the need for a large tradesman-trained workforce, but increasing the need for some with higher trained skills has arisen from the concept that goods, especially manufactured goods, should be produced where it is most valid for capital to produce goods in order to make the greatest return on capital that is possible. The technology made available in Korea or Brazil is not necessarily arising from Korean finance or Brazilian finance. The mode of manufacture for many countries these days is to design the article in a country such as Sweden or Australia or the US and have it manufactured in Korea or Hong Kong or Taiwan.

24. Capital is pursuing its traditional role, varied by the growth of multinational or supranational companies, varied by technology and social attitudes, varied by response to union power and types of government but still its traditional role. The Australian company locating off shore is matched by many others including Japanese although again tradition ensures that Japan is a much tighter society than most of the other countries in the western bloc.

25. All these forces are impacting on the Australian economy without the advantage of size of the US economy. Even significant reductions in the value of the Australian dollar may not of their own volition answer our international trade problems and so alter the balance of payments position of Australia in the way that we would want it to alter. In a very competitive world trade situation there is evidence that competing nations will not raise prices for their exports to match a drop in the value of Australian currency as against their currency while resistance has been evident to Australian exports gaining the full value of Australian dollar reductions, especially in a depressed commodities market. At the same time we have to be aware of the increased cost of servicing overseas debt created by a depreciated currency.

26. While we persist in not fully appreciating the interrelationships of all the various bits and pieces of our society we will fail to appreciate that monetary policy today almost invariably treats the symptom not the disease. It attempts very imprecisely to correct for the many other failures in the complex which we call our nation. Generally speaking, it can only react to circumstances created for it by organisations not under or in its control, leaving the economy always in a state of fragility and subject to possible extreme problems of high interest rates, inflation and high unemployment.

27. It is true that if Australia could present the position of a secure supplier it could be still in a favourable position. Unfortunately, it has not been able to develop that option to the degree that should have been possible basically because of the operation of a conflict society.

28. The social and economic dynamics just described are pressures reacting generally on the community but as always in an uneven manner and the conflicts these pressures produce are not always in the best interest of Australia. The general concept that Australia cannot afford to be in a position where it is a straight conflict society with a three-way conflict between trade unions, government and business exacerbated by those pressures is a basis for the thinking behind the concept of the Accord.

29. This does not mean to argue that conflict should be eliminated from society. Slippage and friction is as necessary for a healthy society as the right in a democracy to state a view. The problem for Australia is not that there is some conflict of the nature adverted to-it is that there is too much. Conflict arising from a number of causes, valid and invalid, directing the nation into unnecessary crisis at times and into too much attention to the posturing of single interest pressure groups, often to a stage where the ``wood is hidden by the trees''.

30. To achieve the overall best interest of this society the object and the emphasis must be to as far as practicable reduce the area of unnecessary conflict and to replace as far as practicable short-term self-interest thinking with longer-term wide-benefit planning.

31. That approach should not be interpreted as requiring people to be ``hungry today'' so that ``they may eat tomorrow''. That is not required in the Australian context. What is required is to optimise our present and future instead of demeaning it for invalid reasons. The difference is one of degree, even perhaps significant degree, but not a choice between riches or penury.

32. The current Australian example of a social accord is only an agreement between an organised trade union movement and one political party which holds government at this point of time. It does not establish a strongly corporate society in the same way as perhaps a corporate society is established by tradition in the Nordic countries.

33. However, the important point to note is that at least two responsible bodies believe that in the current phase of world development it is not in the interests of the Australian society to continue to develop in the way that it perhaps would if modelled on the English example. It is not really a worthwhile exercise to talk of Australia in respect of the American example. There are too many indications that the conflict mode of the American economy is not necessarily working as against competitive societies developing in the Pacific Basin. Notwithstanding a manufacturing industry backed by a huge military complex, limited union organisation, low labour cost escalation and a low inflation rate. American manufacturing industry seeks more and more protection and their balance of payments situation and growing foreign debt is only rescued in current terms by the amount of foreign investment flowing into what is conceived as a secure base for world money in these troubled times.

34. For us, while there is a significant reduction in the value of the Australian dollar at the same time as there is a resurgence in the economy, that reduction and resurgence is not necessarily producing expansion in Australian industry, particularly manufacturing industry. It is producing an expansion in demand that is being mainly fed by considerable amounts of imports. The imports affect the balance of payment situation. If you attempt to control the imports you may do so by protective means and that protective means can fuel the whole cycle of inefficient industry in competition with outside industry unless there is some new thinking in respect of the mode that we adopt to ensure efficient relationship, one part of the economy to the other.

35. All these pressures are affecting trade protectionism and creating clefts in each society and between societies. The effects of such pressures do not need to be detailed. They are current. They are shown up in both the Australian and American scene. However, they exist in many forms and in many countries no matter what name may be applied to them. The pressure is to sell not to buy except as necessary. To anybody who wants to think in general about the situation, the developments automatically answer the question as to whether or not industrial relations can stand aloof from all the other forces shaping economics. They cannot stand aloof and there must be an understanding that as a society we are not any longer in competition with like societies.

36. We are in fact in competition with societies which are entirely unlike. We are in competition in the world trade sense with societies in manufacturing who do not understand a `them and us situation'. In particular, the Japanese where by tradition there is complete and absolute unity of purpose between the capital and the labour in major manufacturing plants. They are part of the same operation. There is no need to talk about industrial democracy within the Japanese manufacturing scene. No manager in a large plant in Japan would be prepared to separate himself completely and absolutely from his labour. It is a co-operative activity. There is an incentive for the labour force in the well-being of the company. That incentive relates to the traditional method of employment and the traditional responsibilities which exist between the management and the labour. It does not necessarily apply to small companies or family business where other traditions apply.

37. The rise of the eastern manufacturing countries is no longer restricted to countries like Korea, Philippines, Taiwan or Hong Kong. China is busily engaged in setting up its industrial compounds. Russia has made its bargains with Fiat and Coca Cola.

38. If one believes that industrial relations, employment and well-being can hide behind protection barriers in these circumstances then one has to believe in other fallacies such as Father Christmas.

39. If you are in competition with more efficient systems, it is not intelligent nor productive to rely on modes of operation which are no longer applicable to the current situation-if they ever were-and to rely on attitudes which have proved themselves unable to stand up to these standards of competition.
40. That comment in particular applies to those who parrot support for and the adoption of the American type of conflict operation and the political input of protection-oriented pressures groups.

41. However, we do have to learn how to adjust to the current pressures. We do need to urgently apply our minds to seek solutions, not just as representatives of labour nor as representatives of capital, but merely as representatives of a society seeking the greatest possible advantage for the members of that society by transferring self-interest from what is the apparent need of the individual or single organisation to the overall need of the society in which we live.

42. Is it in our overall interest to transfer our manufacturing industry into entrepreneurial importers? Do we need to realise that if capital cannot make profit out of manufacturing regardless of what activity is undertaken by governments or other people, they will gradually move into the entrepreneurial importer situation?
43. Is it sufficient to create pockets of resistance to that merely by supporting particular segments of industry in such a way that they exist on the public purse?

44. If we, by that method, create inefficient operations do we at the same time reduce the overall standard of living of the community by requiring more and more money to be paid in taxes to support what are in fact ineffectual operations? Are we encouraging the development of systems very similar in operation to the development of the dairy subsidy system where it became profitable to farm land which was quite unsuitable for dairy farming merely based on the fact that a farmer could live off the subsidy? Is the same thing true of industry and must it be recognised that no matter what you do in respect of the provision of protection, whether it be by tariffs or bounties, you do have a charge on the public purse?

45. Consideration of these questions is not to argue in any way that you do away with all the tariffs and all the bounties and all the support for various phases of Australian manufacturing or other industry. Obviously we do not live in a perfect world. In fact, we live in a far from perfect world and there will be a continuing need for government to ensure that our producers are fairly positioned in their markets.

46. What must be accepted is that if we are to have such systems they must all be based on a non-ongoing situation designed only as a method of creating an efficient operation and a society able to recognise what it must do to compete on a reasonable basis. For that reason, and in addition to other practical steps, it is necessary to develop the concept of positive incentives and a positive sharing of responsibility at an enterprise and/or industry level, or in common with like societies become increasingly irrelevant as not only capital but expertise shift to a different world.

47. There are problems for any group of people or an organisation in adjusting their mind quickly to current pressures let alone long term thinking, especially where those pressures are of the type now existing in relation to the developments in international trade, the rise of different economies working on a different basis. There are real problems in adjusting traditional modes of thought where those traditions have grown up over a century and where traditionalists have traditional self-interest answers to non-traditional problems.

48. However, there is at least a growing concept of the difference and the need to change, but that is not necessarily a concept that is clearly understood by everybody except in those instances where direct pressure is coming on the individual or the organisation. Answers may be coloured by background and electorate or may be less applicable to people who operate on a more adventurous basis or on a purely ambitious basis for their own ends. Yet if we are to progress in this country, if we are to shake ourselves out of our apathy and reach our optimum potential, we will have to look at world developments without prejudice. We will have to learn from those developments and quickly see what we can do to change the thinking of people and organisations to a realistic appreciation of those developments.
SECTIONAL INTEREST AND NATIONAL INTEREST

49. The question is how do we develop such a philosophy? How do we develop a philosophy of looking at the overall national welfare and at the same time understand clearly that the most important motivating force amongst any group is always self-interest?

50. If the last comment is true then what is required is to change the thinking of people by exposing more and more groups to the advantages inherent in a change of thinking. In other words, it is necessary to keep educating portions of the community to an understanding of the advantages of the material gains inherent in a more co-operative productive society.
51. There are illustrations current which may assist in this, providing again you can identify and obtain understanding amongst the people as to what pressures are producing the current changes.

52. There are operating examples of an alternative philosophy based on the concept of producing a co-operative workforce with a stake in the well-being of the enterprise. They exist in a number of areas which in many cases and for many reasons are ignored.

53. The example of Lincoln Electric is there for all to see. Not that anyone from the trade union movement is ever likely to laud in particular the Lincoln Electric example because it does not fit itself into the organised labour movement as do other examples. However, the example of Lend Lease building operations is there for all to see as is Fletcher Jones and Staff and numerous others.

54. They are not ordinary work incentive or contract bonus or production bonus schemes which have many flaws and anyway in most cases do not give the employee necessarily a stake in the welfare of the company over and above their employment stake. They are operations which do provide for all employees a real stake in the competitiveness of the company and its overall viability by one means or another.

55. Having relation to the demands of human nature, that advantage has got to be seen in terms of reward, whether by money, by conditions, by security or by some other means. The workforce has got to see that it is in fact sharing in the welfare of the organisation.

56. It doesn't take too much imagination in respect of any undertaking to work out that if you could improve productivity by any percentage then that almost certainly equates a reduction in the cost of the article by a similar amount and in most industries or enterprises it would not be difficult to produce significant results. It should be understood that an Australian worker does not get greater pay than his German/Japanese or American counterpart, in most cases he gets less and total labour costs per employee are generally less, but it is in the bottom line figure at the end of the day as to productive cost that shows the difference in result per dollar.

57. Since Australian workers can compare with the workers of any country, it might surprise just how much productivity could be improved if the workforce understood that the increase in productivity was going to result in an increase in their security or reward while not prejudicing their safety or principles.

58. One would like to think that we had progressed sufficiently as human beings to not require such incentives but the truth of the matter is of course that if there is no incentive there is in fact unlikely to be maximum productivity. To be effective, capital and management would clearly have to come to an understanding that all increased production did not go merely in profits to shareholders or to management and that is something that many managements and shareholders do not clearly understand.

59. They merely look at their enterprise on the basis of how much additional profit can go to the management or the shareholders without seeing that, if there is no sharing, if there is no feeling of sharing, that what they are doing is to lose out for the undertaking as a whole.

60. Successful examples of this concept, if they can grow, will be important and it may be the only way that it is possible for such a system to grow is by a gradual realisation of its advantages, with that gradual realisation probably only coming on the basis of examples growing in numbers. There is amongst some management an understanding of the value of this approach. Such a concept will work better with smaller labour forces and it will obviously work better on an enterprise basis than it will work on the industry-wide basis.
THE HANCOCK REVIEW

61. It is necessary here to advert to the deliberations of the Committee of Review into Industrial Relations Laws and Systems in Australia, commonly known as the Hancock Committee. Because what is being said here could be interpreted by some as a difference to the findings of that committee. The findings were basically that due to the legal position in Australia, the basis provided by the Constitution, and the majority requirements of our society it is not possible to do away with the Arbitration System which exists in Australia and that the best interests of the country would be served by a retention of such a system modified and improved to make it more workable.
62. It is easy to show that what is contained in this concept is complimentary to those findings, not opposite to them.

63. The question which needs to be addressed is does such a system envisage an end to an arbitration system. Whether voluntary or compulsory. The answer is that it does not. Such a system can only operate in relation to the areas where it is a workable proposition. Not everybody can be included in a shareholder scheme or a profit sharing or other similar scheme. Not every organisation or enterprise is open to such a concept. For example, it would be very difficult to see how such a concept should be applied to government service. In some industries other types of schemes already operate successfully and no-one will want to interfere with a successful operation. The concept would be particularly valuable for undertakings with growth, competitive and profit potential. Whatever plan is applied, it should be a system that will operate side by side with or in partnership with an arbitration system. It should not impose a necessity on governments, whether Federal or State, to alter current systems. The Hancock Committee, in one proposal, suggested that the Federal Act should be amended to provide where a Section 10 agreement was concluded that it would have the same importance as a Federal award. In other words, as different from the past, it could not be overwritten by a State determination or a state common rule determination. However, this concept does not depend on that approach since any economic benefits flowing from an arrangement envisaged here would be outside any award and as such would not provide ammunition for comparative wage justice or any other award prescription or application. It also does not necessarily need to be adopted industry-wide. It can in fact operate on a purely enterprise basis without affecting awards.
UNION ORGANISATION
64. That does not mean that you need to change the whole union system to enterprise unions.

65. What it means is, if you take the manufacturing industry for an example, that where you wanted to change what is the current conflict situation to a situation more in line with the Japanese co-operative society, it would be possible to have an agreement between the management and the labour force of an enterprise which produced basic considerations in respect of conditions but which at the same time added a positive incentive drawing the labour force into the operation of the enterprise. Such agreements are limited only by imagination and practicality.

66. This also provides an alternative to the current concepts of participatory democracy in industry. At the moment the proposals on participatory democracy have more objective application in, say, a public service situation than an industry situation. Much theory is expounded about this. It is beloved by those who expect to change reality into responsibility. Who believe or say they believe that, given the chance to be party to decision-making, employees will be happy.

67. In practice there is much more likelihood of producing a co-operative position between the management and labour at an enterprise or industry level based on the construction of a positive incentive, when participants can see pecuniary gain or greater security of employment and of that spinning off into real participation thus constructing participatory democracy within the organisation.

68. It's a position of decision-sharing which eliminates much of the false nature of narrow demands for representatives on boards of management, etc. A positive incentive that means that employees see a self-interest advantage in the welfare of the industry or undertaking as a whole and as helping to provide a long term future.

69. As the concept put in the preceding paragraphs should not be interpreted as suggesting that you develop enterprise unions, it also does not mean that you exclude organised trade unions from its operation. In fact, if you were to take the example of Lend Lease, that is the last thing you would want to do. Part of any education process will be to take organisations on an industry-wide basis along with the concept. There is finally no problem for trade unions in such an approach where there can be enormous advantage for the community as a whole.
REALISTIC EFFICIENCY

70.
