If you can produce the standard of efficiency required from that type of organisation it means naturally that you do not have to protect industries in the same way and to the same degree that they are protected today. It doesn't mean that you do not necessarily have to provide some community incentives for industry or some protection. For example, if the steel industry plan, even with its attendant costs, can be shown to have done something at all it would be that it constructed, at least in many areas, a new feeling of co-operation between labour forces and management resulting in very large increases in productivity and, I repeat, it is those large increases in productivity that can protect the industry as a whole. The concept should not be seen as the `cure-all' for all problems of industry. It can assist quality of production, productivity and costs. It cannot replace entrepreneurial skill, it cannot replace product. It cannot insulate Australia from the vagaries of international trade. It cannot insulate Australia from overseas competition intensifying in a period of world recession. It cannot, by itself, overcome operations such as the Common Market Agricultural Policy. It does not mean that an Australian government should abandon efforts to change other governments' policies which limit the opportunity for growth in our industries or that governments should abandon their overall responsibilities to industry and employment.

71. It will not make a `silk purse' out of a `sow's ear' except where the potential for that exists. It will not make bad ideas good and under no circumstances should it lead a government to support with public money industries or enterprises that should not economically exist merely to satisfy lobbying by self-interest groups.

72. However, if such a philosophy could be gradually spread throughout the community it would start to provide a different attitude within the community; a greater realisation of where the country needed to go, what it needed to do in order to protect itself and yet at the same time it would provide the rewards to the individuals putting their effort into the concept.

73. Declining employment opportunities in areas of manufacturing industry have led to proposals by sections of the union movement in respect of that industry. Again, the challenge facing the ACTU is to evaluate whether these proposals further the interests of the whole community or merely benefit special interest groups.

74. Industrial relations cannot be conducted in isolation from the realities of a changing international trading environment. In 1983 Bill Kelty spoke of the implications of this in the context of prices and incomes policies. He argued that to be effective prices and incomes policies ``will require a trade union movement which has a perspective beyond tomorrow-a perspective which is long-term in its vision and can understand the nature of the world economy in which we live. The basic impact will be that unions will no longer be able to hide behind industrial tribunals: as a trade union movement you have got to be involved, you have got to take responsibility''.

75. Activity which promotes the national interest in no way inhibits a profitable return to the individual. In fact, entrepreneurial skill that increases the overall wealth of the community spins back into general advantages for the community as a whole. If, for example, a particular enterprise was doing particularly well, its ability to employ a greater number of people is greater; its ability to spend on investment is greater and, therefore, the spin-off for the general community regarding the amount of money its workers spend, the amount of money it pushes into the community, is obviously much greater.

76. In a period when all manufacturing industry is under pressure, a successful manufacturing industry-one which is able to compete in the international export market in particular-is obviously a great advantage to the Australian community. The fact that the workers working for an enterprise or the executive staff of an enterprise are doing slightly better or even much better in financial or other return than the general norm does not mean that it is not working to the general advantage of the community. It is in this field that a rigid concept of comparative wage justice can do harm.

77. In the practical sense it is not possible to divorce the community from the tradition of comparative wage justice, even though many examples can be seen where it works against the general interest of the community.

78. However, if the concept of comparative wage justice is enshrined, whether that is good or bad it is surely possible to accept that where the success of an enterprise comes from the efforts of the individuals making up the total of that enterprise that special rewards may come to those individuals making the enterprise more successful in such a way as to eliminate the problems of comparative wage justice through some form of profit sharing.

79. Again, there is nothing in that philosophy which in any way affects the national welfare, except in a good way. What would affect the national welfare is somebody taking a profitable enterprise and destroying its capability by seeking singular profits to the individuals, or money from the public purse not used in a constructive form for the welfare of the country.

80. It is not difficult to see a position whereby any industry, whether it be mining, agricultural or manufacturing, being improved by a co-operative spirit between management and labour. That co-operative spirit, however, will never be possible under a system whereby the returns to the individuals are restricted by any rigid system, whether that be a rigid arbitration system, a rigid concept of comparative wage justice or a rigid domination by either one of the parties which means that the profits from the enterprise are not distributed in such a way as to provide a positive incentive to produce.

81. Why is it necessary to build in a method of `overcoming rigidities?' It is quite clear that in any complex society such as ours a rigidity which prevents a reward for special endeavour will inevitably mean that there is generally no special endeavour. Very few sections of the overall population are so imbued with their responsibility to the community generally that they will produce special effort for no reward. That is shown in instance after instance in industry. If a method of overcoming that rigidity can be developed which does not affect the overall community except in a good way, that is by introducing more endeavour and more wealth, then it is in the overall interest of the community to allow that flexibility and to eschew the rigidity that prevents the flexibility from developing.

82. There are all sorts of programs around now; mooted by various people and organisations aimed at producing the type of result that I speak of. As almost nothing in the world is new, most of these are not new as profit sharing is not new. Without making any judgment about individual programs because each would need tailoring to the particular requirement of the parties, it is enough to say that to produce optimum results the total workforce or near enough thereto has to feel their involvement and advantage.
THE PROVISION OF A COMMON INTEREST

83. Another major aspect of Australian industrial relations requires consideration. In the Australian arbitration system and as a result of the multiplicity of unions there will often be a conflict of interest between the persons who form, even from the union side, a council of participatory democracy. That in itself is enough to destroy its operation and often the viability of an enterprise because there is no common thread running through relationships which would give all participants an incentive to make it work.

84. In providing a positive incentive it is also necessary to provide a common thread to unite a process worker, tradesman, middle line executive, and a top line executive to work in the interest of the enterprise or industry.

85. Having regard to human nature, that common thread can only be a return to the employees which improves their financial return and their sense of security-which improves their willingness to work in the best interest of the enterprise and which provides for them and their family an improvement in their standards of living.

86. If such a thing can be provided then that will produce the common advantage necessary to mould many diverse elements together to work in the general interest of the enterprise. At that point of time the overall well-being of that enterprise must spin-off to produce improved conditions for the community as a whole.

87. How do you provide that common thread? How do you provide the common interest? The basis for long term trust works not on the principle of producing miracles in a short time but of grafting away at a problem until the problem no longer exists and the unit is working as a whole. It accepts that you cannot convince people to change in two or three minutes, or two or three weeks, or two or three years and maybe that it takes longer than that. It also accepts the fact that all the improvements in profitability, productivity and other spin-offs within an enterprise and industry should not go merely to the management or the shareholders but the improvements in productivity etc. should be shared amongst those all working to improve it. It deals with that in a multiplicity of ways. It will involve flexibility in thinking about appropriate forms of agreement acceptable to participants. It should not offer shares to be bought by only individuals who can afford them. It may provide bonus shares allocated to all employees no matter in what position. Alternatively, another form of positive incentive may be preferred but always it must be based on improved productivity and profitability.

88. It offers not only advantages for the workers employed, whether they be labourer, executives, etc. It takes in activities for their families and so binds them within the organisation and its future.

89. If you can produce such a circumstance from enterprise to enterprise it will no longer be sufficient for idealogues of either side to merely say that this is a conflict society because the one thing that no idealogue or any body else can ever overcome is a feeling of being part of, being fairly treated, and seeing the advantage of the enterprise also meaning an advantage to the individual.
90. It means that people within an enterprise do not have to hide behind or grow fat on the public purse; that they are out acting in an entrepreneurial way to improve their own undertaking.

91. It also means that once everybody in the undertaking has a stake in it, no longer can poor management exist easily because they are under constant pressure from all sections of the workforce employed. If people at the lower level see very poor management at the top creating problems for their security, their returns, they will be taking some form of action in order to bring that incompetence out into the light of day.

92. It's as necessary in the interests of the health of enterprises and industry to bring middle management and top management incompetence into the open as it is to bring into the open any lack of productivity on the part of the workforce.

93. It is not difficult to see that coupled with the current reduction in the value of the Australian dollar what a significant increase in the productivity of many industries would do. A restoration of confidence in our future in world trade may be more important than any other aspect.

94. This does not mean to argue that all enterprises can suddenly become world-wide competitive operations as a result of any such system. Obviously that could never be, but it would begin replacing what after all is in many cases a completely negative incentive within the Australian system with a positive incentive and bringing management and labour more closely together. It can produce a much more co-operative society.

95. There are examples of corporate societies which have done well but corporate societies are not necessarily co-operative societies. That doesn't mean to say that merely saying it's a corporate society or a co-operative society means that it will do well. It will take effort and conviction.

96. It does not mean applying to Australia the systems and customs of Japan or any other country. It would mean taking some of the advantages of relationships in those countries and if that is done whilst it doesn't mean one hundred per cent success it does not have to.

97. Such an operation can stand on its own feet in regard to any single enterprise or industry. The fact that one or two start off and show example by leadership may result in spin-off if other people see advantage arising from an effort.

98. There is one other aspect of sharing instead of ``them and us'' that is worth adverting to. If there is a co-operative spirit in an enterprise, if there is in fact a position where the people even down on the lowest level see the profitability of the enterprise resulting in increased affluence, better conditions, greater security, not only is there a likelihood of productivity increasing, but there is also a more responsible approach to the question of the use of power, the use of materials, the use of tools and a more responsible attitude to the use of machinery resulting in substantial savings on maintenance and damage.

99. Once workers know that their return at the end of that year may be affected by their failure to look after those cost areas, it doesn't become then a matter of merely asking for the individual to be responsible. It becomes a question of frittering away their own financial return because of irresponsibility. That would be a powerful inhibition against individual irresponsibility and no doubt group pressure would be applied to any individual to bring them into line. The group pressure coming from others seeing their material well-being being affected by any such irresponsibility.
THE ROLE OF TRADE UNIONS

100. From the point of view of the trade union movement, does such a sharing spirit within an enterprise mean a lesser or greater role for organised labour? If one took the recent dispute in the Northern Territory between the Mudginberri Abattoirs and the Meatworkers' Union, one would have to conclude that it means a lesser role. However, maybe with a wider and more sympathetic understanding of the critical issues involved by the union leadership that position could be reversed.

101. There is no doubt that a great many trade union leaders with a bias to one particular ideology or with a view of the world shaped by their experiences would be resistant to any concept of sharing with capital as completely foreign to their beliefs.

102. There will also be resistance in many minds to deliberate action to prop up the current political system and there is no doubt that many criticisms can be levelled at the Westminster system of Parliamentary Democracy. Unfair, bumbling, inefficient, unstable. But what other systems have shown themselves in the long run to be better, more efficient, more fair? The answer is none. So it is wise to stay with what is shown as best and prop it up by improving it.
103. The latter viewpoint probably best describes the majority view of the trade union movement.

104. Therefore, it would be clearly desirable, rather than trying to divorce such a concept from unions, to really get unions involved in the concept by bringing them in, by not ignoring them, by in fact seeking in many cases if not their overall approval at least their tacit approval.

105. If that were possible, and the Lend Lease example shows that it is a possibility, then again that creates a measure of co-operation not generally apparent in this country. If on the other hand people believe, or organisations believe, that they can ignore the totality of the trade union movement and proceed with such a plan then the plan will take much longer to come to fruition and be much less certain and fraught with many obstacles. The object must not be to create suspicion and distrust but rather the opposite-to create trust and co-operation.
CONCLUSIONS

106. Finally, it must be again emphasised that spin-offs will occur with every successful example. It does not mean that totality needs to be reached or has to be reached within any declared time. It also means that there are other ways to produce increased return for those industries which are successful whilst at the same time not interfering with the tradition of comparative wage justice nor allowing that concept to create precedents for increases to people in straight wages in industries which are not doing so well or who have not successfully applied the concept.

107. The fact that the concept outlined here does not receive sufficient support to effectively change the course of Australian industry or industrial relations poses no disaster scenario. Persons who pose disaster scenarios or for that matter utopian scenarios are at odds with the process of events.

108. Australian living standards or industry will not suddenly collapse. Accumulated wealth does not so suddenly disappear. Pressure of events both social and economic will force change anyway, albeit over a longer time and with more pain. The ``talked up'' resources boom didn't mean, when it did not completely emerge, a collapse of Australia's commodity market. It meant we sold less than we thought at lower prices.

109. However, we cannot rely on policies and activities relevant to yesterday to answer today's problems. A failure to face up to and answer the challenges inherent in current world changes means a continuation of our present gentle slide and a failure to realise anything like our true potential and therefore the true possible economic return to our people.

110. If we are to as successfully as possible answer the challenges inherent in a flexible, changing world-challenges of technology, stable government, productive life-we will need to harness the full potential of our community. To not do so will not produce disaster, merely mediocrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion before us today is an important matter. It certainly deserves the support of the Australian Democrats but once again they appear to have sold their souls to a socialist government, further confirming their continuing shift to the Left in Australian politics. I know that Senator Button would also like to support the motion but he, too, is captive to blinkered colleagues who continually override his better judgment. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion that we are debating today refers to the need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax and then goes on to propound that this will affect jobs in the car industry. Before I address that, perhaps I should give in to an indulgence and answer a point raised by Senator Short when he quoted from a paper by Charlie Fitzgibbon, the former Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, and said that this came close to the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia on industrial relations. I would be greatly amazed if it comes close to anything that the Liberal Party espouses in industrial relations for the very simple reason that no one in the Liberal Party knows what its industrial relations policy is. It depends on which faction of the Liberal Party one happens to talk to or which leadership aspirant one happens to speak to as to the philosophy espoused. All of the policies are confused and most are contradictory and many members do not know what they are supposed to mean in practice. So let us get it on record from the beginning that, whatever it is that the Liberal Party can be proud of, it cannot be proud of its industrial relations policy because one does not exist and no coherent expression of it can be found anywhere in any policy document of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: That is perhaps not a bad point at which to start in debate on this urgency motion about a fringe benefits tax. What this motion has is the sleazy image of the hot shot back lot second-hand car dealer. It is the sort of motion put forward by people from whom one would not buy a second hand car. Indeed, it has all of Arfur's shonkiness and none of his charm. The proposition is such that, if the Liberals offered it to Arfur of Minder fame, he would not touch it with a bargepole. It is sleazy in the sense that in part of it there are grains of truth but what it then does is to take those grains of truth exaggerate them out of all proportion, disinform and over-blow the rhetoric to present a false and artificial picture and then expect people to believe it. But it is just not true in that sense. The best way to unpick the mystifying rhetoric and the misleading arguments of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) is to go back to what is in fact the case.

When we came into government we inherited a tax system in this country which was haemorrhaging dramatically. People subject to pay as you earn income tax were shouldering the major burden of all revenue payments to the Government. Other forms of taxation were minimal. We came in to government when there was massive tax avoidance and evasion, with rampant bottom of the harbour machinations and a number of other matters that are well known in the public mind. That is what we inherited. We set about trying to rectify that situation with great courage and with great determination-something that the Liberal Party in all of the years that it has been in government in this country failed to do. We set about it logically, through a discussion paper, through a taxation summit conference and through widespread consultation in the community. We have now come down to legislating on the basis of those recommended changes.

At this point let me nail a few of the well known furphies that are propagated by the Opposition. I see that Senator Tate is nodding; he is familiar with these furphies. The first furphy was a furphy from Senator Short about Australia being a high taxing country. The fact is that Australia is not a high taxing country if one compares it with the group economies in the world that are similar to ours. If one compares the Australian economy with the economies of the 23 countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Australia ranks nineteenth in the level of taxation. Only four countries in our comparable economic group in the world have a lower level of tax. Let us nail this constant furphy, that this is a high taxing country, that comes from the Opposition benches whose members carp and criticise but never contribute a constructive idea.

Let us also nail another of those furphies. Despite all the criticisms that come to us, nary a skerrick of a package of comprehensive tax reform emanates from the Opposition benches. The Opposition has lost its courage. It has decided to pick on the difficult taxes that any government has to impose to raise revenue and to criticise those. Then, when we cut outlays to compensate, it criticises because the Government is not subsidising, paying out enough or doing whatever else is needed to prop up the economy in certain areas. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. If the tax system is to be reformed, there will be some things in the package that people do not like. Is the overall symmetry of the package addressing the two fundamental questions of equity, that is, is it fair and is it efficient? Does it close off the rorts and loopholes? That is what this package does, so let us not have this carping, non-productive criticism. With those words, I will now go back to what is a fundamental problem in this whole issue. I will quote from the Income Tax Assessment Act. Section 26 of the Act states:
The assessable income of a taxpayer shall include-

(e) the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted to him in respect of, or for or in relation directly or indirectly to, any employment of or services rendered by him, whether so allowed, given or granted in money, goods . . .

The point is that, through all of the years of Liberal Party government in this country, that provision was in the Income Tax Assessment Act. All of those people who received benefit in kind in their employment and did not pay tax on it were rorting the system. For all of that time the Liberal Party did nothing about closing off those rorts. It did not collect taxes that were due. Because it did not bother to collect those taxes, one of the key reforms that we had to address when we came into power was to close off those rorts, in the name of fairness and equity, so that some taxpayers who held privileged positions in the economy were not advantaged to the disadvantage of the poor and underprivileged in the economy. Some were able to manipulate their tax returns to minimise their income. It is because the Opposition when in government never did anything to close that loophole that we now have to wrestle with it. It is strange that the Opposition should question what we are doing in trying to make taxes equitable and fair. Of course, the Opposition is happy to see the burden of tax borne by PAYE taxpayers rather than by any other source in the economy. It is quite happy to see that load increase. I just want to remind the Opposition that since we have been in government we have provided some tax cuts to relieve the burden that built up during that period.

I turn to the substance of this urgency motion. As I do so, I note that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has well and truly put Opposition members to flight over all the doomsaying and prophesying in which they have engaged on the subject of the fringe benefits tax in the hospitality industry. Despite the scaremongering tactics run by the Opposition about the hospitality industry, the truth is that it is a strong employment industry. In the labour market the shortage of skilled workers has shown up in that industry. There is a demand for employment in that industry rather than what the Opposition members were forecasting a year ago.

It is not surprising that, as we come close to the date on which that taxation legislation will become law, scaremongering on this issue has arisen. I want to deal with it first of all by referring not to what Australian Labor Party spokesmen might say but by referring to spokesmen in the community who do not have a vested interest in this industry but who are commentators on the general state of the economy; I refer to those who are in a position of at least offering some dispassionate observations. The general commentary is that what we are now hearing from industry spokesman-this is epitomised in the outpourings of members of the Opposition-is a high blown rhetoric which overexaggerates the issue. If honourable senators are in any doubt about that they can turn to the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 December and read the Ross Gittins article entitled `A car-industry deal we can do without'. That article nails absolutely the misrepresentation and misinformation that abounds about the state of the industry. Perhaps that is endemic in an industry facing some form of reform.

However, the Government has been careful to try to weigh in the balance the impact of economic performance of a tax which addresses equity. The original proposals put forward by the Government in the first instance have been modified with respect to this industry to take account of some of the objections raised by it. While we have taken account of those objections we are now hard up against the question of whether, by taking any further account of what the industry is saying, we would be trespassing against the basic principles of equity and fairness which now must become our priority.

Let me talk about some of the exaggerations. One of the exaggerations is in the claim that sales are slowing down. It is true that sales are slowing down, but they are not slowing down to the extent to which industry spokesmen are pretending that they are slowing down. Even today an article in the Chanticleer column of the Australian Financial Review has this to say about sales in the car industry:

It is difficult to judge just how real the industry's claims are because, while fleet sales are down 20 per cent this year and total first quarter retail sales are down 47,000 on the previous period last year, a drop was expected this year anyway.

The industry pushed sales hard last year ahead of the expected slowdown in the first six months this year because of lower economic growth, the introduction of lead free petrol and the fringe benefits tax.
The article goes on to say:
A recent survey by Howard Belcher and Associates on fleet leasing has found no evidence that fleet size will drop significantly this year-so it depends on which figures you look at.

I am not arguing that sales are not down; I am saying that there are good reasons why sales are down. The industry pushed forward to last year sales that would normally have occurred this year. It did this by successfully convincing a number of consumers that prices would be higher this year and they should buy now. There was some legitimate basis for claiming there would be price rises, but not price rises of the magnitude of those being projected by industry spokesmen at present.

Let us look at some of the price rises that have been referred to by industry spokesmen; firstly, the wholesale sales tax changes. Of course, we do not regret modifying the wholesale sales tax changes. The Auditor-General's report indicated that wholesale sales tax was a key area for ripping off the economy and, therefore, it ought to be changed to ensure that it was properly collected. So we do not apologise for that. The second area concerns lead free petrol, or the catalytic converters that have had to be fixed to cars from 1 January this year, which has added 4 per cent to the cost of motor vehicles. Of course, that was a Liberal-National Party coalition Government initiative and we are stuck with it. This initiative is by courtesy of the former Government, thanks very much, and now honourable senators opposite are complaining about it. The other area is the fallen value of the Australian dollar, which has had an impact on prices. Of course, no one on the Opposition side-certainly no one I have heard-has said that he or she supports the value of the Australian dollar remaining at the level it was at in the period of the former Government. One of the side benefits of the fall is that there may now be an export market for component manufacturers in Australia that there was not before.

There are a number of other aspects about prices, but the essential thing about prices is that last year there was record trading. This year there will not be as many sales; we will be back to a level marginally above the level of sales in the Fraser Government era. So we are still doing better than the former Government did. Indeed, vehicle manufacturers will now make some adjustment to their profit margins to accommodate keeping prices at a level which the market can stand. Prices will not rise to the extent that is being forecast. As Ross Gittins says in the article to which I referred earlier:

And don't forget that there are prices and prices. A company which pushes its recommended retail price to a level which proves uncompetitive can quickly make amends with factory discounts and all the rest of it. The games those guys play, you wouldn't put it past them to deliberately put the price up and discount it back.

Everyone who has ever bought a car knows that one can negotiate a tremendous number of offsets to the so-called retail price. If members of the Opposition are saying that the real retail price is the price that is being quoted they are saying it without any credibility.

Finally, the tax impost itself is widely misrepresented. The Government has changed the way in which the system can be structured and there are two ways in which one can claim some advantage. There will indeed be write-offs-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support strongly the urgency motion which has been proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, on this most important matter affecting the car industry and other industries in Australia. We have just heard Senator Cook claim that the Opposition is somewhat overblowing this issue. Of course some of his own thinking has to be involved there because, quite clearly, he does not understand the depth of the problems which the motor car industry is now facing. At least Senator Button was honest in admitting that the industry faced a substantial downturn. Already, in the first three months of this year, the market for motor vehicles is down by about 27 per cent compared with that for the previous year. So irrespective of what industry sources are claiming for the rest of the financial year, which is of the order of 90,000 fewer vehicles this year, the figures are showing that that downtrend is already occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for Senator Cook to stand in this chamber and tell us that the reason the prices for vehicles have risen has nothing to do with the fringe benefits tax but it has all to do with things such as unleaded petrol, the devaluation of the dollar, interest rates and increased sales tax. None of us wants to see sales tax rip-offs. None of us wants to see high interest rates or devaluation causing such inflationary effects. The point has to be made that the Government is in control of policy in regard to the motor vehicle industry. Its policy is to impose further costs on the industry, other than those that are already occurring, by the imposition of a fringe benefits tax. The point that has to be acknowledged is that this Government is making things harder, not easier, for the car industry at a time when it is facing difficulties.

Apparently the Government's thinking applies not only to the motor vehicle industry but also to the problems of the resource industries. Senator Chaney has already referred to the problems of the Western Mining Corporation at Kambalda, where it has already sacked 200 workers, as a result admittedly, not only of the fringe benefits tax but also of falling nickel prices and so on. The point has to be made again that nickel prices are falling, so why does the Government choose this moment to impose a further tax on that industry, causing more and more unemployment? Surely that is the height of stupidity and it just points to the depth of the lack of control and policy direction of this Government.

Let us just consider for a moment the size of the motor vehicle industry in Australia. It is true that, quite apart from the dealerships all over this country, motor vehicle manufacturers and their component suppliers employ some 67,000 people. If we apply a multiplier that probably would mean that something like half a million people are directly reliant on that industry in this country. Over $1.1 billion in wages is paid to employees and their families in that industry. All this means is that it is a very substantial industry, particularly in my State of South Australia. Industry and union sources show-Senator Foreman, from my State, would be able to confirm this-that if the trends that are showing up at the moment continue we will see a fall of some 4,500 people in employment in South Australia. That has been demonstrated not only by industry sources and the unions but also by the Labor Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon. He recently faced an election with a whole lot of counterfeit promises but now he is forced to come to Canberra cap in hand to make treaty with the Federal Government to ensure that it reduces the impact of the fringe benefits tax.

Those things are the critical factors in determining where the motor vehicle industry is going. We rely not only on that kind of statistical information; the fact is that when we look at the revenue implications of the new fringe benefits tax we wonder what really is in the Government's mind when it introduces such a tax. Honourable senators might recall that when the tax package was announced last September it was said that the new fringe benefits tax would bring in a further $350m of revenue for the Government. This was to be one of the key factors in ensuring that people got tax cuts in 1986 and 1987. But when we take into account the fact that there will be a substantial drop in the sale of motor vehicles, fuel and motor vehicle parts, that there will be a drop in sales tax on vehicles sold of some $82m, that fuel tax will drop by $28m, that there will be a loss of duty on imported vehicles of some $15m and so on, we find that the total of all taxes which will be lost as a result of the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and the impact on the motor vehicle industry will be $300m of that $350m that the Government claimed it would raise. In other words, a net amount of some $50m will be left after all this pain, all this unemployment and all this strife for people in South Australia and other parts of the Commonwealth who are employed in the motor vehicle industry. What is this Government really on about? I can only agree with the statement in the Adelaide News yesterday by a Mr Ken Eustice, a major motor vehicle dealer in the State of South Australia, that the car tax is insane. Of course it is insane, or perhaps the Government is insane for trying to impose that kind of nonsensical tax on the Australian people.

What are the effects on employment? We have been over those quite a number of times already. What is the Government's concern about unemployment as a result of changes in the industry? Apparently Mr Keating has little concern for this because in the House of Representatives on 16 October 1985, in answer to a question from a South Australian member, he said:

The implication in the question is that the Government should do an employment impact study on every change in the tax system. That is an absurd proposal. I would be in here all the time revealing the Government's assessment of employment impacts for a myriad of tax changes which affect various industries.

That is what this Government is concerned about. Obviously it is not at all concerned about the employment effects of raising new taxes, and the fringe benefits tax is an employment-destroying tax. As a result it will destroy jobs not only in the car industry in South Australia but also in the mining industry and other industries right across the country. That is perhaps where we ought to take a lesson from this Government.

Surely it ought to be noted now that this Government reacts only when facing a severe crisis. Take the example of the housing industry only a day or two ago when it finally woke up to the fact that its high interest rate policy, which was destroying the housing industry and, of course, destroying the opportunities of young couples to buy homes, was actually destroying jobs. This magnificent Government of ours finally discovered that some 50,000 workers in the building industry would lose their jobs as a result of high interest rates. It reacted overnight with a Keatingesque response which produced a new program for the subsidisation of interest rates through the banking system. This is the way this Government reacts. It reacts only under extreme pressure and duress, at the last moment.

Perhaps we have to place the Government under such pressure to bring some sense to it. That is what the Opposition is seeking to do at present. In the last few days the Adelaide News has been running editorials on this very matter and has been putting pressure on Federal Labor members of parliament, including Senator Foreman from South Australia, to face up to their responsibilities to the State and come out and oppose the Government's taxation measures. That is what the honourable senator should be doing. That is what all South Australian Labor senators should be doing. They should be standing up for their State instead of supinely lying down in front of the Keating juggernaut.

That is where we stand at the moment in relation to the employment question. Surely this pressure has to be placed on the Government by the Opposition and by the people of Australia. We have chosen this day to put a matter of urgency before the Senate in order to put more and more pressure on this Government so that it will change its disastrous policies, withdraw its fringe benefits tax and give life to the car industry and other industries in Australia. The fringe benefits tax does not impact just on motor vehicles; it impacts on resources, on the small businessman as well as the large businessman, on the farmers and on any number of small town industries right across the Commonwealth. That is the impact of this Government's stupidity. As I have pointed out, if one looks only at the car industry one will find that this tax will raise only $50m net, leave alone what other problems it might create in other parts of industry.

It is true that there is rising community concern and we have a clear acknowledgment of those problems from Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who has the carriage of these matters. The trouble is that, while Senator Button will stand here and say he agrees with Senator Chaney that in fact the fringe benefits tax will have a substantial impact upon industry, that it will cause difficulties and a loss of jobs, he apparently does not have the weight in Cabinet to be able to influence his colleagues to the extent that they will change their minds. This is a disgraceful admission from such a Minister. He knows that his policies are wrong, that they are obviously leading the country in the wrong direction; yet he is unable to bring any change into effect to ensure that there is a continuity of high levels of unemployment. Naturally that will cause concern in the community and will draw more and more comments from the media as time goes by.

As Senator Short has pointed out, there will be substantial problems with the car industry plan as outlined by Senator Button, and that has been admitted by him. Downsizing as a result of the new fringe benefits tax proposals is sure to have a further impact on the car plan and one has to ask whether the car plan is flexible enough to be able to take account of sudden changes of this kind, especially where they are induced by direct government policy changes. Clearly we should seek replies to those matters from Senator Button in his capacity as a Minister in the course of debates on this matter.

Finally, Senator Cook made a nasty point about used car dealers, with the implication that no one would buy a used car-I presume he meant-from the Opposition. It might please Senator Cook to know that one of the effects of his Government's policies at present as a result of the downsizing that is occurring is to force people not to buy new cars but to start buying second hand cars. That will mean that lower income families will find it more and more difficult to buy a secondhand car as prices rise as a result of that activity. In that way again the Government's policies will impact right across the community as the result of bad thinking, and certainly bad consideration of the new taxation package.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of urgency that is now before the House takes on the form that is followed in many debates in this place. What it really means is that one should take a tax off a particular area of activity because as a result all sorts of benefits will flow. But what the matter of urgency does not deal with is where that tax is to be imposed or, if it is not to be imposed, where the money the tax would otherwise raise is to be saved. One would have thought it would have been fairer if the Opposition had said: `That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency: The need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax which threatens thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries, and to impose the tax . . .' in some other area which it could have specified. Alternatively, the Opposition could have said that this could be brought about by cutting costs in education or family allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: It is implicit in this matter of urgency that the Opposition is intending to cut something. The Opposition has not denied that it may cut family allowances or the amount spent on defence, education or roads. If the Opposition intends to keep on expending, does it intend to increase taxes on wages or the cost of telephones to make up the difference? It is incumbent on Opposition members to explain what they mean. They could give the House a throw-away line and say that they intend to reduce the tax on a particular benefit. But what does that mean? Where does it get us? What new policies do Opposition members intend to put in place to cover the vacuum left by such a move? It shows just how empty matters of urgency such as this become because they do not develop a constructive policy to replace the one the Government is pursuing.

There is another aspect of this debate to which I shall refer. Senator Messner referred to this matter among others and said that this was a tax on the car industry. Well, it is not a tax on the car industry at all. It is a tax on benefits obtained by certain people, and by an exclusive group of people. If a person earns a certain amount of wages, he gets taxed; if he obtains those wages in cash, he pays tax accordingly. If on the other hand a person gets a certain amount of wages but nevertheless gets additional benefits or remuneration by having his children's education fees paid or by getting a car for his own use, the suggestion in this matter of urgency is that he will escape the tax that the other person would have to pay. If a person gets a wage of, say, $300 a week and is taxed upon that sum, a certain amount of that wage is taken away. If on the other hand he gets $200 a week by way of wages and an extra $100 by way of fringe benefits, the Opposition proposes that he should pay less than the person who gets his income in cash. Where is the equity, the justice in that? Why does the Opposition put forward this proposition, which it no doubt intends to bring in if it becomes the government, whereby people who earn an equal amount of remuneration are nevertheless taxed differently, because in one case that remuneration is obtained in cash and in the other case it is obtained partly in cash and partly by way of fringe benefits? Where is the equity in that? The Government is not simply about economic rationalism. It is also about social justice and equity. Where is the equity in the proposition that is now before the House?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not talking about Opposition policy. We are talking about your Government's policy.

—It is being said that I have got the matter of urgency wrong, but what is being said in this wording is that there is need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax. That tax is put upon benefits obtained over and above the amount obtained by way of wages. The proposition remains that if a person obtains $300 by way of wages, he is taxed at a particular level, but if the remuneration is obtained in cash to the extent of $200 and the extra $100 is obtained in fringe benefits, according to the proposition put by the Opposition that person should be taxed only on the $200, whereas the person who obtained his remuneration by way of cash is taxed at whatever level applies. I suggest that that is unjust and inequitable. It was said that because of the present situation the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should resign. That would have been like asking Don Bradman to retire when he was leading the Australian test team in the 1940s.
—He was winning.

—So was Senator Button. Let me go down his batting record. Last year in 1985 there was an increase of 9.2 per cent in the passenger vehicle market over the previous year-the highest sales rate ever. The same argument also held for commercial vehicles. Let me go through the figures. In the previous year of 1984 466,000 passenger vehicles and 172,000 commercial vehicles were sold. That figure is to be compared with the 1982 figure of 152,000 commercial vehicle sales, some 20,000 fewer. That is what has happened under the present Minister. If there is a decline in the number of vehicles sold in 1986, that is understandable given the record sales that have flowed through. One of the problems in the Opposition's argument is that the tax to which the matter of urgency refers has not yet been imposed.
—We dealt with that.

—The Opposition is saying that it is reduced in terms of anticipation, that if people anticipate the tax, therefore something happens. But the Opposition has produced no evidence beyond imputation. Opposition members throughout the debate have made a lot of statements without backing them by evidence. The Opposition has merely referred to fear in the community and has sought to add to it. It has suggested that that fear has caused the present situation, without in any way producing evidence to show that it is so.
—It is called the Messner syndrome.

—Yes, I agree, it is the Messner syndrome. In talking of the way in which evidence can be used, reference was made to a statement made by Mr Charlie Fitzgibbon. It was said that he went along with all the Opposition propositions. What Mr Fitzgibbon was in effect saying was that industry, management-workers and employers-should co-operate more and more. The thrust of his remarks was that there should be co-operation in industry and that that will lead us to the vision splendid.
—But he said `co-operation through flexibility'.
—I am talking about through flexibility. Of course, this Government has proceeded with a flexible policy, a policy which has improved the car industry. There is no denying that is a fact.
—Flexibility in the current circumstances, not the past.

—The reality if one looks at the evidence of what has happened since this Minister has been Minister of the portfolio is that the automotive industry has improved, and that has been acknowledged. What the Opposition has done is to extrapolate a very short period say that it is typical of the whole scheme and deduce from that very limited amount of evidence conclusions that just do not hold. I simply say that the way the Opposition has adopted a good political approach but a logical approach requires a much better effort than that. The other problems the Opposition faces are these: First of all, it is talking purely in economic terms in a situation which requires not only an economic approach but also a social approach. The Opposition talked in terms of reducing wages because that in effect is what members opposite talked about before. The other thing the Opposition does is to ignore its own benefits it has brought. I will stress one of those.

SPEECH.PARA: Much criticism has been made about unleaded petrol. I would have thought that, instead of that being a criticism of the Opposition when it was in government, that is something to its benefit because a health measure has been introduced which will help the ordinary citizen of this country. Why does the Opposition suddenly resile from that position? Why does it now turn its back on a policy and a program that the Opposition put into operation and which I would have thought was something it should be proud of? Now it puts it forward as an impost on industry which should not be tolerated in some sort of way. That seems to me to be quite wrong. The Opposition should be quite proud. The Opposition says it adds 4 per cent cost to the cars. So what? What about the number of lives it will save? What about the purity of the atmosphere it will create? What about the social and health benefits? I really cannot see why the Opposition, having brought that policy in, is now turning its back on it, unless it simply wants to make a political point at this stage. I suppose that is a fair enough thing to do in a chamber like this. On the other hand, if the Opposition wants to put forward a policy which may help the Australian people, which may take us forward and which may lead to a program which can be debated in this House, really something other than what it has done ought to be brought forward.

Senator Short spoke about the need to justify that vehicles allegedly used for commercial purposes were in fact so used. He said it would require a lot more work to be done to show that in fact the vehicle was used for legitimate business purposes. There are two things I want to say about that. It raises the point first of all, which may have been overlooked in this debate, that if in fact a vehicle is used in the course of business and if in fact expenditure has been made on transporting goods in the business, that is tax deductible. What is not tax deductible is that part of the use of the vehicle which is for pleasure, private use and so on. What is wrong with that proposition? If a person uses the same vehicle to do those two things-uses it for both a commercial purpose and a private purpose-why should a person not be obliged to identify the difference between the two and to pay tax on part of that and pay no tax on the other part?

I think it should be clearly understood that this is not a debate about taxing the use of vehicles in business in the production of income. This is a debate about taxing vehicles and the cost of running those vehicles for private purposes. Let me return to the important point that I perhaps began with and which I have made before. In that context it is to be remembered that this is a tax on an aspect of remuneration which is paid in kind rather than in cash, and in those circumstances why should not tax be paid as everybody else has to pay tax on their remuneration?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator who originally came from the vehicle industry I would like to make a few points on the matter of urgency. The importance of the vehicle industry as an employer cannot be overstated. In South Australia the vehicle industry has a special significance. It is part of the industrial backbone of that State. What is more, when all of the doomsayers opposite have had their say and when the legislation is finally brought down the motor industry will still be a major employer in South Australia and in many parts of Australia as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The fringe benefits tax obviously worries members of the Opposition, not because it threatens jobs but because it exposes taxation rorts which they, when in government, failed to stop. The Opposition seems to want an Australia in which honest wage and salary earners pay for their lunch while unscrupulous high income earners can write off their Sunday lunch in a plush restaurant as a taxation deduction. Moreover, it seems happy that the same high income earners can drive to that Sunday lunch and away from it again in a Mercedes and write the expenses of that off as well.

The Opposition has a strange view on such things. The plain fact of the matter is that the Government has had to act in this area to arrest taxation evasion on a very significant scale. The provision of a motor vehicle as part of the income package ought to attract taxation. The Government believes that any sense of equity would hold that taxation principles should be and must be fairly implied. A car which is provided for the personal use of an employee or part personal use is income. The desire of some employers to provide a car or other fringe benefits puts the taxation burden on other income earners who have no such provision. This seems to be the world the Opposition is supporting.

The statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in September made the situation quite clear. Motor vehicles provided as part of a person's employment will be taxed at company rates of taxation. However, if a log book is kept of the use of the vehicle and no personal use is recorded, no tax is paid. Under this method taxation is paid only on the proportion of private to employer use of this vehicle as a percentage of the total annual vehicle costs. Employers, however, can use a different method still. In that statement the Treasurer presented a formula as follows: Less than 25,000 kilometres per year, 11 per cent of the original cost of the vehicle to be paid; between 25,000 and 40,000 kilometres, 7.4 per cent of the original cost to be paid and over 40,000 kilometres, only 3.7 per cent of the original cost of the vehicle to be paid. This means that if private use does not occur, not a penny of taxation is paid. When private use is made, the formula log book method provides an adequate opportunity to treat the whole matter fairly.

In my opinion, the Opposition has overstated this case to defend a growing tax avoidance scheme to the cost of the community as a whole. The Government has always put employment as a high priority and it still does. Another principle which this Labor Government has striven for is taxation justice. It is in these areas that this Government has the runs on the board-the provision of new jobs and the fight against tax avoidance. This Labor Government does not need a lecture on either of these two issues from an Opposition which failed so miserably to address either when in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Opposition senators for their contributions to the debate on the motion that I have moved-namely, the need for the Government to abandon its fringe benefits tax which threatens thousands of jobs in the car industry and other industries. I particularly thank Senator Messner and Senator Short, who supported the motion. I shall not devote much time in this reply to the arguments that they put forward, which were complementary to those which I put in arguing the case originally. However, I want to comment on the defence against the motion which was put forward by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and by Senator Cook, Senator Cooney and, latterly, Senator Foreman.

SPEECH.PARA: What is clear is that no real defence has been put forward to the proposition contained in our motion. The Opposition has made it clear that a combination of circumstances is pulling down motor vehicle sales. We did not, as was suggested by Senator Button, say that all of those circumstances were within the Government's control-although many of them were influenced by the Government. What we were saying was that the present environment in which the motor vehicle industry is working is an environment in which it can ill afford the imposition of new government taxes, of new burdens which will further depress sales. In the face of those circumstances, the reality is that the Government is adding new tax burdens which will add further downward pressures on sales and which have already put pressure on the sales indeed, the industry says that 35,000 extra sales will be lost because of the imposition of this new tax, and the industry suggests that 10,000 jobs will be lost.

I was very disappointed that Senator Foreman, to whom I had gently commented before he spoke that I thought that he might well speak on my team, addressed not one single remark to the question of the impact of these taxes on the industry. He confined his remarks, in what was admittedly a brief opportunity for a contribution, to the taxation questions and questions of tax equity. But he suggested that the Opposition had overstated the case. What the Opposition did was, in fact, to quote three authorities. We quoted the Labor Government of South Australia, which has come to this Government and said that 4,500 jobs will be lost in South Australia. We quoted the industry itself, which, in what appears to be a conservative statement, has suggested that 10,000 jobs will be lost around Australia. We quoted the union from which Senator Foreman has come, which has given the most expansive view as to the number of jobs which will be lost because of this tax. The union has said that 25,000 jobs will be lost around Australia.

To suggest that we have overstated our case is ridiculous, because the union has said that 25,000 jobs will be lost, and we have simply put forward those three estimates, among the many estimates that have been put forward publicly, as a guide to the Government on the sort of views that are held, and we pointed out that the statistics this year make it clear that damage is being suffered already. There is a substantial reduction in the volume of sales in calendar 1986.

We had a fascinating contribution to the debate by Senator Button. He concedes his embarrassment at the situation in which he finds himself. He concedes that damage has been done to the industry or that it will be done to it by this tax. He concedes defeat in Cabinet in trying to do something about it. I can well understand that Senator Short, who spoke after Senator Button, felt constrained to call upon Senator Button to resign, because, after all, we have a situation in which the Minister, who has invested a great deal of effort and political capital into the car plan, is now admitting that the actions of his own Government are counter to the thrust of the plan. That is a very serious admission for the Minister to make.

Senator Cooney, who suggested that we were trying to play on fear in the community in regard to this matter, might care to look at the history of the Opposition's support for the Government in its car plan since May 1984. The reality is that we have not sought, for example, to join with elements of the trade union movement which have at times attacked the Government's car plan. We have said that we believe that it is in the interests of the industry that there should be bipartisanship with respect to the plan, and publicly and privately we have given that support to the plan. In those circumstances, it does not fairly come from Senator Cooney that we are playing on fear in the community. We are saying in this place what has been said in the privacy of discussions with the Government, by the Labor Government of South Australia, which has then told the Press, and by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries privately to the Government month after month before it has made that information public, and we have quoted the public statements of the trade union movement, which has been very vocal about the potential for the loss of up to 25,000 jobs.

What we got from Senator Button was a series of concessions. I have labelled today `Honesty Day'. We have had many concessions from Senator Button today about some of the realities put to him in this debate and at Question Time. But I complain about Senator Button's misrepresentation of our case. We did not suggest that it was for him to reverse the floating of the dollar, that he should be reversing all of the elements which have come together to damage the sales prospects of the motor vehicle industry. What we said to him was that in the circumstances that apply he had a responsibility to do something about the new tax imposts which are being put upon the industry through the fringe benefits tax.

With respect to Senator Cook's contribution, I must say that I think he is getting very confused about the faction to which he belongs. I think that he should move back to the Left faction, because again in the Senate today he conceded that he is part of the high taxing section of the Labor Party. He is famous for a number of statements in this place. Time does not permit me to go through some of his better bon mots, but I treasure his admission that the Labor Party is a high tax Party. That is one of his honest contributions to debate in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that it is a low taxing country.

—If honourable senators look at the report of the first seven or eight minutes of Senator Cook's speech on this topic this afternoon, they will find that he was justifying the levels of taxes in Australia. His Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. What he is saying is that we are a low tax country. All that I can say is that he has the decency, the honesty, to say that he supports high taxes; good on him. But I do not believe that the people of Australia support high taxes. Senator Cook may believe that, but I do not think that the people do, and I do not believe that the people employed in the car industry are interested in hearing defence of high taxes in terms of defending the imposts on this industry which are to be imposed from 1 July.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney made a couple of statements which perhaps need to be challenged. He suggested that the fact that the tax has not yet been imposed meant that all this debate was irrelevant. The fact is that this new tax, which will apply from 1 July, will apply to vehicles purchased from this point on and, indeed, all vehicles which are currently being used. So the argument is one which is certainly not being mounted by those who have been making representations to the Government. With the greatest respect to Senator Cooney, I do not believe that that point is valid. It may well be true, of course, that the impact of the new tax will be more severe after 1 July. The Opposition believes that that may well be so. But let us hope that that will not be so, because already there has been a downturn, which we bitterly regret and do not want to see. We hope that the impact of the tax will not be any greater later in the year than it has already proved to be.

Senator Cooney also suggested that there was no evidence to back up the suggestions that were made about loss of jobs. I can only say that that was a very brave statement from a Victorian senator. Bearing in mind the drop in sales during the first three months of this year, to suggest that it is now just a matter of academic guesswork is a very bold and a very inaccurate statement, and one which I think will return to haunt Senator Cooney.

I believe that the Senate should adopt this motion. I believe that we should assist Senator Button to overcome some of his embarrassment by getting the Government to change its position on the fringe benefits tax. It is a particular difficulty for the motor vehicle industry. It puts under additional pressure, as Senator Button himself conceded, a car industry plan which we want to succeed for the sake of Australia's manufacturing future. It is time for the Government to admit its error and to reverse this decision. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented in remarks made by Senator Chaney when he said that I had said that the Australian Labor Party is a high taxing party. I had not said that. Reference to the Hansard report will show that I did not say that. What I said was, in reply to remarks made by Opposition senators in the debate, that Australia is a low taxing country. I cited a table of tax revenues of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries dated 1983 showing tax as a percentage of gross domestic product.
—This is 1986 that we are talking about.

—This is the latest available table. In the table Australia was ranked nineteenth out of 23 OECD countries, which is to say that we are the fourth lowest taxing country out of 23 like economies to Australia in the world. That can hardly be, under any flight of fancy or emotional rhetoric, an argument for Australia being a high taxing country. In fact, it was a direct reply to the misrepresentations about Labor's taxing policies made by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Button did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Missen).

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate just concluded Senator Cook said that I had said that Australia was one of the most highly taxed countries in the world. Australia is a much more heavily taxed country than Senator Cook suggested, but that it not what I said. What I said was that taxation in Australia is now at its highest level in our history and that that is irrefutable. Any suggestion by this Government that it has cut taxation overall is simply untrue, on whatever basis one may wish to calculate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I commend the National Crime Authority's first annual report. I also particularly commend the work that has been done for the Authority by Mr Justice Stewart, Mr Bingham and Mr Dwyer during that period. I believe that Mr Justice Stewart's contribution to crime fighting in Australia has been absolutely outstanding. The report covers the formation period of the Authority to 30 June 1985. Much has happened since then. The comments in the report should be dealt with and considered very carefully. The report is very well written and careful. I believe that it was intended to be used and very carefully studied. I recommend that the report be read by every member of parliament.

There is no doubt that crime and corruption have reached mammoth proportions in Australia. I believe that not nearly enough people are taking it seriously enough. All sorts of cosmetic things are being said and done. I believe that it is time we took the matter very seriously. It is important that we look at what is being done and at the areas where action may be curtailed because of our lack of appreciation of their operation or because of the impediments of legislation. One has only to look at the range of crimes that are covered. Page 24 of the document shows a whole group of crimes at which the National Crime Authority was looking during its first year of office. It also goes to show that lots of skills and all sorts of legislation are needed to make it possible for the Authority to do its job properly. The Costigan transfer was a massive operation and required quite a lot of work during the formation year. Australia waits for more results from the follow-up of that work. The matter of publicity has been raised. My view is that no information should be released that may prejudice personal security, interfere with any investigation or deter information from being brought forward. If we follow those rules we will not go far wrong. I do not think that it is necessary to do what one Australian newspaper suggested and put the names of people on the front page and deal with them in that way. That is not appropriate.

It is regrettable that differences still exist between the Crime Authority and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I hope that we will be able to get them sorted out to the approval of both points of view. There is a need for substantial changes in legislation. I hope that we will be able to deal with that matter through the Committee in a bipartisan parliamentary way in the interests of ensuring that crime is dealt with more adequately. Clearly, there are deficiencies and omissions. The report suggests how these can be overcome. It concerns me that there is such a multiplicity of overlapping organisations. The Committee could well look at the organisation of crime fighting equipment in Australia and make recommendations on how we can improve it.

We are all very interested in the Government's new proposal on drugs but I am disappointed to find that of the $42.26m that has been itemised as the contribution towards this fight, every cent has already been promised, or was in last year's Budget or was set aside at last year's crime summit. Not one new dollar in the money mentioned will come forward. Anybody who believes that this is a massive new onslaught into fighting crime will be terribly disappointed because that is simply not what it is all about. I ask the Government to take another look at this and see whether it can do something towards trying to patch things up and have better tools for the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall make just one small comment before I proceed to my remarks. My understanding is that moneys under the drug allocation-about $30m worth of grants in the last year-are for improving services already on the ground. It is not true that there has been no money for providing increased services for the giving of attention to individuals and support for a variety of institutions dealing with the drug problem. It is not only publicity expenditure at this point. I will comment about the National Crime Authority annual report partly because of a longstanding acquaintance through the preparatory inquiries of the Senate committee and because I am a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. That goes to a point also raised by Senator Archer about some difficulties on which I will comment briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I endorse the remarks by Senator Archer about the content of this report. It is very comprehensive and gives very briefly a potted history of the need for a National Crime Authority and its emergence in its present form. Anybody who has an interest should run through the section dealing with the history of the establishment of the NCA as he or she would find it a very useful summary and a very adequate coverage of that topic. The report goes to some of the difficulties in the establishment of the National Crime Authority, not the least being the transition period when the NCA took over many of the considerations and deliberations of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. As Mr Justice Stewart makes it very clear on the first page of the report:

. . . the Authority was not then, is not now, and will not in the future be merely an extension of that Royal Commission. The Authority is a national body and the Royal Commission's work was but one facet of the significant task now before the Authority.

That is a very important point. Secondly, before looking at the difficulties of what material the Commission should pass over to the Authority the report addresses another very important area-administration and the appointment of staff. Mr Stewart says:
In view of the specialised nature of the Authority's work and the importance of obtaining the best available staff, the Members and I were determined to play a large part in staff selections.

As a result, and as the Joint Parliamentary Committee also established, a considerable chunk of the Authority's time was taken up in those staff appointments and administrative details so that, even though there was a delay in the establishment or the actual functioning of the Authority, there was a further delay as the Authority spent its time getting the staff appointed and getting satisfactory administrative procedures in place. Further in the report it was stated that much of the early work was devoted to establishing satisfactory liaison, co-ordination and co-operation arrangements with other agencies.

I turn to page 17 of the report, which comments briefly on the Parliamentary Joint Committee. This report came down ahead of the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee pointing to the difficulties that the Parliamentary Joint Committee has in its required role vis-a-vis the National Crime Authority. The report states very clearly:
The duties of the Committee as set out in section 55 (1) of the National Crime Authority Act, are-
first-
. . . to monitor and to review the performance by the Authority of its functions.

It goes on to spell out the other requirements and it is on that point that we have had considerable difficulty. The Joint Parliamentary Committee tabled its first report and a statement that addressed that difficulty. I hope that in the coming year the next National Crime Authority report will be able to say that a satisfactory arrangement has been reached between the two bodies, but it is certainly not the case at the moment. Comments during a television coverage last night on the work of the Parliamentary Joint Committee will not help that process. It is my understanding, having watched that program, that wrong information was provided about what the Parliamentary Joint Committee is seeking from the National Crime Authority. We did not intend and will not ever intend to require information that would in any way jeopardise the work of the National Crime Authority. It highlights a difficult point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the legislation to establish the National Crime Authority was before this Senate the Opposition made it clear that the Government has seriously weakened the powers of the body to pursue fully its responsibilities. Instead of being given independence to seek wherever it wanted and create its own initiatives, they were to be politically determined. We had the extraordinary situation of a Federal-State committee having the ability to determine and veto whether an issue should be pursued. It is well to remember that the Hawke Government at that stage would have proceeded with an authority which would have allowed State governments to veto the right of the Commonwealth to investigate a matter that was purely in the Commonwealth's jurisdiction. It was only by the action of this side of the chamber in amending the Bill that that absolute monstrosity was ruled out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to know that in recent days in a public broadcast on Four Corners a series of royal commissioners came out with a very clear message. That was despite the fact that there had been some five royal commissions-the Moffitt Royal Commission on Alleged Organised Crime in Registered Clubs in New South Wales, the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking, the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-which brought down reports all of which were damning indictments on our inability to deal with the drug situation. The commissioners felt that insufficient action had been taken on these reports and, where action had been taken, it was too late. Mr Justice Woodward had a strong message, as I understand it, regarding the deliberate action by the New South Wales Wran Government to go it alone in a particular way on drugs and he felt that that would stifle law enforcement. What has happened is an incredible situation. Against the background that the Government is saying that it is determined to put down drug abuse, we have in Australia a Government that has brought in legislation which has deliberately restricted the ability of governments to do this.
