We have had some measure of success in bringing about the trial and conviction of some drug offenders but what we have not done is get to the core of the problem.

Recently in New South Wales a series of people, who were engaged in perhaps the largest of the known drug smuggling rings into Australia, were brought to trial and sentenced. I refer to the purchase of a Panama freighter which was loaded with drugs, I think, from Lebanon. The freighter was brought to just off Darwin. The drugs were loaded into barges. The freighter was sunk, the drugs were distributed by trucks and the crew was got rid of through Bali. One could even be satisfied and say: `The courts have dealt with the matter'. It is interesting that those who were tried all pleaded guilty and we must ask ourselves why they did that. That is usually a fair indication that it is safer inside gaol, rather than outside, in terms of who were the principals, the proprietors. However, the fundamental question that has not been answered is: `Who put up the enormous tens of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars which allowed this situation to occur, that is to buy a freighter and to manipulate this event?' At this moment we are dealing with employees. We are not dealing with the principals involved. Anything that a government-State or Federal-does to restrict the rights of the National Crime Authority or other authorities to hunt freely wherever the trail may lead is bad, crippling and prevents us from getting to the source. I believe that the National Crime Authority cannot do its job thoroughly at this moment because of the restrictions it is placed under. I commend it for what it is trying to do. I regret very much that a Labor Government which says that it is doing something on drugs should have put a major restriction on anyone who is achieving justice in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to refer to the National Crime Authority's report. I support what Senator Crowley said about the activities of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which was set up by this Parliament. I assure the Senate that no members of the Committee have a desire to be informed about matters related to current investigations. Our duty, as we see it, is to ensure that we are equipped to report on the methodology of the Crime Authority, on the morale of the staff and matters dealing with administration rather than investigation. I expect that we have a responsibility to examine the Authority to ensure that necessary legislative powers are given to it to ensure that it can carry out its very important task with more efficiency and effectiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in the community at large there is widespread and growing concern about major crime and this report highlights the variety of crimes that are being brought under notice by the Crime Authority. I think Senator Archer referred to page 24 of the report which details those matters. The report states:

The abuse of both legal and illegal drugs is acknowledged as one of Australia's gravest social and criminal problems. The Authority's concern about illegal drug abuse stems from the fact that four of its five references and the majority of its general investigations involve drug related offences.

While there is much to praise in the drug education program that has recently been authorised by the Government, much greater effort is necessary to properly fight and find the generals who run the drug syndicates rather than the front line troops who distribute the drugs. Senator Sir John Carrick referred to that a moment ago in his speech. In this respect I suggest that the Government, through the Inter-Governmental Committee associated with the National Crime Authority, should produce the necessary legislation to give both the Authority and the Commonwealth and State police the necessary powers to combat major criminals in Australia who are a scourge on our society.

In particular I support the National Crime Authority's request for legislation similar to the United States racketeer influence and corruption organisations statute and the entering into mutual assistance treaties to enable international trafficking to be countered. I certainly believe that telephone tapping to obtain the necessary evidence is justified in the case of this illegal trade. I know there is an argument about civil liberties but when we are dealing with mass murder, the introduction of drugs to school children and a perpetual pushing of this obnoxious material, I think that those matters provide an adequate reason why police should be given the right to tap telephones provided, of course, they have evidence to suggest that in doing so they will be able to follow the money trail and eventually bring to justice the major criminals whom we would all like to see behind bars and out of the way in order to prevent further problems associated with drug trafficking in Australia.

The question of providing Government support for Federal and State police to do the job more effectively is essential. This has been highlighted recently, I think, by Mr Woodward, Frank Costigan, QC and Mr Athol Moffitt in his book A Quarter to Midnight. All of those comments ought to be taken account of by the Government so that the war against these severe major crimes in Australia can be effectively won. On two occasions we have had talks with the Crime Authority; we have talked with the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and pointed out some difficulties between the Crime Authority and the Committee. We intend following up that matter shortly with the Minister and the Crime Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the National Crime Authority allows the Senate the brief opportunity of looking at the work which is being done in the pursuit of organised crime in Australia. It demonstrates the extent to which certain elements of both the Federal and New South Wales State Labor governments are simply not serious about the fight against organised crime. The editorial in the Age of 8 April headed `NCA: the verdict of three wise men' draws attention to the effectiveness of the NCA and states that it is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . undercut by rivalries between the various law enforcement agencies and governments. In theory, they are all working for the same end but, as Mr Woodward noted, organised co-operation between Federal and State agencies is lacking.
The editorial continued:
. . . The Authority's capacity to turn back the tide of organised crime and corruption in Australia will continue to be seriously limited

In the same issue of the Age attention was drawn to the fact that Mr Athol Moffitt, who headed Australia's first inquiry into organised crime 13 years ago, Mr Phillip Woodward, QC, Sir Edward Williams and Mr Frank Costigan, QC, all former Royal Commissioners, have all attacked the hobbling of the powers of the National Crime Authority and related authorities throughout Australia to deal with the question of crime in this country and it is no wonder. I invite you, Mr Deputy President, and members of the Senate, to consider what has been happening in New South Wales so far as this matter is concerned. I invite honourable senators to consider the fact that the Premier of New South Wales, the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, has been launching the most bitter attacks upon Mr Temby, QC, the Director of Public Prosecutions, for daring to pursue matters of organised crime. I invite honourable senators to consider that the use of the no bill provisions by the Attorney-General of New South Wales has reached such scandalous proportions that Mr Masterman, QC, the Ombudsman of New South Wales, has drawn public attention to this misuse of the Attorney-General's power under government direction. As a result, Mr Masterman, a Queen's Counsel of absolutely impeccable reputation, has found himself savaged and attacked by Mr Wran, the Premier of New South Wales.

I invite honourable senators to consider the fact that the New South Wales Government, in order to get itself off the hook at the last New South Wales election, announced the establishment of the Commissioner of Public Complaints. That office was set up in a way that made it totally unable to deal with the issues of organised crime. It was set up on 20 August 1984, but empowered to investigate only complaints against senior public officers and officials that occurred after that date, and then was denied the right to use its royal commission type of powers against those individuals concerned so that the Commissioner, Mr Lloyd Jones, QC, said on 5 September 1984 that his office had acted on none of the 14 complaints received because 10 of them were outside the scope of his ability to act.

I ask honourable senators to consider that the very distinguished judge, Mr Francis Hutley, on his retirement from the New South Wales Court of Appeal on 19 October 1984, drew attention to the increasing tendency of the New South Wales Government to attempt to put pressure on the judiciary and to interfere with the judiciary in the pursuit of organised crime. I invite honourable senators to consider that, when the recommendations of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union were announced, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said on 1 November 1984:
. . . as far as my Government is concerned, we will be taking a very positive approach to (all) his recommendations . . .

The Government then rejected his recommendations for the NCA powers to be extended, that a further royal commission on drug trafficking be held, that the veto power of the Federal-State Inter-Governmental Committee over the NCA's coercive powers be removed and for the institution of a taxation investigation tribunal, a tax crime investigator and a port security authority.

I do not have time to draw the Senate's attention to Senator Richardson's attempt to interfere in the prosecution in the Enmore conspiracy case and the attempt of the New South Wales Government to put pressure on the magistracy over that particular matter but what I do invite honourable senators to turn their attention to is the simple fact that the fight against organised crime has been hampered in this country, both at the Federal and New South Wales level, by a Labor Prime Minister and a Labor Premier and Federal President of the Australian Labor Party who have too many skeletons in the closet to hide and who are determined to hide them, determined not to allow them to be exposed, determined to hobble the fight against organised crime in this country, and they should be ashamed of themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It almost seems like a hoax when we have an announcement of the spending of $100m on the drug offensive. Of course, $100m is not the amount being spent, although I guess that a number of people who have seen the publicity so far may have been misled into believing that that is the case. No one could object to the concept of a drug offensive. The objects, as stated in this rather expensive brochure we have been given, are to work in the areas of drug education, treatment and rehabilitation, research and law enforcement. But we know from this report that we are discussing that drug offences are the principal offences being dealt with by the National Crime Authority. We know from the report that the drug industry is a very big and profitable industry in Australia. It is important that it is able to be attacked on a proper basis. Of the four references in the report under consideration, drugs are the basis of them, along with other things such as tax evasion and distribution offences.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Crime Authority report also deals with some of the offences which are not included. We all know how powerless the Authority really is. The restriction of its powers has been referred to this afternoon. It has no power to tap telephones-not that that is a desirable activity, but everyone in the drug industry can tap telephones as they wish, with very little risk of getting caught or suffering as a consequence. The Authority has less power than a royal commission. The Government seems reluctant to hit into this very lucrative industry. The reports of previous royal commissioners who have inquired into the drug industry have been referred to this afternoon. I refer to the reports of Mr Woodward, Mr Costigan, Mr Moffitt and others. Let us not forget that drugs are big business and big money, but drugs are also a huge social problem. They have completely destroyed the lives of many young people in this country. They have seriously interfered with the lives of many others. We should not underestimate what drugs can do to a family.

I hope this campaign that has been announced will be successful in discouraging young people from attempting to try drugs. I welcome the idea, but it does not get to the availability of drugs. The problem that we are really talking about is the need for an increase in the amount of money spent on the surveillance of shipping ports and airports. What are we seriously doing about monitoring what goes on around our coastline? What are we seriously doing about penalties for people caught in drug activities? Certainly, many of those caught are the small fry and not the big fish, but the penalties need to be sufficiently severe to act as a deterrent; at present most of them are a joke.

There was a report recently of a drug boss being sentenced to 20 years in gaol for involvement in a $40m drug ring. It was also indicated in the report that a period of 13 years had been set as a minimum non-parole period. But I wonder what period he will really serve. He will probably be in gaol for about three years; that seems to be the case these days. It is pretty easy to get out of gaol. There is no longer a serious belief in this community that a gaol sentence means what it sets out to mean and that it is in any way a deterrent for those involved. How much of the $40m, or whatever the real amount is, will still be available to that drug boss when he gets out of gaol in a few years time? How seriously are we ensuring that assets are forfeited? We need to ensure that our police are properly equipped and trained. What happened to the report a while ago that stated that the Australian Federal Police was grossly undermanned and that another 1,200 police were needed?

By all means let us seek to educate people on the horror of drugs and seek to turn young people against drugs. By all means let us seek to provide the best means of rehabilitating those whose lives otherwise would be virtually destroyed, but let us be serious about it and give the National Crime Authority the power to attack the source. Let us impose real penalties that act as a deterrent. Let us have adequate police resources to do the job that the police are supposed to do. Let us hope that there will be much better news in the reports of the National Crime Authority that will come to the Senate in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks on the fifth report of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled `Examination of Annual Reports' and sub-titled `Another look at Children's Television'. I do so because I believe we have now got to the stage where the regulation of children's television and broadcasting for children on television and radio is no longer justified in terms of the impositions which are being made on broadcasting authorities allegedly regulating children's television for the benefit of children. In the Senate Committee report attention is drawn in paragraph 4.2 to this fact:

SPEECH.PARA: Ninety-eight per cent of Australian homes have a television set. These are in use for an average of thirty-one hours a week. On average, children watch approximately twenty-four hours of television a week. Some children watch television for forty to fifty hours a week.

This has led to a situation in which it is estimated that children will watch two full years of television in the first 15 years of their lives and will see half a million advertisements in that time, and that for every hour that they read they will have watched seven hours of television. Unfortunately, while the report of the Senate Standing Committee has many admirable things to say, in my view it repeats a lot of the extremely paternalistic and, I believe, totally outmoded concepts about the regulation of children's television.

The Committee last reported on the decision given by the Federal Court of Australia in the Herald-Sun TV Pty Ltd case, in which the regulation of C classification programming on children's television had been interrupted. I said at that stage that I believed there was over-regulation of children's television. The Parliament, nevertheless, proceeded to pass legislation amending the Broadcasting and Television Act. It amended that Act in order to restore to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal regulatory powers over children's television.

The Senate Committee's examination of this matter, I believe, has inadvertently picked up at least one significant point which I think is open to considerable challenge. That appears in paragraph 4.19 of the report, which indicates that the Committee has accepted evidence from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation about its ratings for children's television. If we look at pages 481 and 482 of the Hansard transcript of evidence given to the Committee we see this claim made by Mr Farrell of the ABC:
. . . the ABC alone is achieving 40 per cent of the available audiences . . .

He was talking about an audience of children in a specified time framework during the week. I have a copy of a letter which was sent to Senator Colston, the Chairman of the Committee, by David Morgan, the Federal Director of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Education
and the Arts
Parliament House
CANBERRA 2600
April 1, 1986
Dear Senator Colston
FIFTH REPORT: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS
`Another Look At Children's Television'

This Report, recently published, contained comments by Mr C. Farrell, Acting head of the ABC's Children's Programs department which were extremely critical of the programming performance of commercial television stations in the 4.00 to 5.00 p.m. period reserved by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal exclusively for programs directed specifically to children aged between six and thirteen years inclusive. Unfortunately, Mr Farrell's comments are inaccurate and therefore misleading.
In paragraph 4.19 of the Report, Mr Farrell is quoted as follows:

`One of the arguments that is put forward against the `C' hour is that nobody is watching. If the ABC alone is achieving 40 per cent of the available audience, then I think the commercial networks have to question seriously whether it is what they are putting into the `C' hour that is causing them to lose figures.'

The `C' hour to which Mr Farrell refers is 4.00 to 5.00 p.m. Monday to Friday which has been set aside by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal specifically for programs designed for children aged six to thirteen years inclusive. Each program telecast by a commercial television station in that period must receive prior approval from the Tribunal. Only in the case of a live sporting event or live coverage of an event of national importance may these approved programs be pre-empted.
Neither Mr Farrell nor the ABC is in any position to be critical of commercial television broadcasters because the ABC ignores the Tribunal's prescriptions.

In the two weeks from February 23 to March 8, 1986, all programs telecast by the ABC in this period were designed for pre-school age children. The programs in question were Play School and Mr Squiggle. Both are repeats. Had any commercial station televised either of these programs between 4.00 and 5.00 p.m. it would clearly have breached the Tribunal's Standards and, I venture to say, would have been in quite serious trouble.

Mr Farrell infers that the ABC is achieving 40 per cent of the available audience between 4.00 to 5.00 p.m. Research conducted by McNair Anderson for the four weeks, February 9 to March 8, 1986 reveals:

More relevant to the matter in question is the fact that the ABC reaches nowhere near 40 per cent of the target audience, i.e. the six to thirteen year olds. The following tables reveal the percentage achieved by the ABC and commercial stations of five to twelve year olds. (McNair Anderson survey category).

Clearly the commercial stations have the lion's share of the five to twelve year old audience between 4.00 and 5.00 p.m. Clearly, Mr Farrell's criticisms are unwarranted.

Despite the criticisms by Mr Farrell and others, commercial television throughout Australia have made and continue to make every effort to produce and telecast programs which meet the Tribunal's criteria and which will attract children from the relevant age group.

It is unfortunate that Mr Farrell's comments have obscured the real concern expressed by commercial broadcasters. That concern is that the criteria for `C' programs and the judgment of the Tribunal appear to be out of touch with the needs and desires of six to thirteen year old children.

While commercial stations are doing their best to produce and telecast programs which will attract children and are, as illustrated, attracting the majority of children who are viewing between 4.00 and 5.00 p.m., the overwhelming majority of children within the age group do not appear to find `C' programs to their liking.

Of the potential audience of 412,000 five to twelve year olds living in Sydney, at best only 72,000 (17.48%) are attracted to `C' times programs in an average week. The situation is not much different in Brisbane and Melbourne although some 30.65% of children in Adelaide watch `C' time programs.
It would appear that despite the good intentions of the Tribunal, its Children's Program Committee and broadcasters, the `C' program concept in its present form is a failure.
Yours sincerely
DAVID MORGAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr Morgan, in his submission, presents evidence from the ratings of the McNair Anderson survey taken in the four weeks 9 February to 8 March 1986 which reveals that, by and large, the ABC is lucky to achieve a figure as high as 23 per cent of all people in that 4 to 5 o'clock time slot and it is lucky to achieve a high figure of 34 per cent for 5 to 12-year-olds. There is no doubt in my mind, in looking at the McNair Anderson details, that the ABC has presented evidence to the Senate Committee which is simply unsustainable on the basis of evidence which can be tested from what are usually regarded as the principal reliable standards-the McNair Anderson ratings-as far as television watching behaviour is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this has in part influenced the Committee in the way in which it has addressed its mind to the regulation of children's television. I believe we have got to a stage where people of the greatest good will and of the greatest integrity are regulating children's programs on television by applying to children in the late 1980s the standards which were appropriate for children in the early 1970s. I do not believe that the classification of children's television programs has in any way kept up with the changing attitude and the changing intellectual development of Australia's children.

If one looks at the programs one sees that we are still back in the Play School and Mr Squiggle days among children whose familiarity with computers, computer technology and the use of computers and whose understanding of computers is, I must say, considerably greater than mine-not that that would be difficult. Under the sorts of classification procedures that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is still applying to children's television, I do not believe that children are being presented with educational programs or, indeed, with entertainment programs which are appropriate to children at this time in their development. I believe that the standards of the 1960s and 1970s are being applied to the intellectual development of children in the 1980s and I believe that that is now having a substantial and, indeed, detrimental effect.

The quality of children's television in Australia is uniformly in decline. It is poor television; a lot of it is poorly made. It is not stimulating television; it is not relevant television; it is not entertaining in the sense that the standards of entertainment applied for children these days ought to be changing. There is almost no live broadcasting, there is almost no sports broadcasting and there is almost no current affairs type of broadcasting relevant to children. We are not dealing just with pre-school kids but with children up to the age of 14 years. We are dealing with children who are at high school, children who are being made familiar with news broadcasts and with developments in science and technology and other parts of the education system which are simply not being catered for by the level and the standard of the children's television regulation which is apparent in this country at the moment.

The Education and the Arts Committee has performed over a long period one of the most valuable services for this Senate in terms of the monitoring of children's television. This is the fourth report which looks at the issue of children's television. Very few Senate committees have maintained an ongoing interest in a particular subject and have continued to report at regular intervals. If my memory serves me correctly, the first of these reports was prepared under the chairmanship of Senator Davidson, with subsequent reports being prepared under the chairmanship of Senator Teague and Senator Colston. Going back for the best part of a decade this Parliament has been kept in touch with developments in children's television through the excellent work of this committee.

The Committee has attempted to come to grips with a number of these issues. However, I believe it has been substantially influenced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, by the institutional people interested in maintaining children's television as it is and by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and it has not in fact opened the window for children's television in the way that other areas of the broadcasting spectrum-television in particular-have been opened up. It is now time for the whole C classification procedure to be put back into the melting pot. It is time for some of the standards and ideas which I think are old and outdated to be severely challenged and tested. I believe that the Senate Committee would be the most appropriate, and within Australia the most competent and informed, body to do that. I hope that next time it has a look at children's television it will not simply look at the question of how to make the existing system operate better but will in fact look at whether the existing system is relevant any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to see that Senator Puplick has rightly commended the monitoring by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts of children's television over many years. Over the last eight years a most careful interest in children's television has been expressed by the Committee. I have happily been a party to those four reports to which Senator Puplick has referred-those of 1978, 1981, last year and this year. I note that he has taken up one particular matter. He has commended our interest and has suggested that the Committee would be well placed to look at the question of the C classification, which is an issue in which many viewers, the children of Australia, the commercial television stations, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are interested. He has looked to the Senate Committee as being the best placed body to carry out any additional review.

SPEECH.PARA: I want at the outset to reassure him and the Senate that, whilst we have been substantially influenced by the competent witnesses from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the ABC who have appeared at all of our hearings, especially at the last two when we have been expressly reviewing the annual reports of those two bodies, we have been equally influenced by the commercial television stations in Australia, all of which have appeared before us or presented written material. Their witnesses have very ably presented their views to us. There has also been representations from the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and from the industry as a whole, including writers, producers, film makers and, not least, the Independent Children's Television Foundation which, although based in Melbourne and although too reliant perhaps upon eastern States personnel and initiative, is nevertheless a national foundation and an organisation that I am proud was established to a large extent as a result of the original report of this Senate Committee.

Whilst Senator Puplick, armed with careful representations from FACTS, has incorporated some criticism by the Federation in his speech just now and made the assessment that we have been overly influenced by the public statutory authorities, I deny that and believe that we have given, with justice, a proper hearing to all the interests involved. Uppermost in the Committee's mind-it is evident in all of our reports, not least this report in the series of examinations of annual reports-has been the interests of the children themselves. We are conscious that between 5 and 7 o'clock on any week day half of the children of Australia are watching television and that in the course of growing up in this country on average a child views approximately 24 hours of television a week. Some children view television for between 40 and 50 hours a week. Most children in Australia spend more time watching television than they do in instruction at school. It must be evident to all of us that, whilst parents, brothers and sisters and all the home influences provide the primary context for the development of children and schools rank second in that influence, television must certainly rank third in terms of the way our children's minds, lives and values are determined.

We have very much kept before us the fact that television, especially at the time most children are watching it, ought to be creative and inspiring, and it ought not to be so entirely educational that it does not entertain. We think that children have as much right to find enjoyment and satisfaction in watching television as anyone else in the community. My own views are somewhat biased in that I hardly ever watch television and I do not encourage children to watch it. In fact, I am somewhat cheered by the most recent statistics that there is a decline in children's television watching habits. Apparently, the main reason for this is that videos are now so widely available to children that they are watching videos in preference to television.

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as they are not watching adult videos.

—Perhaps they are watching too much adult videos. When I was pricking up my ears that there was a decline in the periods of time children watch television, I was then again put back on my haunches by the admission from our witnesses that this arose primarily because children were being diverted to watching their own choice of videos. However, there is a growing number of children who are making their own activities entirely outdoors, with their own books, with their own peers, with other children, in activities that are not just presented to them on a plate, often soporifically, on television.
—Does that not say something about the quality of children's television?

—I shall come to the question of the quality of children's television. Senator Puplick has said that there is in television a uniform decline. I want to say on the one hand of children's television that this is not the case with children's drama, and it is not the case especially on one commercial channel in South Australia, Channel 9, which has an excellent approach to C time television productions which have been so well received by children in my own State. Sadly, these are not emulated by all, and there is still too much that is uniformly mediocre, and worse, on our television.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that recently there has been the production of the Henderson Kids: the Children's Television Foundation has produced the Winners series which is made up of some eight dramas specifically geared to children aged six to 14. I happen to have watched three or four of those programs with my children and they are uniformly of a high standard. They ought to be as they have each received around $3m worth of production costs. That amounts to some $3m worth for the series as a whole. The Children's Television Foundation is to be highly commended for the excellence of the programs in the Winners series. They have shown mostly on Channel 10 on Saturday and Sunday evenings, not in C-time because they are so good that they are seen to be best broadcast at a time when a majority of the population may be watching television. Though aimed at children, those programs have a wider relevance and have been of great enjoyment to many adults as well as children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts called `Another look at Children's Television' continues the fine tradition of that Committee. Over many years it has considered vital issues relating to children's television and its reports have thrown a lot of light on this important area. The quality of the Committee's work can be seen from last December's all party support for the restoration of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers to preclassify children's programs. Apparently Senator Puplick objected to all the parties supporting this matter. The Government dragged its feet for nine months on the matter. Indeed, I would like to contrast this to the Australian Democrats' approach and to the speedy manner in which the High Court gave its judgment on the question of standards and pointedly noted that broadcasting matters were before Parliament on 21 May last year. The Australian Democrats at that stage introduced a private member's Bill to restore the preclassification powers only two days later-two days after the original High Court decision. I have no doubt that the August 1985 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled `Children's Television Standards' was a major factor in persuading the waverers in the Government and the Opposition ranks to vote for this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering children's television, primary importance must be attached to the well-being and nurturing of our children. We cannot allow our children to be exposed to the vagaries of organisations which mainly seek to maximise advertising revenue and to minimise programming expenditure. I am glad that the commercial stations have started to recognise some of their responsibilities to children in recent years. The report before the Senate points out a major deficiency in programs for children aged between six and nine years. It links that problem with the advertising advantages to be obtained by aiming at the older and broader audiences which may be reliable at this time. The television industry should take note of this matter and show that it is capable of discharging its responsibilities to all children without the presence of further regulations, if it wishes to have a self-regulatory role.

I heartily endorse the Committee's prod to broadcasters in chapter 4 of the report. In fact, in evidence before the Committee Dr Shelley Phillips made these observations about the neglect of children aged six to nine years. She said:

Six to nine years of age are crucial years for the development of imagination and make-believe. The latter is very important in a child's intellectual and personal development. When children are troubled or depressed, imagination shrivels or may stop all together.
She went on to say:

Researchers are increasingly producing evidence that if children are fed unimaginative stodge at a period when fantasy and make-believe are crucial, they may be rendered passive, intellectually and emotionally. They are discouraged from utilising normal outlets for coping with the world outside through imaginative ventures, make-believe and fantasy.
I think that Mrs Hazel Hawke's remarks at the opening of the three-day conference on `The Challenge of Kids Television' in May last year bring the situation into proper perspective. She said:

There are 4.6 million Australians aged 16 years and under. They do not yet vote but their actions will define Australian life in the next decades. Their major source of entertainment is television and most of their free time is spent in front of a television set. The tragedy is that it does so little good when it could do so much good.

For every hour that children read, on a average they watch seven hours of television. Thirty per cent more time goes into watching television than receiving formal education in the first 16 years of their lives. Half a million advertisements will be seen in that time by each of those children.

I thoroughly endorse the call by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for a wider diversity of innovative, exciting and entertaining programs for the benefit of our children and the nation. I am heartened that the 9 network has recognised the value of providing stimulating fare with its C'mon Kids program since last February. Station NWS 9 in my own home State of South Australia showed that it could be done. I support Senator Teague in this matter in congratulating the station. Instead of offering the dull formula material which does not go beyond the letter of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's requirements, it has set up a format that has five different types of programs within a week. This keeps the children occupied and interested. It beats the opposition hollow and it attracts nearly three times the audience of any of its commercial rivals and over double of that for the Australian Broadcasting Commission between four and five.

That should answer Senator Puplick's discussions about what one can really do with children's television if one tries. I am pleased that the concept has gone national. I hope that other stations will look at providing a greater variety also. That will be necessary for them to be able to gain the audiences they crave for and which they have lost since the mid-1970s. That was well before pre-classification of children's programs was introduced.

The performance of the ABC in relation to children's programs suitable for the various age groups is in fact praised by the Committee. A hope is expressed that children's television will continue to get proper funding within an organisation which has been chronically under- resourced for some years now. The program Play School, as has been mentioned before, has managed to achieve as much as 50 per cent of the available audience between 4 p.m. and 4.30 p.m. in certain States. There are quite a few programs for the five to eight-year-olds, and the ABC has started to target material towards the 11 to 14-year-olds also. Paragraph 5.10 of the report states:

According to ratings provided to the Committee by the ABT, the ABC has increased its share of the child viewing audience in the 4.00 p.m. to 5.00 p.m. time slot. In 1977 the ABC attracted about 9 per cent of the viewing audience in the Sydney and Melbourne metropolitan areas. By 1985, this proportion had increased to 34 per cent.

I would like to join my congratulations to those already given to the ABC and I hope that it continues to provide this service. Perhaps the comments of the Acting Head of Children's Programs in the ABC to the Committee explains this. He said:

The area of children's television in the ABC has always been in the forefront of our television thrust and it has been, from our point of view, something we have welcomed rather than the attitude that some of the commercial networks have taken to it which is something that has been forced upon them.

This matter of attitude is crucial, just not to the children's television but to the nation as a whole. I asked a question of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) last year on this area and I seek leave to incorporate the question and the answer from the Minister for Communications in relation to the activities of the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Leave granted.
The question upon notice and the answer read as follows-
Films for Children
(Question No. 754)
Senator Vigor asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 5 December 1985:

(1) How many programs, pilots, outlines of program concepts and film scripts have been submitted to the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in each of the financial years the Committee has been in existence, and in each year, how many of these submissions have been rejected.
(2) How many have resulted in substantial modifications after initial advice about potential unsuitability.
(3) What proportion of the material either (a) rejected; or (b) substantially modified, happened because the material was not aimed specifically at an under-14 audience.
(4) What have been the other main causes for rejection or substantial modification of material in each year of operation of the Children's Program Committee.

(5) How many of the projects given a Provisional `C' classification during each year in which it has been used, have later been rejected, or have required substantial modification in order to obtain a full `C' classification, and what has been the major problem in each such case.

(6) What has been the average time for arriving at a decision as to whether a film script should have a Provisional `C' classification since the operation of the children's drama quota, and what has been the longest delay.
(7) What has been the average time for dealing with the submitted finished programs, and what has been the longest delay in assessing any such program.
ANSWERS
(1) (Nov) 1978-1979: 37 submissions, 8 rejected
1979-1980: 230 submissions, 114 rejected (in addition, further information was sought on 3 submissions and 13 were withdrawn)
1980-1981: 167 submissions, 61 rejected (further information sought on 1, 9 were withdrawn)
1981-1982: 124 submissions, 62 rejected (further information sought on 2, 5 withdrawn)
1982-1983: 99 submissions, 28 rejected (further information sought on 2, 3 withdrawn)
1983-1984: 174 submissions, 53 rejected (further information sought on 2, 14 withdrawn)
1984-1985: 84 submissions, 25 rejected (6 were not classified `C' Drama on script although retained Provisional `C' classification), further information sought on 1, 6, withdrawn
1985-23 December 1985: 39 submissions, 5 rejected, 9 awaiting a decision for `C' drama on script, further information sought on 2.
(2) It is not clear how many programs have resulted in substantial modifications after initial advice about potential suitability.

(3) Children's Television Standard (CTS) 2 (a) states that `C' programs should be designed specifically for children older than 5 years and younger than 14 years. This criteria is the major reason (which is in a ratio of 4:3 to the next main reason, Standard CTS 2f) for rejection and/or need for modification.
(4) For each financial year, except 1979/80, 1980/81 and 1981/82, the reasons for rejection in descending order of frequency have been as follows:
1. CTS 2 (a) CTS 2 is designed specifically for children older than 5 years and younger than 14 years;
2. CTS 2 (f) contributes to the social emotional or intellectual developments of children;
3. CTS 2 (g) is appropriate for Australian children not assuming too much of the culture, dialect or environment of some other country;
4. CTS 2 (b) is designed to entertain children; and CTS 2 (e) fulfils some special need of children;
5. CTS 2 (c) is well produced technically and artistically;
6. CTS 2 (d) can be easily understood and appreciated by children;
7. CTS 2 (h) is not outdated in content or in technical or artistic production.
In 1979/80, 1980/81 and 1981/82 the pattern varied with CTS 2 (f) and (g) being the main reasons for rejection above CTS 2 (a).

(5) No completed program granted a Provisional `C' classification at script stage has later been rejected for a full `C' classification, although many projects granted a Provisional `C' have not yet been resubmitted as complete programs for a full `C' classification.

The number of projects that have required substantial modification for full `C' classification is not clear although some projects required modification for `C' in 1978/79 (1), 1979/80 (1), 1980/81 (3) and 1983/84 (12) in order to meet CTS 2 (a) and in 1982/83 (2) because further information/pilot was required. In 1984/85 6 scripts were rejected either because the Committee considered it could not assess the programs still at script stage with regard to CTS 2 (c) or because modification was needed to meet CTS 2 (a).
(6) The average time for Provisional `C' recommendation and decision has been approximately 4 1/2 weeks. The longest delay of Provision `C' recommendation and decision has been 12 weeks.
(7) The average time for `C' recommendation and decision has been approximately 4 weeks. The longest delay for `C' recommendation and decision has been 16 weeks.

The timing for the recommendation/decision process depends upon when the submission is received in relation to the Committee's meeting schedule. Delays may also occur if the Committee requires further information from the applicant before making its recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —These statistics show conclusively that Senator Puplick's contention cannot be supported.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to endorse the remarks made when he tabled this report and to congratulate him on the tabling of his first Chairman's annual report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. As the Whips are aware, it is not easy to get members to serve on this Committee. If one looks at the report one will see why. The Committee is involved in scrutinising delegated legislation and we are currently scrutinising about a thousand instruments of delegated legislation every year.

SPEECH.PARA: While only a small proportion of those attract our detailed attention, they must all be read and appraised. For that the Committee is indebted to its legal advisor. For that the Committee is indebted to its legal advisor, Professor Douglas Whalan of the Australian National University, to the Committee Secretary, Mr Peter O'Keefe, and to his staff for the gruelling preliminary work they do in sifting through the regulations, ordinances and other instruments on behalf of the Committee. Secondly, the Committee is by tradition and by practice a non-partisan committee on which senators are asked to temporarily suppress the party political instincts and skills which are very important to any senator, but membership of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is in fact a self-denying ordinance for Government senators as well as Opposition senators. It is really that matter that I wish to raise before the Senate.

Government senators, as well as Opposition senators, have to look at the legislation without adopting a party political prejudice. That, of course, creates great difficulty because the application of the principles of this Committee cannot survive the interference of party political intrigue, advantage or pressure. The Committee meets each Thursday at 9 a.m. in committee room 6 and when we walk in there each member of the Committee in fact is expected to abandon his or her party political prejudice and it is my belief that we manage to do so. I congratulate Government senators for adopting the attitude of abandoning their party political prejudice when they come into that committee room. I recognise the difficulties which they have. I know only too well from our term in government that sometimes Ministers responsible for the making of delegated legislation mistakenly view the Committee's scrutiny as a threat to the political confidence which they seek to enjoy, in particular from senators of their own party. It is no such threat and it should not be seen as such. That is why I am supporting these remarks of Senator Cooney.

In its more than 50 years of experience, the Committee has, to the best of my knowledge, never permitted itself to question the policy behind delegated legislation or the political reasons for its enactment. There may well be a need for a regulations merits committee to probe policies but that is not and has never been the Committee's role. The Committee, with a low-key profile and style, seeks to apply standards of agreed principles to delegated legislation and through moral suasion of its bipartisanship, to persuade Ministers to amend instruments to remove possible infringements on personal rights or insert better or clearer protections of those rights.

It is worth reminding the Senate that the Committee has never lost a disallowance debate which a Minister's intransigence or obstinacy has forced upon it, and that is no mean record. The senator who is chairman of such a committee has a very difficult task of chairmanship, of preserving the bipartisanship of the Committee, of fostering and maintaining the confidence of this chamber in the work of the Committee while still retaining the respect and trust of his ministerial party colleagues. Senator Coates, the former chairman of this Committee under this Government, did that and now Senator Cooney is doing the same. I applaud them for their commitment.

Senators who read the Committee's report will see why 50 years on it is still necessary that the Senate should possess this world renowned committee, its oldest and, because of the Acts Interpretation Act, thankfully one of the most powerful committees of its kind in the Westminster world. The protective safety net of the Committee's scrutiny and its disallowance power can prevent objectionable provisions appearing or trends developing in legislation which, accumulated over time, could have serious effects on the form of parliamentary democracy and on the kinds of personal rights which we all value in a bipartisan way. Like Senator Cooney I, too, urge the Ministers of this Government to read the report so that when drafting delegated legislation they can take into account the principles which the Committee, with the support of this Chamber, applies to legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the matter before the Chair because it raises in my mind the period I spent on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The short time I spent on that Committee made me realise just how important the Committee was in view of the mass of delegated legislation or regulation that was being enacted by the bureaucracy. The scrutiny of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee made certain that the rights of citizens were not in any way affronted. In spite of my experiences on many other committees, I endorse what has been said, and I would consider the Regulations and Ordinances Committee to be the most important committee in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Too often by regulation the rights of citizens are taken away; too often by regulation the bureaucracy imposes certain limitations or restrictions which limit the rights of citizens but advance its own interests. During the period I served on this Committee I came to learn, even though I had no legal training, that a lay person could contribute considerably, together with people with the legal skills that were displayed by some members of the Committee. One person in particular who served extremely well on that Committee and who had no legal background, and in fact very little educational background, because of the period in which he grew up, was Senator Cavanagh. His role on that Committee and in this place was quite precise, incisive and revealing to the rest of the Senate.

There is a tendency in some omnibus legislation that comes through this place-and I wanted the opinion to be expressed by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee-to lumber together a whole series of bureaucratic decisions, and this passes through the Parliament without proper scrutiny. Just one small example would be the way in which parking fees were increased from $10 to $25 at airports throughout Australia, without proper announcement and without proper display at the airports of information to the effect that parking fees for vehicles had risen from $10 to $25-a massive increase, although it is only a small amount in itself. That was done by legislation which, I would take it, bypassed the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, because it was so done. Nevertheless, it means that there is now a device by which a considerable amount of enactment can take place without the proper scrutiny of the Parliament because such measures can be hidden in a multitude of decisions which the bureaucracy wants to impose upon us.

I use the word `bureaucracy', and that may, in the minds of some, be an offensive term to use. But it is the correct term when one is attempting to encompass the whole of the Public Service. Many governments, many styles of government and many systems of government suffer by virtue of the extreme power which the bureaucracy can impose. In this place, it imposes by way of regulation. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee prevents this; it limits it. I am pleased to see that it has brought down a report which exposes another way in which the bureaucracy, through the Executive, through Ministers, has imposed its will-that is, by delay in bringing down regulations and delay in responding to the requests of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

I am pleased that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is insisting upon its status, upon its position and its responsibility to the Senate. I am pleased that that is so because if it does not do so honourable senators can rest assured that it will be snowed, and that devices will be created which, on the basis of a lack of attention on the part of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, will enable the Public Service and the Executive to escape. If they escape once they will escape again. Once the pattern is developed, of course, they will exert their influence and achieve what they need.

I strongly support this report which has been brought down. It is not before time that we give to our committees the recognition that they deserve. Two reports have come down in the last half an hour, one from a standing committee and one from the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, and there is another one to follow. What I object to, in a way, is that through the changes in our Standing Orders we have somehow truncated our rights as a Senate to fully debate a subject. Through my speaking for 10 minutes on this report I deprive honourable senators who follow me. Of course, this is not deliberate. It is not because the report that happens to follow is the report on dolphins and whales in captivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get on to the dolphin report.
—I am certain that the honourable senator does. This is not deliberate on my part.
—Stop filibustering.

—Surely the honourable senator is not accusing me of filibustering on such an important report from the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I mean exactly what I say. I take the opportunity to say that the Standing Orders need to be reviewed to ensure that time is made available to fully debate important reports which come before this Senate. The Senate can have a committee-as it does-which sits for 18 months to two years on a reference and the members of that committee suddenly find that they have merely 10 minutes in which to contribute to the Senate, after two years of effort. The only way that we now manage to get a reasonable debate is by continuing from Wednesday to Wednesday with sharp bursts. I would say that that is not the way in which we should consider these reports and it is not the way in which we should consider this particular report from this particular Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Dolphins and Whales in Captivity

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Conservation issues are always two-sided. On the one hand, we have the need of society to conserve resources, environment, heritage, or the natural cohabitants of our world. On the other hand, we have the cost to society of this conservation, or the cost to be borne by certain individuals or corporations in the form of anticipated profits forgone or the extra costs incurred. The final cost in every situation depends heavily on the `politically perceived balance of public interest',-namely where the cost is seen to outweigh the advantages, no action should be taken; where the advantage of conservation is seen to be highly in the public interest while the threatening activity has no public justification, that threatening activity should be either banned or regulated in the public interest. Where both sides are seen to have merit in the public interest, part of the costs of conservation may be borne by taxpayers to enable the activity to continue while measures are installed to prevent damage to our environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of humankind's effect on its environment is unfortunately very ugly. We have taken over huge tracts of land and sea for our cities, farms, transport, mining and hunting enterprises. We have hunted and killed and are responsible for the complete annihilation of a multitude of species of animals and plants to such an extent that we have endangered our own survival on this planet. Most of this damage has happened and is happening through ignorance. It is ignorance which destroys the habitats of certain native animals. It is ignorance which destroys trees. It is ignorance which makes us do many of the things that eventually will harm us. As we learn of the risks, we take measures to avoid them. It is in this light that I commend the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare for bringing under public scrutiny accepted practices in our society which are needlessly cruel in the light of current knowledge.

Cetacea have long been needlessly exploited. Their inherent curiosity and intelligence and previous immunity from danger within the seas have led them unwittingly to expose themselves to human exploitation. Only seven years ago the Cheynes Beach whaling station at Albany, Western Australia, was still killing 700 sperm whales a year, which was its `quota' under the International Whaling Commission. The Frost report on `Whales and Whaling' suggested that the issue of whaling licences be banned except for a `licence to take, in appropriate circumstances, a limited number of dolphins live for display purposes'. It recommended that only in special circumstances should a permit be issued to take any cetacea for scientific purposes. That resulted in Parliament, in 1980, passing the Whale Protection Act in exactly those terms.

As a result of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, to which Australia is a signatory, Parliament later passed the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 which forbids the import of all species of the order cetacea-that is, whales, dolphins and porpoises-`except in exceptional circumstances where the proposed import is being transferred between zoos, is born in captivity or is for the purpose of prescribed scientific research'.

Thus, the earlier Whale Protection Act allows the taking of dolphins and whales in Australian waters for display or for scientific and educational purposes; but the later Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act of 1982 prohibits totally their import and export.

In the light of the current Select Committee's findings, this discrepancy needs to be addressed. The Whale Protection Act 1980 should now be amended to prohibit the taking of cetacea in Australian waters. State laws in some cases override Commonwealth laws, particularly within the three-mile limit. State laws vary from State to State. In order to address this, the Committee's recommendation to ban new establishments for keeping cetacea in captivity will shut off the demand for the capture of dolphins and whales and allow the States to introduce laws to match the Commonwealth's laws on this issue. The Australian Democrats support the Select Committee in all its findings. We look to the Government for changes in the legislation as soon as possible to implement these findings in the `very near future'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek a ruling from you, Mr Deputy President--
—Senator Georges, if you speak you will be closing the debate. I cannot call you, in the circumstances.
—The problem is that we have had a whole series of speakers, particularly from one party, on this matter and the debate is now getting out of kilter.
—Does that mean that your Party is not interested in the subject?
—It is not that. If I might reply to the interjection, the National Party has a particular interest in this matter and is participating--
—Order! Senator Georges, I cannot call you because if I do so you will be closing the debate, and other honourable senators wish to speak.
—But what, Mr Deputy President, if I insist?
—I will not call you. I call Senator Sheil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I had one of the most memorable experiences of my life, which was to go swimming with whales and dolphins. I do not think Senator Georges would have done anything like that in his life. The reason I wound up swimming with these whales and dolphins was that the manager of Sea World on the Gold Coast got in touch with me because of his apprehension about the results of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare that has been brought down. He asked me to come over and inspect the facilities and animals there and draw my own conclusions. I was surprised to find that the Chairman of the Committee had not even been there. He had been invited to Sea World but he had not even been to have a look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: When one gets in the water with these animals there is an initial feeling of apprehension because they have big teeth. However, they were immediately friendly and got on very well with me. They want to play with you. They take you for swims. They are interested in you. They certainly do not want to hurt you. They show a great affinity and friendship with man.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one reason why you don't keep them in captivity.

—There is a lot of history to whales and porpoises and their association with man which goes back, I suppose, to Jonah. I remember that one of the books I read when I was a young fellow was The Killers of Eden. I find that the Committee has not been to Eden to look at the skeletons of those killer whales.
—I have been there.
—Senator Sanders is not on the Committee. Those whales showed a great affinity with man.
—But they were not in captivity.

—Ease up. The report is on whales and dolphins in captivity, not on whales out wherever the the honourable senator says they were. I remember stories we used to hear about Pelorus Jack. He was the porpoise which used to guide the ships around Wellington and Cook Strait. While he was taking the ships in there were never any accidents, but he was accidently shot. Since then there have been dreadful accidents. The Wahine was sunk and recently a Russian ship was sunk there.

SPEECH.PARA: The report brings down about a dozen recommendations. Most of them are fairly commonsense recommendations and can be agreed with. However, three of them are very way out. They recommend that we do not catch any more dolphins, that we do not import any more dolphins and that we gradually phase out the dolphin areas we have unless scientific evidence can be shown that they should be kept, and things like that. Those recommendations cannot be supported by the evidence the Committee took.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very well supported-and by experts around the world, I might add.

—Senator Sanders's experts, not mine. Let us consider the number of dolphins. For example, what about the recommendation that we do not catch, experiment with or research other species of dolphins? There are many species of dolphins. Some of them roam the whole world. Some of them are specific to a particular ocean, some of them to a particular part of an ocean. There are dolpins that are specific to rivers, such as the Ganges, the Indus, the Yangtze Kiang and the Amazon. These dolphins may present enormous opportunities-both for us and for them. Unless dolphins are caught and kept in captivity there will be very little opportunity for any research into them. The research is important to them and us. It has been said that keeping them in captivity renders them mute and prone to stress effects and other adverse conditions. I did not find anything like that at Sea World. In fact, if one put one's head under the water and listened one would hear an enormous amount of conversation going on, not only between the dolphins but also between dolphins and whales. They certainly did not show any signs of stress and they were friendly.
—What are their views on the Bjelke-Petersen Government?

—They would have been very happy with that. I found no evidence that they had been rendered mute or were stressed in any way. They seemed to me to be very happy. Honourable senators cannot tell me that three dolphins will stick together and let a guy ride them like a Roman chariot if they are not happy. They would have him off in no time. In fact, when I was riding them, if it looked as though I would fall off, they made sure that I would not. They would roll back under me to see that I did not-unlike a horse, for example. While I am on that subject, I can imagine what would happen if the first Stone Age man was not allowed to pat the first wolf or horse that showed signs of being friendly. They are now domesticated. Dolphins can be used for servicing divers and for research on the ocean floor.
—To carry bombs to plant on ships in a naval war.

—I have heard of naval uses where they can put limpet bombs on ships-enemy ships, I hope. I do not see why we should not be allowed to serve each other when the relationship between us is so good. I hope that when the Senate is considering the report and when the Government is considering legislation they will take no notice of these three recommendations. I go even further than the recommendations in the dissenting report because we should be able to import dolphins. Just because we are breeding them in captivity does not mean that we should not take advantage of all the other species in the world that may be of even greater value to us as we journey through our lives together.
—Order! The time for consideration of committee reports has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on a matter that has been raised several times. Senator Sheil commented that I had not visited Sea World--
—Have you?
—No, I have not visited Sea World.
—How have you been misrepresented if you have not been there? You have been invited.
—The honourable senator is endeavouring to discredit the report by discrediting me because I have not visited Sea World. I will bring the honourable senator up to date.
—You were not invited?

—I have been invited by Mr Lawrence to visit Sea World at an opportune time. I have had discussions with Mr George Smith, who represents Sea World. I have made arrangements to see him because he has sought my advice on what is necessary to meet the requirements of the report. I have agreed to that. The attempt to discredit the Chairman of this Committee by members of the National Party and others--
—I take a point of order. At no time has the National Party tried to discredit Senator Georges.
—That is not a point of order. Nevertheless, Senator Georges, you must stick to the personal explanation and not criticise other senators.

—I am. A charge was made by someone on radio that I had received five invitations and had declined the five. That is not the case. I wish this to be brought to an end. I have had a request from Mr Smith, who represents Sea World, to visit it. That will be done at the earliest opportunity. But the misrepresentation goes further. The inference is that the Committee did not visit Sea World. That is incorrect. The Committee visited Sea World, engaged in lengthy correspondence and received considerable information from Sea World which is included in the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Proposed Work in the Parliamentary Zone

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President and for the information of honourable senators, I table the report from the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House on the proposed construction of the National Bicentennial Science Centre within the parliamentary zone.
