DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report of 1986 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Air Navigation Amendment Bill 1986. I also lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 5, 9 April 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventy-eighth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on its scrutiny of the Artificial Conception Ordinance 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Artificial Conception Ordinance deals with the status of children born by the use of artificial conception techniques. Under the Ordinance, a woman who gives birth to a child is, for all purposes, conclusively presumed to be the mother of that child, regardless of the biological history of the child. The man with whom the woman has a bona fide domestic relationship is, for all purposes, conclusively presumed to be the father of that child, regardless of its biological origin and provided only that he has consented to his partner's involvement. A man who donates semen and who is not in a bona fide domestic relationship with the woman who becomes pregnant as a result of that semen is, for all purposes, conclusively presumed not to be the father of the child.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee is concerned about this Ordinance when considered against the criteria that it applies. The criteria relate to issues involving civil rights and the appropriate vehicle for legislative change. Having considered the Ordinance and the correspondence from the responsible Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Committee has decided not to recommend disallowance of the instrument under its criteria. However, the Committee considers that the Ordinance is of such a nature and the issues it raises are of such importance that it should table a report on the legislation in the Senate. The Committee wishes to alert the Senate to the fact that the Ordinance affects the rights of children, of parents and of donors of genetic material. It is to be noted that the issues raised have been debated in this chamber and will be debated again in the future particularly when the Human Embyro Experimentation Bill is brought before the Senate.

In the course of the Committee's correspondence with the Attorney-General the Committee gave notice of motion of disallowance of the Ordinance while it examined the issues. This morning the Committee agreed that I give notice of intention to withdraw that notice of motion tomorrow. This may give honourable senators an opportunity to consider the Committee's report. The Committee wanted me to draw the attention of the Senate to two other Australian Capital Territory ordinances. These are the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 5) 1985 and the Evidence (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1985. These ordinances make major changes to the Australian Capital Territory law relating to sexual offences. The Committee does not recommend that any action be taken against these ordinances but it considers that the attention of the Senate should be drawn to them. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's exchange of correspondence with the Attorney-General.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
18 February 1986
The Hon. Lionel Bowen, M.P.
Attorney-General,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Attorney-General,

At its meeting on 13 February 1986 the Committee considered the Evidence (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1985 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 61 of 1985 tabled in the Senate on 3 December 1985) and the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 5) 1985 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 62 of 1985 tabled in the Senate on 3 December 1985).

The Committee notes that these Ordinances make quite fundamental changes to the rules concerning the giving of evidence in sexual offence proceedings and in relation to the substance of the law of rape and other sexual offences in the A.C.T.
In the Evidence (Amendment) Ordinance the following points may be noted-
the accused may no longer seek to adduce evidence relating to the making or terms of a complaint by the complainant;
the court may direct that the proceedings be in camera;
the complainant's identity shall not be disclosed without the complainant's consent;
the judge need no longer warn a jury that it is unsafe to convict a person accused of a sexual offence on the uncorroborated evidence of the complainant.
an accused no longer has a right to adduce evidence relating to the sexual reputation of the complainant. Admission of such evidence is subject to the judge's discretion; and
in an unsworn statement from the dock the accused may not refer to the complainant's sexual reputation or experience.
In the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance the following points may be noted-
the crime of rape as conventionally understood has been abolished; sexual offences have been significantly reduced and rationalised;
sexual intercourse is given a very wide meaning, much of it unrelated to its conventional meaning;
from the point of view of consent, sexual intercourse is viewed as a continuing act but of divisible or severable components which permit consent to be withdrawn at any time;
penalties of up to 20 years imprisonment are imposed;

consent to prima facie voluntary sexual intercourse is to be negated by inter alia ``mistaken belief as to the identity of the person'' and ``a fraudulent misrepresentation of any fact made by the other person''.
the presumption that young people below a certain age are incapable of engaging in sexual intercourse is abolished;
marriage will no longer be a bar to an accusation of and conviction for offences related to sexual intercourse.

The Committee notes that these Ordinances make quite fundamental changes in the criminal law of the A.C.T. with regard to the very serious and very difficult area of sexual offences. On their own these Ordinances are highly significant. However, one of the Ordinances is the 5th in a sequence of Crimes (Amendment) Ordinances. If these and the Evidence (Amendment) Ordinance had come before the Committee (or the community) in one document as a virtual criminal demi-code instead of piece-meal over the past year, it would be clearly seen that a major recodification of A.C.T. criminal law had been undertaken by ministerial instrument without the community, the committee, or the Parliament having an opportunity to consider the scheme as a whole in the light of the accumulated innovations which it reflects.

The Committee notes that with respect to the two Ordinances presently under examination the Explanatory Statement makes no reference to there having been any consultations with the A.C.T. House of Assembly, or the Local Criminal Law Consultative Committee. This may be merely an oversight from the Statement rather than a reflection of any failure to consult. The Committee would welcome your description of the extent to which consultations across the community and the legal profession pointed to agreement on these major proposals which have now become law without Parliamentary debate or sanction.

The Committee notes that in making these Ordinances you have placed considerable reliance on the Tasmanian Law Reform Commission Report No. 31 on Rape and Sexual Offences (No. 84, 1982) although there are a number of other published authoritative reports on sexual crimes which have made recommendations somewhat at variance with some of those in Report No. 31 (for example, in connections with the abolition of the common law offence of rape). The Committee seeks your advice on whether, after full parliamentary debate, the Tasmanian Legislative Assembly implemented the recommendations of its own law reform experts.

As you will be aware Principle (d) of the Committee's terms of reference requires it to scrutinise delegated legislation to ensure that it does not contain matter more appropriate for Parliamentary enactment. Given that there are few areas of law socially or politically more significant than criminal law the progressive promulgation of what may reasonably be seen as a criminal code (including sexual offences and property offences) must give the Committee pause in considering the application of Principle (d) to these Ordinances.

The Committee would be very grateful to have your comments and advice on these matters in particular whether any consideration was given to bringing these two far reaching reform proposals before the Parliament.
Yours sincerely,
Barney Cooney
Chairman
Deputy Prime Minister
Attorney-General
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600
4 March 1986
Dear Barney,

I refer to your letter of 18 February 1986 concerning the Evidence (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1985 and the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 5) 1985, a comprehensive review of the ACT laws relating to sexual offences.

These Ordinances form part of the program of reform of the criminal laws of the ACT, which my predecessor began in September 1983. The importance of a review of the criminal law was emphasised by (the then) Chief Justice Blackburn on 6 July 1983 in the case of Queen v Sykes when he said,
`the criminal law of this Territory is to a degree which is scandalous, in need of review, and all Judges of this court have been saying so for twelve years to my knowledge'.

The reform of the criminal law of the ACT has been undertaken in two parts. The first part, now substantially completed, involved a tidying up of archaic or non operative provisions as well as adopting some desirable reforms made interstate. The second part involves substantial reform of the laws covering particular classes of offences. So far, two Divisions of the Crimes Act 1900 (NSW) in its application to the ACT, have been the subject of such substantial review. The first was a review of property offences, which was implemented by the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1985. The second was the review of sexual offences, implemented by the two Ordinances under discussion. Therefore, although there have been five Crimes (Amendment) Ordinances during 1985, only two of these implement reviews of laws covering the whole of particular class of offences.

The programme for ACT criminal law reform certainly involves review, and, where appropriate, revision, of the whole of the Crimes Act, 1900 NSW in its application to the ACT. However, it should be noted that that Act, in its application to the ACT, is not a code. It is not technically correct, therefore, to refer to the programme as ``a major recodification''. In all non-code jurisdictions, including the ACT, nearly all the criminal law is contained in legislation: this has been the situation for most, if not all, of this century.

You have expressed concern over the extent of consultation on the two Ordinances. I would point out that these Ordinances were given extensive consideration both by the ACT Criminal Law Consultative Committee and the ACT House of Assembly. The Committee considered these reforms not only at one of its ordinary meetings, but also at two specifically convened extraordinary meetings. Late in 1984, the draft ordinances were referred to the ACT House of Assembly which requested its Standing Committee on Finance and Legislation to consider them. That Committee presented a report to the House of Assembly in September 1985. It recommended that the Ordinances be agreed to, subject to certain minor amendments. The Ordinances were subsequently amended in accordance with these recommendations. I would also point out that the Office of the Status of Women was fully consulted at the outset and supported the proposals. I understand that the Office of Status of Women also undertook wide consultation amongst interested groups within the community.

In preparing the draft Ordinances, consideration was given to the Tasmanian Law Reform Commission report No 31 on Rape and Sexual offences. Consideration was also given to recent reforms that had been implemented in NSW and VIC., together with reports from other Australian and foreign jurisdictions. As to your request for advice on whether the Tasmanian Legislative Assembly has implemented the recommendations of the above report I have been advised that while no legislation has been enacted giving effect to the recommendations a draft Bill is currently being prepared for consideration by the Tasmanian Government containing provisions that will give effect to some of the recommendations of the Commission, namely
providing that a husband can be found guilty of the crime of rape against his wife, where the parties were not cohabiting at the time of the offence;
removing the presumption that males under the age of fourteen could not commit rape;
providing for the suppression of names of victims, and offenders in incest cases.

In view of the wide consultation, I believe the two Ordinances cannot be regarded as falling into the same category as other delegated legislation made without prior reconsideration by elected representatives. As indicated in my letter of 4 December 1985, to your predecessor, concerning the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 3) 1985, if the ACT House of Assembly had had legislation making powers, this Ordinance would have been law by virtue of its unanimous passage by that House. As you are aware, the issue of self-government for the ACT is a very live and sensitive one, and it would not be appropriate for the criminal law of the ACT to be contained in a Commonwealth statute.
Yours sincerely,
(Lionel Bowen)
Senator Barney Cooney,

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of not only honourable senators but also all members of the House of Representatives-indeed all those who are listening-the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It is a most important report. It deals with the Artificial Conception Ordinance 1985 of the Australian Capital Territory. The only people who are really affected by this Ordinance are the people of the Australian Capital Territory so the legislation is being enacted by way of ordinance, not legislation. Thus the matter has not come before the House of Representatives or the Senate for debate but it is a matter of national significance. The seventieth report of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances of June 1981 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is concerned to establish a mechanism whereby the attention of the Senate may be drawn to a matter which, while not necessarily warranting disallowance under the Committee's principles, is nonetheless of such significance as to merit substantive discussion in the Senate . . .

This is a matter of such significance that it warrants consideration by all honourable senators and debate in this chamber, indeed debate nation-wide. I draw honourable senators' attention to the measure which deals with what happens in regard to paternity, what happens with regard to maternity, what happens in relation to donated semen and, in particular, to the fact that the secrecy of the donor of semen is not protected. I am not sure whether that should be so but I will say this: It is my firm belief that anyone who donates semen in the 1980s and does not believe that around 20 years later, when the children are grown up, they will want to know who their father was, will have a tremendous shock. In 20 years time there is no doubt that the children will want to know who the donor of the semen was. These are matters of national significance and national importance which warrant not only debate but also the best brains of this Parliament to consider what is important and what should be borne in mind. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-
BUILDERS LABOURERS' FEDERATION (CANCELLATION OF REGISTRATION) BILL 1986

This Bill and another Consequential Bill, which I will shortly introduce, provide for the cancellation forthwith of the registration of the BLF and consequential measures which flow from that action, including the re-allocation of BLF work coverage to other registered unions.
Immediate legislation to achieve these objectives has become necessary because of the intolerable situation with which the industry is faced as a result of the actions of the BLF.

On 20 August 1985, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations introduced the Building Industry Bill into the Parliament and in doing so set out the reasons why the Government concluded there was no other course than to deal with the BLF as proposed in the Bill.

At that time it was clear to the Government that the BLF had established an unparalleled pattern of broken industrial agreements and undertakings and that, through its industrial excesses, it had set itself apart from the mainstream of the trade union movement generally and also from other building industry unions.

The Minister went to some lengths to outline the considerable steps which this Government had taken since coming to office to deal within the established industrial relations framework with the problems posed by the BLF. However, efforts by the Government, employers and the trade union movement to achieve a permanent resolution to the problems were repudiated at every turn by the BLF.

It was against this background and the immense damage being done not only to the industry, but also to the job security of building workers, by the actions of the BLF, that the Government decided it had no alternative but to pursue the course of action set out in the Building Industry Bill.

Accordingly, following the passage of the Building Industry Act, the Minister applied on 6 September 1985 to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a declaration under the Act. He sought a declaration that the BLF had engaged in conduct which contravened agreements or undertakings to which it was a party, which seriously hindered or prevented the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or which was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration.
In short, Mr President, the Full Bench was asked to consider whether the BLF had engaged in conduct which threatened the very basis of our present system of industrial relations.
The Minister's application was duly dealt with by a Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which handed down its decision last Friday.

I should add that the Government's application was supported by the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria, by the Confederation of Australian Industry and by building employers through the Australian Confederation of Construction Contractors and the Master Builders Federation of Australia.

This support for the Government's application emphasises the extent of concern within the community at the behaviour of the BLF and the damage its actions have inflicted on the building industry and on the economy.

Because of the serious consequences of the action under the Building Industry Act the Government was most concerned that the Builders Labourers' Federation should receive every opportunity to know in detail what the Government alleged against it and to answer those allegations. The Act made such provision and there were extensive proceedings before the Commission.

These proceedings occupied 56 sitting days and covered 4500 pages of transcript. Counsel representing the Government tendered 298 exhibits to demonstrate to the Full Bench that the BLF's conduct was such as to warrant the making of a declaration. The BLF itself tendered 105 exhibits, was represented by 4 counsel-including 2 QC's-and called 75 witnesses and evidence from all States, including the ACT.
On 4 April, the Full Bench issued the declaration which the Government had sought.
In doing so, the Full Bench concluded that:

`It has been established beyond question that the Builders Labourers' Federation has rejected the standards of behaviour accepted by most trade unions in Australia. The Federation has no standards as that word is commonly understood, but reacts to events according to the view taken at the time by the Federal Management Committee. Instead of a rational policy designed to advance the interests of the members, the Federal Management Committee is addicted to slogans.'
The Full Bench went on to say that:

`It is under such archaic banners that the Federal Management Committee has waged its campaigns, leading the rank and file from one disaster to the next. The efforts of the Leaders have caused hardship to other workers and aroused the hostility of the other building unions. Builders labourers have been deprived of National Wage Case increases until long after other Australian workers have received that benefit; the excesses of the leadership have taken the Federation so far outside conventional trade union activity that it has been expelled by the Labour Council of New South Wales. As our review of the evidence has shown, the activities of the Federation have brought extensive dislocation to the building industry.
The case against the Builders Labourers' Federation is overwhelming.'

The declaration made by the Full Bench illustrates the breadth of the Federation's disregard for normal standards of industrial behaviour. The declaration specifies numerous fundamental breaches by the BLF of agreements and undertakings regarding its conduct within the Federal system. These include breaches of undertakings the BLF gave to the Industrial Registrar, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, employers and of industry agreements.

Those breaches were the result of many instances of extremely damaging industrial action which led the Full Bench to declare that the BLF had prevented or seriously hindered the achievement of objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and had engaged in conduct that was inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by means of Conciliation and Arbitration.

Even while the hearing was before the Commission, the union showed its complete contempt for the Commission, and its disregard for its undertakings, by pursuing claims that were patently in breach of the National Wage principles and by backing those claims with widespread industrial action.
The consequences of that action were very serious indeed.

For example, many building sites in every Australian State have been affected by strikes, bans and threats in pursuit of claims for the 3.8% National Wage increase, other wage claims, implementation of a shorter working week and payment for time on strike.
As a consequence of these actions major projects have been held up and fellow building workers have been stood down and their livelihood jeopardised.

The BLF, by its actions during and immediately after the hearing, has led the Government to the view that immediate measures are needed so that the Federation should no longer remain a registered organisation. The Federation has continued to flaunt every accepted convention on which the Australian system of industrial relations depends and its guerilla tactics, industrial blackmail and intimidation are an anathema to the vast majority of trade unionists.

A clear illustration of the BLF's total contempt for the system is seen from the fact that on the very day that the Full Bench's decision was handed down, more than one hundred sites in NSW and Victoria alone were subject to bans in support of various BLF claim with no regard to the normal processes of dispute settlement through conciliation and arbitration.

The Government cannot allow the threat to the Australian Conciliation and arbitration system, to the building industry and to its workers posed by the behaviour of the BLF to continue. It cannot allow one organisation to disregard utterly the accepted processes of dispute settlement and prevent the establishment of a strong efficient building industry, which can make a major contribution to economic and employment growth in Australia.
The stage has now been reached where:

After a very lengthy hearing, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has made a declaration based on a careful and thorough examination of the evidence before it. That decision is a damning indictment of the BLF's behaviour;

time and time again, the BLF has shown it will not mend its ways and that it has no respect for the processes of conciliation and arbitration or the system which enables it to enjoy the status and benefits of a registered organisation;
the BLF has lost the support of the trade union movement as a whole;
the building industry continues to be seriously disrupted by the BLF's industrial action and faces the prospect of further sustained attack; and
the system itself continues to be under serious challenge.

The union is clearly only interested in using every available avenue to threaten, intimidate, coerce and weaken the resolve of all those engaged in the building industry to resist unreasonable demands by the BLF while it remains registered and enjoys the privileges and protection of the system.

In these circumstances the Government has decided that the responsible course is to immediately cancel the registration of the Federation. This means that the BLF will no longer be a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act anywhere in Australia. The Bill I have now introduced will have that effect.

Without immediate action, the BLF will undoubtedly do everything in its power to string out for many months final resolution of proceedings under the Building Industry Act in relation to it and, at the same time, place massive industrial pressure on employers not to support the Government's action.

The BLF has no right to the protection of the system whilst at the same time it seems intent on destroying the system. Registration under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act does not confer only rights and privileges but also involves obligations to behave responsibly and in a manner consistent with the objects of the Act.

Mr President, I must emphasise that the action which this Government has already taken in relation to the BLF and what is proposed now is not intended as an attack on ordinary builders labourers. It is the leadership of the Federation which cannot be trusted and which, as the Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission said, has led the rank and file from one disaster to another.

The Government will be concerned to ensure that the jobs and conditions of individual labourers are protected and that they are able to join appropriate federally registered unions with coverage of their work and which will properly represent their interests. It is essential in the interests of the workers concerned and the system of conciliation and arbitration that they should be able to be represented and enjoy the protection of their conditions of employment by awards and agreements secured under that system.

Employers will have a vital role to play under the new arrangements. They will have to ensure that the rights of labourers prepared to work normally are maintained. In addition, builders will have to be prepared to stand firm against efforts of the BLF to maintain its place in the industry. The Government will be looking to employers to remain united in support of our action.

I should add that the code of conduct to which the employers are required to adhere will be maintained and any employer seeking to deal with the deregistered BLF will risk exclusion from government contracts.

Furthermore, should it prove to be necessary, the Government, with the co-operation of the State governments, stands ready to ensure the maintenance of order so that workers wanting to get on with their jobs in the industry will be able to do so without interference, threat or coercion.

Mr President, the terms of this Bill are simple. Honourable Senators will note that its preamble places emphasis on the public interest in preserving the system of Conciliation and Arbitration. The proceedings before the Commission, the Commission's findings, and the BLF's continuing misconduct demonstrate conclusively how serious a threat to that system the BLF has been. Flowing from that and from the concerns I have expressed, the Bill goes on to declare that, upon its becoming law, the registration of the BLF will forthwith be cancelled.
Mr President, this is a step which the Government is taking as a last resort and after the Government has shown great forebearance and patience in exploring all reasonable alternatives.

However, the BLF has shunned every effort to resolve this matter within the established industrial relations processes and has alienated itself from virtually all other groups within the community, including the trade union movement.
The BLF's activities have been condemned by other building unions, have led to its expulsion from the NSW Trades and Labour Council and caused the ACTU to declare that it cannot support the BLF.

The circumstances confronting us are therefore unique in the history of the nation and they require a unique solution. It is in that context that the Government has decided to take the serious action contained in this Bill.

Such action is essential to preserve the future of the building industry, to establish rational industrial relations behaviour in that industry, to protect the national wage fixing principles, and to preserve the authority of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
Most of all, this legislation is essential to secure the preservation of the federal system of prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BUILDERS LABOURERS' FEDERATION (CANCELLION OF REGISTRATION-CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

I have in my second reading speech on the Builders Labourers' Federation (Cancellation of Registration) Bill 1986 explained why the Government has decided to take action which will result in the immediate de-registration of the Federation as a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
This Bill which deals with three important areas that are consequential upon the cancellation of the Federation's registration, is expressed to come into operation when that occurs.

These areas relate firstly to the consequences of the Federation's de-registration, secondly, to the question of the registration in the future of the Federation or a similar body, and thirdly, to the coverage by federally registered unions of work which was covered by the federation before the cancellation of its registration.
I shall address each of these areas in turn.

Clause 4 of the Bill provides for the consequences of the Federation's registration. Important elements of this provision relate to operation of awards and access to the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration machinery. It provides that no award applying to the Federation or its members will have any force or effect in relation to them.

The clause also provides that the de-registered federation, or any association of members or former members of the federation formed in relation to the building industry, will not be able to participate in proceedings before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or be a party to an award made by the Commission. Furthermore, the Commission will not have jurisdiction over industrial disputes brought about by such bodies or their members, or by employers who are in dispute with them.

The provision makes it clear, however, that the commission is not denied jurisdiction over disputes between an employer and a registered union in relation to any of its members who may not have relinquished their membership of the federation or of some other association in the industry formed by the members or former members of the Federation. This is necessary so that Federation members who join registered unions before they cease to be members of the federation have access to the federal dispute settlement procedures and awards as members of such registered unions.

The second significant area of the Bill concerns the future registration of the Federation. The Government believes that it would be entirely inappropriate for the Federation to be able to re-apply for registration immediately after its registration has been cancelled.

Honourable senators need only reflect on the Federation's conduct after it was registered again in 1976 after being de-registered in 1974. Despite undertakings about its industrial behaviour and adherence to the process of conciliation and arbitration, it demonstrated within months of re-registration that it had no intention of abiding by those undertakings. Its subsequent conduct showed how little the obligations of a registered union meant to it. I refer honourable senators to last week's decision of the Full Bench of the Commission to make a declaration under the Ruling Industry Act for a clear exposition of the appalling history of the Federation's conduct after it was so re-registered.

The Government therefore believes that a reasonable period should be set before the Federation can apply to be registered again. We consider that 3 years is the minimum period in which stability can be restored to the building industry without the presence of the federation as a federally registered union. Such a period is provided for in clause 5.

Furthermore, the Government believes that the Federation should not be capable of registration again unless it is prepared to behave responsibly as a registered organisation. Accordingly, clause 5 also contains a requirement that a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission must be satisfied that the Federation would not, if registered, engage in conduct inimical to the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by means of conciliation and arbitration, and that such registration would not prevent or seriously hinder the achievement of an object of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The other requirements of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as to registration will also apply, but any application for registration must also be dealt with by a Full Bench.
These requirements also extend to any association formed in the industry by members or former members of the Federation. This will prevent any attempt to sidestep the requirements as to registration.
The third important area of the proposed legislation relates to arrangements for federally registered unions to cover work of which the BLF had coverage when registered.

Clause 7 provides that regulations may be made to give federally registered unions coverage of work in the industry or in connection with which the Federation was registered. This can only be done with the consent of those unions. The regulations will declare persons who work in that industry to be eligible for membership of the consenting union. Such regulations may relate to work of specified kind in the industry or part of the industry, and in Australia generally or specified parts of Australia.

This is considered an essential measure to provide industrial peace in the industry, and to ensure that workers who are or were members of the Federation are able to be represented by responsible federally registered unions, to have disputes over their employment settled through the proper processes of conciliation and arbitration and to secure the protection of federal awards.

I wish to emphasise that no union will be compelled to accept an extension of its existing work coverage and the Government will be consulting fully with all interested parties to ensure that the most appropriate arrangements are made. It is not our intention that these arrangements should result in disruption to the existing work coverage of any federally registered unions.

Another important aspect of clause 7 is that these arrangements are intended to be of an interim nature until federally registered unions can alter their rules to cover such work. The regulations will therefore cease to operate to the extent that they are not consistent with any subsequent rule alterations made under the processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

Mr President, each of these elements of the Bill represents an important part of the Government's approach to securing the proper operation of the federal system of dispute settlement, and the achievement of better industrial relations in the building industry. I stress that this cannot be achieved without the best efforts of employers, unions and workers in that industry to strive for a permanent improvement in their industrial relationships. Australia cannot afford to continue to have a situation like that brought about by the conduct of the BLF.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I lay on the table explanatory notes from the Parliamentary Library, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Department of Education and the Australian Development Assistance Bureau on estimates of proposed additional expenditure for 1985-86.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise very briefly on the adjournment a matter which I would be grateful if the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who is at the table, would simply consent to take on notice and draw to the attention of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). It concerns the proposal by Australia Post to dump onto the Australian stamp market a large number-in fact $1m worth-of stamps from its own archival collection. For some time Australia Post has recognised the fact that it does not have a complete archival collection of early Australian postage stamps and for that purpose it has been seeking to build up its collection. The fact that it does not have a complete national collection of early Australian postage stamps is a reflection on what has been in the past the poor management and the poor planning undertaken by Australia Post. Therefore it has decided to raise the sum of approximately $1m and to do this for the purpose of allowing it to buy back into its own archival collection in order to establish a national collection which it should have maintained. I understand that it is interested in purchasing the collection of Ray Chapman, a former president of the Australian Stamp Dealers Association, which is reputed to be one of the most impressive private collections of stamps in Australia and may fill many of the gaps that Australia Post currently has in its national archival collection. However, in order to do so, Australia Post has decided to embark upon what is a most extraordinary way of financing, that is, by raising $1m or so by holding a series of auctions of material currently in its own archival collection.

SPEECH.PARA: One million dollars may not seem very much in the overall budget of Australia Post but it represents about 15 per cent of the annual turnover of all Australian stamp auctions. Therefore, it is within the framework of Australian stamp auctions not an insignificant amount. In particular, Australia Post proposes to put onto the market four types of postage stamps. They are the early kangaroos, some of the early decimals, the very famous five shilling Sydney Harbour Bridge stamps and sets of the Robes and Coat-of-Arms stamps. It is important to understand that these are not cheap items. For instance, if we look at the current Australian stamp catalogue, we will see that a #1 brown and blue first watermark 1913 Australian kangaroo stamp currently has a value of approximately $1,800; for one postage stamp that is a fair amount of money. The 10 shilling grey and pink first watermark 1913 can fetch anything between $750 and $1,500. The second watermark 1915 issue, the five shilling grey and yellow, sells for around $900. The third watermark 1915 Australian kangaroo stamp, a #2 stamp, is currently catalogued at $2,800 for a single stamp. The famous five shilling Harbour Bridge stamp of 1932, a five shilling green stamp, is in the catalogue at $650 but at the moment is retailing in Sydney for between $800 and $850. The Coat-of-Arms set, which is also proposed to be included in this collection of material, will cost perhaps $200 to $250. The coronation set, the so-called Robes set, will cost $150-odd.

Honourable senators may not think that dumping a small number of stamps on the market will have very much effect. But is is proposed that 60 of the five-shilling stamps, approximately 200 sets of the Robes and 130 sets of the Coat-of-Arms will be put on the market. We do not know how many of the kangaroo stamps will be put on the market-perhaps only a dozen, but maybe more. We know that in certain private collections, one of which I am aware in South Australia, some 60 stamps are held in the one collection. I know of one in Adelaide that has more than 600 kangaroo stamps, including a number of the #2 stamps.

I will give an example of the volatility of the market when a large number of stamps come on to it. In 1980, to buy a Coat-of-Arms set one would have had to pay approximately $450; now one can buy one for about $225. Some years ago the British post office, although not conducting an auction, acted by a quite improper dumping of stamps on the market, a matter for which a philatelic curator was subsequently suspended pending police investigation. The so-called De La Rue set of high value castles which is catalogued for approximately #515 sterling is currently available on the market in Sydney for somewhere in the vicinity of $320, which is a very considerable difference. That poisoning of the market has taken place quite simply because the United Kingdom post office allowed these stamps to come on to the market.

A number of people to whom I have spoken have indicated that perhaps one of the advantages of this will be that a large number of stamps will be bought by overseas collectors. In some respects that may be true but, in terms of the kangaroo stamps, it may also be that they will fall within the provisions of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill which has passed the House of Representatives and is awaiting consideration by the Senate. It is certainly true that there are a number of very rare stamps varieties which one would hope would not be exported from Australia following enactment of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. However, what I object to is that the Government, through Australia Post-I am sure the Government and the Minister have absolutely no knowledge of this matter-is making a decision to poison the market by offloading $1m worth at least of its privately held archival stock to what will in fact be the disadvantage of collectors, of people who had bought these items in reasonably good faith for investment purposes. People who are intimately concerned with the trade will find that they are now at risk because, in order to cover its previous failure to maintain an adequate archival collection, Australia Post now wants to take 15 per cent of the total stamp auction market and poison the market by in effect dumping a large number of additional sets of postage stamps on to the market. In the course of things that we deal with in this chamber, it is an extremely minor matter to a very large number of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad that Senator Button is prepared to acknowledge that it is only a minor matter. I am sure that the two million stamp collectors in Australia will be pleased to note that their intense interest in this matter is not shared by a senior Minister in the Government. Nevertheless, for those who are concerned about this, it is a matter of general principle that I do not think that a government or a government agency should use its resources in this way to raise money on the open market in a fashion that will have considerable detriment to private collectors and to people who have made bona fide investments. The best that I can hope for is that Senator Button will at least undertake to ensure that this matter is referred to his colleague, Mr Duffy, the Minister for Communications, and that some consideration is given to whether Australia Post should be allowed to proceed. I understand that the first auction is not scheduled to take place until July, but there will be four of them spread over the next 12 months or so.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that Australia Post has entered into proper negotiations with those who may be affected. I do not believe that Australia Post is attempting to raise money to fill its archival collection in the correct fashion. I do believe that the effect that this will have on the Australian market will be an undesirable one. Minor as the matter is, it is nevertheless a matter on which the Minister should take some advice and see whether he can prevent this from happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take just a short time of the Senate to bring before it the plight of the farmers who are down here probably for the fourth of fifth time, lobbying to try to explain and put their point of view to the Ministers of the Hawke Government. We have seen them on a number of occasions. The first group of about 50,000 farmers came down here last year, I think on 1 July. They put their problems and their concerns to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) but, of course, nothing has happened since that time. Interest rates have gone up. Commodity prices have fallen, although I accept that the Government has no responsibility for that. I have a summary that I have prepared that I want to have recorded in Hansard. The summary refers to points that the farmers have lost-reductions in allowances or the loss of allowances for the rural community.

SPEECH.PARA: I plead on behalf of the rural community. At the moment the rural community is honestly on its knees, with no hope in sight. Farmers cannot keep up with the ever rising interest rates. There is just a big blank void in front of them and they cannot see how they can ever get ahead of the situation. All they can see is a great, dismal bankruptcy staring them in the face. They are in Canberra making a last desperate plea for something to be done. There are a number of things that this Government can do. It can start by restoring some of the allowances that have been taken away from them. I seek leave to incorporate a list of those allowances in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, did you show the document to the relevant Minister?
—I showed the document to Senator Button and he assured me that it would be all right.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LABOR'S ADVERSE BUDGETARY DECISIONS ON PRIMARY INDUSTRY
May Mini Budget: 1983
1. Reduction of general depreciation allowances.
2. Removal of the tax incentive from the Income Equalisation Deposit Scheme.
3. Increase by 2 cents a litre the excise on aviation fuel.
4. Abolition of the special depreciation allowance for petrol storage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I hope that the Government will take the plight of the farmers and rural communities into consideration when it brings down its package on 15 April, next Tuesday. I know that 170,000 farmers will be looking expectantly to see some hope on the horizon. I hope that this Government honours its commitments to the sugar industry and to the general farming industries; I sincerely hope that there is some future for the wealth creators of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of taxpayers had taxable incomes above $22,000, in the 1982-83 income tax year.
(2) What percentage of the total cost to the Budget of the Dependent Spouse/Daughter/Housekeeper rebates combined went to those taxpayers with taxable incomes greater than $22,000 in 1982-83.
(3) What percentage of all taxpayers in 1982-83, received either a Dependent Spouse/Daughter/Housekeeper rebate.
(4) What percentage of taxpayers with incomes: (a) between $22,000 and $31,999 and (b) over $32,000, received either a Dependent Spouse/Daughter/Housekeeper rebate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 17 per cent of taxable individuals in the 1982-83 income year had taxable incomes above $22,000.

(2) 31 per cent of the amount of rebates allowed for dependent Spouse or Daughter-Housekeeper rebates in the 1982-83 income year were allowed to taxable individuals with taxable incomes above $22,000.
(3) 19 per cent of taxable individuals in the 1982-83 income year were allowed a rebate for a dependent Spouse or Daughter-Housekeeper.

(4) In the 1982-83 income year, (a) 37 per cent of taxable individuals with taxable incomes between $22,000 and $31,999, and (b) 32 per cent of those with taxable incomes above $32,000, were allowed a rebate for a dependent Spouse or Daughter-Housekeeper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 7 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present legal status of the former Northern Territory pastoral leases known as `Goodparla' and `Gimbat' which have been resumed by the Commonwealth Government.
(2) What is the present legal status of any mining tenements which had been granted over portions of these leases prior to their resumption.
(3) Will the Commonwealth Government if there is any doubt about the security of tenure under any such mining leases remove the doubts as a matter of urgency.
(4) Will the Commonwealth Government protect the rights of the holders of any such mining tenements in the event of the declaration of Stage 3 of Kakadu National Park.

(5) What action does the Government propose to take in respect of any applications for exploration licences or mining tenements which have already been made but not granted in the event of the declaration of Stage 3 of Kakadu National Park.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Northern Territory pastoral leases known as `Goodparla' and `Gimbat' have not been resumed by the Commonwealth; the present legal status of the pastoral leases is the same as that which existed prior to the granting of self-government to the Northern Territory, i.e. 50 year pastoral leases held from the Commonwealth since 1961 and 1962 respectively.
(2) The legal status of mining tenements granted over portions of these leases prior to self-government is as provided under sections 69-70 of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978.
(3) There is no such doubt about the security of tenure of such mining leases.
(4) The rights of the holders of such tenements would be preserved in accordance with the provisions of section 8B of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975.

(5) The Government is currently addressing various matters associated with the incorporation of the `Gimbat' and `Goodparla' pastoral leases into Kakadu National Park. Until the Government has completed its consideration of the matter I am not in a position to outline the Government's intentions regarding future exploration and mining.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Afghan refugees are present in Pakistan and Iran, and what percentage of the total number of Afghan refugees does this figure represent.
(2) What was the population of Afghanistan before the Soviet invasion in 1979.
(3) Can an estimate be given of:
(a) how many Afghans have been killed as a result of the Soviet invasion and occupation;
(b) how many soldiers in the Afghan Army and the Soviet occupying forces have been killed; and
(c) how many Afghans have died in refugee camps.

(4) Why did the Australian Government decrease its support for assistance programs by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross for Afghan refugees in Pakistan from $6.363m in 1983-84 to $4.525m in 1984-85 and an estimated $4.600m in 1985-86.
(5) Is the number of refugees coming out of Afghanistan increasing, decreasing or stable.
(6) Does the Australian Government provide any humanitarian aid to the Afghan refugees in Iran.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to the Government of Pakistan there were approximately 3 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan at the end of 1985. Official Iranian estimates put the number of Afghan refugees in Iran, as at mid-1985, at 1.8 million. These figures represent about 99% of the total number of Afghan refugees.
(2) An official census conducted in June 1979, six months before the Soviet invasion, put the population of Afghanistan at 15.5 million.

(a) It is not possible to provide any reliable estimate of the total number of Afghans killed as a result of the Soviet invasion and occupation of Afghanistan, but the casualties have been significant. Claims by some resistance leaders put the number of Afghan casualties in the millions but the true figure may not be that high.

(b) Because of mass desertions from the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan military it is not possible to assess accurately the number of Afghan military personnel killed in Afghanistan in the past six years. However, it has been estimated that there have been 25,000-30,000 Soviet casualties in the past six years. This figure includes both dead and wounded.

(c) No statistical records are kept by either the Government of Pakistan or the UNHCR of deaths in Afghan refugee camps in Pakistan. In Iran there are no refugee camps as such. A number of short term reception centres have been established by the Government of Iran but Afghan refugees remain at these centres for no more than two months before being absorbed into local communities.

(4) In 1983-84 Australia's assistance to Afghan refugees in Pakistan comprised 25,000 metric tonnes (M.T.) of wheat plus freight at a cost of $4.985 million (channelled through the World Food Program) and $1.303 million for a water drilling program co-ordinated by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to which Australia pledged assistance in 1982. The latter contribution was never intended to be a continuing commitment and was provided to purchase equipment such as a water drilling rig, drilling accessories and trucks.

In 1984-85 Australia's food aid contribution was reduced to $4.749 million, comprising 20,000 M.T. of wheat, 155 M.T. of high protein biscuits (and freight charges). This reduction reflected tight budgetary restraint and the need to cater for increased and urgent needs in Africa. There was also a non-food component of $190,000 covering the final payment to the water drilling project.

As a result of final accounting, total figures for Australia's assistance to Afghan refugees in 1983-84 and 1984-85 have been adjusted from those used by Senator Jessop and provided in the response to Question No. 1977 of 1985. The changes in the figures result from a revision of the costs incurred in providing the water drilling equipment to the UNHCR in 1983-84, and from increases in the final delivered costs of the food aid component in 1984-85. The totals are:

The further reduction of Australia's assistance to Afghan refugees, to an estimated $4.6 million in 1985-86, reflects the finalising of our contribution to the water drilling project and the continued need to direct aid to the crisis in Africa from other regions.

(5) It is difficult to estimate the number of refugees coming out of Afghanistan during any particular period. Evidence suggests, however, that there was a marginal increase in the outflow of refugees from Afghanistan in 1985 compared to either 1983 or 1984.
(6) The Australian Government does not provide humanitarian assistance to Afghan refugees in Iran.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government agree that the Soviet Union's unilateral nuclear test ban moratorium is a positive step towards a bilateral US/USSR test ban, which is in turn essential to the conclusion of a Comprehensive Test Ban (CTB).

(2) Does the Government agree that Secretary Gorbachev's recently stated willingness to accept on-site verification of a test ban within the USSR removes the United States' major stated objection to a CTB.

(3) Is the Government of the view that continued United States nuclear testing, in addition to facilitating the development of new nuclear warheads will allow the development of X-ray lasers for the Star Wars programme, and that this is a major factor in the United States' failure to reciprocate the USSR test ban moratorium.
(4) Has the Government consulted with the United States over these matters; if so, what has been the response.
(5) Is United States reciprocation of the test ban moratorium likely, in the Government's view.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government welcomes any interruption of the nuclear testing programs and has welcomed the Soviet Union's unilateral moratorium on nuclear explosions. The Government agrees that the cooperation of both superpowers is essential if a comprehensive test ban Treaty (CTBT) is to be concluded. The Soviet moratorium would be a positive step towards a CTBT if both parties agreed that this was a sensible way of working towards a CTBT. However, this is not the case. The Government's own position is that the most direct path to a CTBT is to address and overcome the outstanding verification problems. This view is supported by the history of the long quest for a CTBT.

(2) No. The Government agrees that Secretary-General Gorbachev's recent statements on verification are encouraging although it should be borne in mind that the Soviet Union accepted the principle of on-site inspection in the CTBT context during the 1977/80 trilateral negotiations. The Government hopes that the Soviet Union will now be willing to engage in the process of translating these principles into concrete arrangements for the verification of a CTBT. Doing so would address an important United States objection to a CTBT. To this point the Soviet Union has declined to address the verification issues which are an essential part of any process of negotiating a CTBT.

(3) The United States Government has stated that a CTBT is a long-term objective that would be acceptable in the context of broad, deep and verifiable arms reduction, substantially improved verification capabilities, expanded confidence-building measures, greater balance in conventional forces and at a time when a nuclear deterrent is no longer as essential an element as currently for international security and stability. I have no evidence which would substantiate the honourable senator's statement that research into X-ray lasers for possible application in a system of defence against ballistic missiles is a major factor in the United States decision not to join the Soviet testing moratorium; although I presume it is one consideration.

(4) Yes. The Australian and United States Governments have regular consultations on these matters. In the course of these consultations we have reiterated our strong support for the early conclusion of a CTBT. We have been kept informed of the United States position in regard to the Soviet moratorium and the reasons for that position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia abstain from voting on Item No. 50 (Vote number 3 of Meeting number 113, Resolution number 40/80B) in the General Assembly of the United Nations on 12 December 1985.
(2) Was the subject of the vote `The cessation of all test explosions of nuclear weapons'.
(3) Did 121 nations vote for the Resolution, 3 vote against it and 24 abstain.
(4) Did Australia abstain; if so, why, and who took the decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.

(4) Yes. Australia abstained on the resolution in question primarily because it did not provide for the development of adequate means of verification of compliance with a comprehensive test ban treaty. The issue of verification is important but technically difficult and, in our view, should be given the utmost attention in a body like the Conference on Disarmament.

For this same reason, we also had difficulty with the call in the resolution in question for a moratorium on testing to precede the negotiation and establishment of appropriate means of verifying such a moratorium. Australia is not opposed to a moratorium on nuclear testing but as a matter of principle we could not support a call on the nuclear weapon States to enter into an arrangement that may not be adequately verifiable.

Finally, as is clear from the title, the resolution addresses nuclear weapon tests. Australia's firm view is that a CTBT should also embrace so-called peaceful nuclear explosions. I would note that, in one place, the resolution uses the apparently comprehensive formulation `complete cessation of nuclear-test explosions' and Australia was encouraged by this change in the language of the resolution as compared with previous years.
The decision to abstain was made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

Australia's support for a complete end to all nuclear testing by all States for all time was manifested by the resolution which Australia sponsored, together with New Zealand on the urgent need for a comprehensive test ban treaty (Resolution 40/81).
